I'd recommend it, but it's not for me. I've tried multiple times to get into it, but it's not fun.
It's well made and decisions you make matter.

It's difficult, requiring planning and a bit of luck. Maybe more than a bit of luck.
If you like brutal RPGs where the decisions are permanent and luck can be for or against you, you would probably like this.

I don't like it because of how punishing it is. The intro rings true: "Darkest Dungeon is about making the most of a bad situation." There are too many bad situations for me to have fun.
a really relaxing game, if you ignore all the stressful parts

This game is frustrating, annoying and is at no point fun to play.

10/10 would recommend 

also learnt the word indefatigable from this game

This is one of the best games ever made.

Honestly, not sure why it's taken me this long to make a review of this game. I'm kind of nearly 10 years too late (Oh my fuck-ing god it's been almost ten years jesus christ) but since the Autumn Sale is here a lot of people may be checking this game out so I need to pump out the propaganda.

I'll start with a brief overview of the pros and cons of the game for those who just want a quick review, and then go into detail afterwards. 

Pros:

-Phenomenal Turn-Based Gameplay. Simple but so damn good.

-Incredible Art Direction and Character Design. Hauntingly beautiful.

-Amazing Atmosphere, and Narration. Seriously...Wayne June's performance elevates this game to another level.

-Challenging yet Rewarding. Loot is always exciting to find and earn.

-Stress Concept is Unique and Helps it Stand Out

-Perfect Music. Ambiance and Combat themes capture what they need to amazingly.

-Great Modding Scene....if you ignore the gooners (Seriously why for this game in specific is it so bad?)

Cons:

-Difficulty Can Be A Turnoff. Easier difficulty modes exist, but characters WILL die in this game. 

-Critical Hits are Punishing. They feel good to pull off, but enemy crits can erase a heavily invested character.

-Idk man I'm struggling to come up with any uhhhh stress act outs are kind of annoying and the crimson curse can be too ig

Now for the detailed review.  Where to even begin? The game-play is multifaceted yet easy to understand. This game is called a Rouge-like...but I don't think that's entirely accurate. Sure, dungeons are randomized but your heroes retain their upgrades, trinkets and skills. Progression is much more permanent in this game, with your dungeon delving allowing the estate to grow and grant you new bonuses, shops and better heroes for the future challenges. The game-play loop in very simple terms is to expand your estate and set out on ever more dangerous expeditions with your heroes in order to eventually take on The Darkest Dungeon.

Speaking of, let's talk heroes. There are several different classes in this game- each sporting 8 unique skills. The characters excel in different positions but can be played in many different ways. The back-line healer? Yeah, she can beat the shit out of people in the front ranks too. It makes understanding each one very rewarding and fun. The skills themselves are easy to understand but can also expand into many complex and powerful setups and strategies. Want a team that stacks DoT? Maybe on that applies a mark to one enemy and guns it down? There's a lot of variation here. Your party is still human, though, and are vulnerable to the stress of the expedition.

This game's big calling card is the stress system. It's extremely memorable, and much simpler to understand than it sounds. In short, you can just consider it as a second health-bar with lower stakes. Certain attacks will deal stress damage, which causes a hero's stress to increase. If it gets too high, they will face a resolve check. 75% of the time they will fall into madness, and gain a random affliction. These afflictions can make characters act out against your commands and even hurt their allies. It can admittedly be frustrating to deal with, so managing your stress is important. Many hero skills, trinkets and prioritization of killing stress-causing enemies can make this easier to deal with, thankfully. If a character's stress bar fills out again, they'll suffer a heart attack which can leave them only one hit away from death.

25% of the time, however, your character will become virtuous during a resolve check. Unlike afflictions, these make your character much stronger and even de-stress the rest of your team and themselves. It's very satisfying to dread having a character reach a resolve check in a hard fight, only for them to emerge virtuous and end up saving the entire party. Careful, though, because this game is not afraid to remind you of just how mortal a man really is.

If you're as brain rotted and mentally ill as me, you may know what a Pokemon Nuzlocke is. The game works very similarly to that. if you're normal, then its simply just that characters die permanently. Your favorite Crusader or Leper can be killed forever- barring a very rare event which allows you to bring one character back. This creates real, palpable stakes to each adventure and allows you to develop attachment to your favorite digital freak. I love Darkest Dungeon 2 as well, but this one of the things this game just does better than it. For some, though, this may be a turnoff. Pouring investment and emotional favoritism into your Grave Robber only for her to die brutally to a monster that looks like a deflated testicle? Not for everyone, sadly.

Moving onto the artistic side, this game is hauntingly beautiful in so many different ways. The art, music, voice-work and story are dark, grungy and desolate but are so enrapturing and sometimes even motivational. Sure, 90% of the game is about humanity's corruption and eventual inescapable demise...but god does it feel good to crit and enemy or kill a boss. Each victory feels earned and like one step has been made closer to the end of the corruption.

 This is in no small part helped by the phenomenal narration by Wayne June, who has sadly passed away. In this game, he plays the role of your ancestor and constantly drops lore of the world and comments about your campaign. It sets the mood so perfectly and even bleeds into the game-play. This game has crunch to it- scoring a critical hit makes the game zoom in, and sparks a powerful voice line from your ancestor. Even non-critical hits will have voice lines that make the moment feel powerful and memorable. I think it's at its best when your character's stress breaks- only for them to remain resolute and virtuous. Hearing the narrator cry "Many fall in the face of chaos, but not this one. Not today!" as your beloved little gremlin Plague Doctor scores back after back crit? Yeah, this is cocaine for pathetic white boys like me.

The cons really are hard to pinpoint for me. Yes, the challenge can be frustrating. A badly timed crit can wipe an entire party of invested heroes and you'll want to just shut off the PC right there. It's always worth trying again, though, because as desolate as the game may feel sometimes, there are always more heroes waiting in the stagecoach. There is always hope of rising back up from the ashes and using the estate you've built to raise a new army and take vengeance for your fallen friends. 

The odds are stacked against you, and the game wants you to feel the crushing burden of failure. The game may not be for you and that's okay. If you're willing, though, then there's always a path forward. This game is one of the best uses of video games as a medium to create art I've ever seen. Because you aren't just being told to feel despair, you're actively experiencing it. You don't have to look for the meaning, because it's what you make of it. You'll fall, and you will rise up again. The message of the game is hope- to keep trying no matter how many heroes die or how many expeditions result in disaster, because eventually you will succeed...

against The Darkest Dungeon.

10/10
The game UI and control are perfect for mobile. Wish the game can be ported to mobile so I can rage on the bus

This game gave me IRL stress related sleep issues, fear of managing, schizophrenia, trauma, and depression.

i have 12 hours playtime.

If you don't find grinding out hours to learn strategy and preparing for all scenarios(and still failing due to RNG) fun then consider this recommend poisonous, stay away from the game. It's meant to frustrate you and challenge you to do better. Lots of people don't find joy in that sort of challenge for a video game.

Your characters arrive, grind, expire or are in dire need of respite. The story is a nice setup but quickly gets lost in the grind. My god, are you going to grind in this game. Even updating your Stage Coach to bring in more characters at higher levels will do little to stop the never ending need to grind up characters because of the games systems. Whether it by dying to stress or bad rolls. The non-character mechanics(ex. Town Events, torch light, spawning of mini-bosses) in the game are nice and not only match the themes of dire times but also keep the player constantly managing more than just character gear. Leveling up things in your town home base was wildly helpful but nothing screamed over powered. There's a variety of characters and each has their own move set(with the exception of Arbelast and Musketeer, they're identical. Musketeer is a reskin and DLC that as of right now is free), gear, and 'trinkets'(items that go into one of two slots per character that can influence them. Generic or class-specific). The quirks your characters can get from the dungeon add even more to consider, or to cure, anytime they delve and get stressed out. The narration is nice even if it starts to sound mocking after a certain amount of time with repetition, and the designs overall are very cool. 

This game isn't perfectly balanced but it has so much going for it. I highly recommend it for players like me who enjoy being constantly challenged and beating the odds. If that's not your preference the game goes on sale often for under $5 USD, and even then I would recommend it for it's interesting mechanics for a short while. The DLC aren't anything I would rave about enough to mention in the base game review.

Generic tips and tricks for the interested;

-Upgrade your Stage Coach early! It brings in new characters to use. The more slots it can show the better the odds of showing a class you want to use. Even better, there may be characters above level one so you don't invest as much time into a fresh prospect for the dungeons

-Watch out for your Stress. It can drag a team down and be deadly, as you'll soon find out. How do you manage Stress besides the obvious of 'keep light nearby'? Kill enemies that begin in positions 3, and 4. They tend to have more Stress-based abilities

-Stun is your most powerful friend, if you can get an enemy to have that condition

-Trinkets are always underrated

-The Cove is a deadly area on Stygian, just flat out avoid it
Amazing game, I finished it several times outside of Steam. Couldn't buy it when I first played cuz I was broke, bought later to support the creators.
Touched an object and then a horror beyond my imagination wiped me. 10/10 game

A masterclass in dungeon crawler gameplay. An epic journey worth the time as you train your heroes and gather loot to prepare yourself for the namesake Darkest Dungeon in the endgame. The voice of the sadly passed Wayne June for the Ancestor turns the makings of a great game into a legendary one. The atmosphere of the game really shows the terrifying nature of venturing into these dungeons.

You will die, You will cry, and you will be angry.

Yet that is the beauty of the game, Overconfidence is a slow insidious killer.

This is my favorite strategy game of all time.  (Which means it's the best, obviously.)

"Darkest Dungeon is about making the most of a bad situation.  Quests will fail or must be abandoned.  Heroes will die.  And when they die, they stay dead.  Progress autosaves constantly, so actions are permanent.

The game expects a lot out of you.  How far will you push your adventurers?  How much are you willing to risk in your quest to restore the Hamlet?  What will you sacrifice to save the life of your favorite hero?"

I've never played a game that better explained it design goals nor did a better job of meeting them.  That's the game, right there.  I have this game on three different systems.  You WILL fail quests.  You WILL get ambushed by spiders and watch helplessly as they kill a character.  You WILL feel like you've been unfairly cheated.  But disaster is Darkest Dungeon's secret spice.  It makes every decision more meaningful and every victory sweeter, and Red Hook Studios added just the right amount of that spice.

You've probably heard it said that this game is hard.  At the end of the day, though, at the normal difficulty level there's no way to lose.  Winning isn't a matter of strategic mastery, it's a matter of emotional endurance.   Finishing the game is hard only because giving up is easy.

Do I recommend this game?  Duh.  But I'll add that if you, too, are an adult who loved Pokemon for its strategic elements, don't let the wildly different aethetics throw you off the scent:  you've gotta play this.

The devs said it best : " Darkest dungeon is a game about making the most out of a bad situation. "

And bad situations are pretty much a constant in this game... Everything is rigged against you, just when you start thinking it cant happen to you, the RNG will make sure it happens to you ! Very good dungeon crawler undoubtedly.

Most people who do these things make an actual attempt to write a proper review, offering an honest and fair moral critique based on healthy critical thought, meant to serve the reader with the objective state of things. Others prefer to write a one-line statement with humorous intent. But I would like to bring only one thing to this board of digital notices — this game has made me sick.

I have felt things in my intestines which I could not have imagined sensing during the course of my life. Like living, crawling, greasy serpents, these aches staggered me relentlessly. I want my hair back. After facing the horrible reality of this game, I have noticed my hairline slowly, but steadily, marching backward.

Hours went by, my sorrowful companions fell one by one, and I replaced them only with new witnesses to the carnage that awaited them in the deeper parts of the ruined chasms. As these poor souls fell into despair, their anguish became mine, for I had made the mistake of entering this microcosm not as a nihilist, but as an altruist.

Now, I wake each day with a bald, marked-up skull and shadows below my eyes. I stare into the reflection in the foggy mirror at something that once resembled a man. God is dead — in the hearts where good intentions once lay.

I would start on the "radiant" or 'easy' difficulty when playing this game for the first time (I wish I had). It takes a while to get a sense of which characters synergize, what the challenges and rewards of each biome are, how to manage your money, etc. As the game suggests after the opening credit, this learning curve can mean you lose a lot of characters, money, and progress... often. However, once you understand the mechanics and gimmicks, the losses and successes feel genuinely earned, the game play loop is fun and rewarding, and the DLCs all add interesting and unique mechanics to the game to make it feel fresh, interesting, and replayable. Would recommend, just know it takes a few hours to get there!

Firstly, game is so slow. Not the gameplay or story progression but the animations are slow. If you want to really enjoy it you need faster darkest dungon mod, my fav is the one in nexus.
It saves hours in a campaign.
Then the tutorial is slow, it becomes a chore every game.
Then you need to complete 5-10 quests so you can unlock all the buildings and see heroes you want to use.

Even then it's grind mostly. Need busts to upgrade buildings so you grind busts. Heroes need exp but missions suck so you grind them on same missions.

Tip: Instead of choosing a party from ground up for every mission you can implement a corps like system with solid teams.
It's easier to manage who gets to rest and who goes out with dedicated teams. It would be cool addition to have two parties out at the same time so they train outside your control or a way to train heroes without grinding.

And game doesn't even respects when you do all that and raise a good hero.
Your crusader who is sole survivor of a boss fight, trained and equipped well. Gets random crit, blighted in one round and then dies next round without ever getting a chance to be healed.
It would be reasonable if enemies were faster and it makes sense a legend can die to a bastard arrow but game calculating who takes turns is stupid. 
Instead of hero with 9+ speed the skeleton guy with 1 can take priority sometimes. There should be safeguards like if hero has more than double speed or 20 dodge and enemy's accuracy is debuffed, it should be certain they will miss or certain hero will get to strike first.

And crits make no sense, enemy does a critical attack but it only hurts a little,but your heroes still get stressed out. 
You can lose heroes in stupid ways like they refuse to eat a meal then they starve+death's door+ stressed from death's door+heart attack. And you can't do anything while it's happening. It's dumb.

I think best feature is having quirks and trinkets to personalize your heroes, making them feel special.
But majority of quirks and trinkets are simply useless and clutter the game instead. Or have stupid debuffs that ruin them. Or simply too weak you don't even bother equipping one.

Heroes getting quirks in town events-activities is a nice touch.

Getting random quirks after quests however makes no sense. Virtous melee hero who survives deathly encounter earns a ranged trait for no reason.
Quirk earning is a wasted potential.

It would be more enjoyable and it would feel more personal if traits were given by specific actions. Ex:
-Guy who disarms traps more gets better at it.
-Heroes that get afflicted constantly breaksdown completely needing proper treatment or goes 
full psychotic.-And make it double edged sword, instead of simply stress debuff add +%25 
damage so he is unstable but stong making it a decision to treat that hero or not- 
-Guy who goes to warrens a lot should be warrens explorer. -This enables you to make region specific teams.-
-Guy who lost a close friend to beast should be beast hater.

Heroes that proved their worth or sole survivors of bossfights got things like "Veteran's guilt" or "Local Legend" that also effects other teammates making them calmer since they are adventuring with a guy that 1v1 an alligator. Or the guy who got afflicted and killed his own teammate making his future teammates stressed and more likely to turn paranoid.
It would feel more personal when you lose those heroes.

Quirks and stress is what makes this game unique.
There should be a lot more quirks and diseases but important ones that make you care not -%5 melee damage. Imagine diseases spreading in barracks, or progressing worse and heroes getting more and more tired and needing treatment after you non stop used them for a month. 
"Irrepressible" should not be simply +%5 virtue chance. That makes it useless clutter, give him a good buff so we can rely on that hero not letting us down.
 
You don't feel anything when guy with no reaction to his own actions and randomly gained quirks die to a random reason you couldn't avoid.

Most trinkets are mediocre while good ones have stupid debuffs that ruin them for no reason, earning that trinket is really challenging at first why not simply let player enjoy it?

Grinding could be fun too but all the missions are essentially same:
-Walk around the dungeon until you see enough rooms.
-Activate 3 items (or gather 3 items from rooms) So walk around dungeon until you see enough rooms.
-Skirmish/Cleanse Walk around dungeon and find room battles. Only difference is you can avoid wandering uselessly but that's only if you get to scout before, but scouting is chance based too. So same.
-Scouting quest is literally walking around dungeon
-Boss missions are slightly different since you avoid other rooms to hold on to your strength until boss.
Also why does bosses punish you for trying new tactics? Break the guy's stuff and they all get angrier and stronger. Or the game doesn't even let you break it. It's opposite of Fear&Hunger  instead of outsmarting the fight you get punished for not grinding until boss HP runs out. 

And all the dungeons feel the same, even though warrens are square shaped and weald is straightforward because of how missions are structured, you end up walking in a single line.

They could have added more variation, making dispersed paths that doesn't connect later on, with different rewards and risks so you can choose where to go or add VIP escort missions or survival ones where you fend off waves-Like farmstead-. Or ability to send another party to a lower level mission so they can grind themselves while acknowledging threat of losing them out of your control.
Like add option to split party in half in scouting mission, so they scout faster but they need to be more self sustaining, and why not make speed more useful.
Or make the layout more complex and give us ability to flank enemies in cleansing missions with a %100 chance to surprise them.
Or attend to hamlet's needs to upgrade it instead of grinding busts.

Things like buying campfires in short quests, using laudanum for stress healing, scouting for the room right next to you so you can plan ahead, arbalest/musketeer healing bleed, plague doctor having stronger battlefield medicine so she can be a weak healer, occultist having min 1 heal so he doesn't kill people randomly with bleed, campfire scouting skills being passive so you get the buff but don't spend time on it, meeting allies or another party you sent before etc. would make the game a lot more enjoyable.

Camping skills take too much time and half of them are useless. Scouting should be given free at least for the room right next to you and all the skills related to scouting are so useless they are not worth the time and instead should be passive skill for equipping that hero. Having +%25 damage is better than idk a chance to scout ahead the corridor you will walk anyways because there is no other way.

Only differences are farmstead dlc and player's choice antiquarian rushes for money those feel nice but still you have to grind for the good missions and resources.

It's really, mostly grinding for a while so you can train your heroes faster and then they will reject your orders or die for some nonsense. It's a common thing for the game to unnecessarily restrict stuff so you grind more. Mods can help with that.
This game needs a remake with all of it's mods. Promise is good but you can't connect with heroes and their loses because heroes themselves don't care, they don't care if they accidently kill some of their own, or they don't care if they survive hell, they simply go to tavern have some drinks and get a random quirk.
Also Ancestor is cool but he talks too much for my taste.

Also even though nobody cares about it, I think it would be a nice touch if the same effect was seen at the same time. Like two heroes get blighted, instead of the horror+blight it would be comfier showing the blight once on two heroes and then the horror.

In short, alcoholic Knights clear the dungeons of freaks in order to end up in a mental hospital, or even go to the other world. Did you think there would be shining armor and unicorns?

After Darkest Dungeon, you will begin to look at role-playing games in a different way, in which the characters calmly descend into the inferno of hell. A man is just a shaking piece of meat, ready to go crazy at any moment. Here you will have to balance on the edge between "everything is bad" and "everything is very bad" — and it will be incredibly enjoyable.

The narrator's voice alone and his gloomy comments are enough to fully experience the meaninglessness of existence in this dying world [b][i] (press F for the Legend) [/i][/b]

It's difficult to rate this game. On one hand, it's fun, has solid mechanics, it's got a good atmosphere.
On the other, it's very repetitive, slow, grindy, brutally harsh, swingy in range results and not an interesting story/premise.

I feel like the game simply doesn't respect your time enough. And because of that, I can't recommend it.

To back up my point. Only about 20% of players has even managed to get 4, 6th (full) level characters, which you need to go into the hardest/main dungeon of the game. I needed 45 hours for this.

>built a high lvl team in 6h with nice trinkets just to get fully squad wiped by a random group of zombie grunts that kept stunning my healer. 

10/10 game

Some people love the punishment.  I do not.  There doesn't actually seem to be all that much to the gameplay itself and success and failure can feel like a complete flip of the coin.  The game absolutely oozes style and atmosphere but that can only carry it so far before your session can become an exercise in relief that you made it through or frustration that the RNG resulted in your party getting rolled and wasting your time.  There are some things you can learn for your next run but the RNG ensures that whether or not you can actually put that knowledge to use is another story.  If you enjoy trial and error and have lots of free time, you might enjoy it.  If your time is more limited and you use games as a bit of escape, you probably want to pass here.  I tried to like this game but it wouldn't let me.
fun stressful game with enemy's that pull bullshit moves out their asses when you start wining

I've quit the game three times and finally powered through it so I could feel justified in giving the negative review.

To start off, the story is alright and the art/music/voiceover are great. No real complaints there.

The actual game design starts off fine until you reach the later stages of the game, where it just becomes an exercise in wasting your time. It takes forever to grind a hero to level 6, which is fine for the first part of the game, but becomes majorly tedious as you continue to play. The game forces characters to become unusable in lower tier missions, so you can't have an experienced hero help power level your plebs like you can in, say, XCOM. I understand what they were trying to do but it doesn't work. It makes the game an incredible grind fest.

The worst part of the game was the fact that when you finish a part of the main story dungeon, you can't use those four heroes in any subsequent story dungeon. The in universe reason for this is flimsy, but even if it wasn't this is a terrible piece of game design just meant to prolong the game and keep you grinding for no reason. 

Within the dungeons, even travelling about seems to want to waste your time. Your party walks at a snail's pace, and scouting (which is essential) takes forever to resolve. Animations like curio interactions and trap disarming/triggers also take forever.

Balance wise the game is also wack. Seems like the only real choice to make is to stack accuracy on all your heroes because high level enemies have such ridiculous dodge chances. Stuns are OP, consumables take no action and healers are only useful for topping you off so there's very little actual meaningful decisions to make during combat. 

Don't waste your time. The game looks and sounds nice but plays terribly.

A brutal yet brilliant and unforgettable journey into madness.
Not for the faint of heart, you will bleed ,break, suffer and falter to the horrors or merely one misstep.

But every victory feels beyond exhilaration when you overcome and survive adversity.

The atmosphere, Gothic art, suspense filled music and a brilliant narrator will have you hooked.
In a nutshell it's a "base management" (for my lack of better terms) Roster and hero management, and a turn based combat game with the following aspects

Deep tactical combat 
Unique Stress and affliction system that ads to the psychological management of your heroes
Meaningful risk-reward decisions in and out of combat
Diverse Hero classes with unique playstyles and skill synergies
Long term investment campaign
Replayability 

Some RNG can feel unlucky, it's part of the game and to be fair, RNG can feel very rewarding too. I think that it is a fair system in it's full glory or despair. I personally find it fun and challenging in that sense.
It can be punishing for new players, but if you feel like a challenge and ready to lock in and explore the game, I highly recommend it.

If you are fearful of how brutal it is, I still recommend it, it's a thrilling experience, even if you just play 2-3 runs and quit, the game has already earned it's title, as the DARKEST DUNGEON !!!
if you enjoy adhd, late night adderall driven gaming sessions of carefully grooming and training your squad to end the night in a fast forward death session.. this game is for you.

Anger is power - unleash it!

Many fall in the face of chaos, but not this one. Not today.

A moment of clarity in the eye of the storm..

Adversity can foster hope, and resilience..

A moment of valor shines brightest against a backdrop of despair.

the game gets good after you realise its optimal to spend 30 minutes stalling one fight to reduce your stress to 0, also i do not recommend this game to people with lives and things to do other then click flare 30 times.

TL:DR rating - 9/10

I have owned this game for 7 years but never ended up playing it beyond the first intro mission. Well, better late than never I suppose. I'm 7 years behind but I beat it finally.

This is a very fun but very stress inducing game untill you hit lategame and figure out all the items, hero combinations and enemy types+attacks.
Once you get the hang of these things, this becomes a lot less stressful. Yes there is a bit of RNG involved, but mostly you can use items and stat bonuses and perks to shift the odds in your favour massively.

The enemies are pure nightmare fuel and some of them might compel you to punch your monitor(I am looking at you hateful Virago).
This is not an easy game by any means, but it is extremely rewarding once you put in the time to understand all it has to offer. Super fun.
The dungeon is a lil bit dark, it's quite the fun experience though!

Darkest Dungeons made me feel the creeping madness from every twisted voice line or sound effect, crawling into my ear like the squishing of bloated maggots or the anguished squeems of those depraved of hope.

The mood setting for this game is just phenomenal and feels, despite its 2D art style and lack of character animation, like the characters are still writhing through it all, clasping through the roads of damnation.

The gameplay for the game feels solid and has its ups and downs in regards to the sanity system but feels fair and balanced. My biggest problem, however, is that it doesn't explain anything about how the game stats work and interact with each other, leaving you to figure it out yourself.

The classes for the game are all decent, but some of them, like the Leper, just aren't as strong as the others, which makes them feel not worth it, and considering you have to level up the character, it's just a waste of effort, which in a game this old should have been balanced out—though it's mostly minor since all the characters are at least usable to some extent, but still.

Overall, the music for the game is good  and atmospheric, great to use as a backdrop for something like a D&D campaign, as it fades into the background of the gameplay nicely to give that little extra bit to pull you further into the game.

This game isn't easy and isn't for everyone, but if you're up for a challenge, it's a joy to behold as you get attached to your delvers, only for them to shrivel to the floor from a heart attack. I'd recommend it.

[i]Darkest Dungeon[/i] is by every aspect an experience tailored for me, and easily fits in my top 15 favourite game [b]ever[/b] played. That being said, I can see why it wouldn't be the case for everyone else. I tend to keep my reviews from brief to slightly detailed on this platform, but [i]Darkest Dungeon[/i] is such a unique journey that truly resonated with me. I think it's probably for the best to lay out the full picture; especially if you've just got yourself the game, or are wondering if it would be wise buying it during a sale. So allow me to set the stage, in a structured way, to show you what truly is awaiting you in this wretched land. 

[i]"You remember our venerable house, opulent and imperial..."[/i]

[b][u] The Good [/u][/b] 

[i]Presentation[/i]
One of the strongest point of [i]Darkest Dungeon[/i] from the very start, and a reason why it personally stuck so much with me, is how original and defined in [u]presentation & concept it truly is[/u]. The game is set in the Gothic era, but it also inspires itself a lot from Lovecraftian Horror and it fully takes advantage of it. From the first cinematic, the game engulfs you in mystery, and does it with very few words. To be honest, I sometime let it fully play when booting up the game after a long time, or when I feel like fully immersing myself in my ancestor's delirium. 

[u]The visuals[/u], like the title suggests, are very dim and unsaturated. The atmosphere is dark and unwelcoming, even the neighbouring Hamlet that's now decrepit is devoid-ed of any colours. Grotesque black strokes of ink shape the outlines of everything: The [i]UI[/i]s, the menus, the texts' typeface, the buildings, the various collectable objects and more so of every characters. That being said, that plays it to its favour as it fully ties in to the story and how atrocious the situation is: it sets the stage and raises the stake on how depressing the world truly has gone into.

While we are talking graphics, the next logical thing would be to address the [u]monster and enemy design[/u]. To make fairly brief, they are nothing short of amazing and well thought-out. Many monsters have standard ghastly look as you begin : classic skeletons, to wild dogs and madmen. As you progress the game and ramp up in mission difficulties however, they get even more ghoulish. Bosses are the true stars in design though, and should be as they are centre-piece to the story and they all have a unique grotesque, Lovecraftian design to show it.       

As for [u]the music and overall sound design[/u], the tone is gloomy, sometime unnervingly silent while traversing the many dungeons' halls, other time thrilling when engaging in combat. My favourite piece however, is the [i]"The Hamlet"[/i], the track that plays when visiting the main hub - the Hamlet. I think that Stuart Chatwood, the composer, really did something special there. This track is very intriguing to me as it tethers between drops of hopeful and depressive tones. I think they've really nailed in creating a soothing yet unsettling atmosphere.

The jewel of sound design though, inevitably goes to [u]the narration of the game[/u], performed by talented and late [b]Wayne June[/b] (May he rest in peace), that is present throughout every player choice, every discovery and at every return to the Hamlet, after previous expeditions. Something about the cadence of the words and his deep gravelling voice just tie in perfectly with the writing, and it hitches the right spot in my psyche. I sometimes catch myself quoting him out loud during the day, or when playing other games. His overall performance like his character's nightmares was otherworldly and he is sorely missed.   

[b][u] The more challenging [/u][/b] 

[i]"And now the true test... hold fast, or expire?."[/i]

The gameplay loop on the surface is simple : 

Recruit heroes, gather them in an handcrafted party tailored to certain needs via each individual skills (Heroes that benefit from debuffs, status effects, against certain enemy type, etc), and level up their Resolve by exploring procedurely generated dungeons and vanquishing the evil and sometime bosses roaming within them. Gather, in a restrained inventory, loot throughout the expeditions such as gold to buy the various services the town offers like skill and arsenal upgrades, or other valuable trinkets and heirloom to upgrade town buildings; thus improving the efficiency of said services. Rinse and repeat until your roster is strong enough to face the Darkest Dungeon.

The real gripe with a lot of players, especially the new ones is [u]the learning curve and overall investment [/u] of time required to fully enjoy the game. Heroes that end up dying is a very punishing experience during the expeditions as it drastically lowers the chances of successful runs, and it can also set you back a lot in the beginning when resources are finite. A roster that does not perish instantly though can slowly succumb to stress, which adds in a ton of unwanted parameters, and can be the difference between victory and defeat. The real challenge then is to carefully avoid stressing your party during expeditions as it can lead to members skipping their turn, stressing other heroes or worse, succumbing to heart attacks. I've had my fair share of failed excursions from a single recruit that managed to raise panic in the entire party, leading to a full team wipe. Though this is hard at first, you definitely can and should learn from failure, i.e. what stresses your recruits and how to stop it. This accumulated experience makes each run smoother and all the more satisfying when victorious.

Some will say that a game should be fully enjoyable from the get go, and I do respect this opinion, which is why I understand if these same people end up putting the game down for a while, if not forever. Truth be told, I had a previous 60 hour run that sat idle for a good year when I came back to the game. [i]Darkest Dungeon[/i] is a very complicated game to get into, even at standard difficulty. A good tip is to leave the wiki opened and gather as much information / strategies as possible. This will smooth out the experience.  

My recommendations : 
- Upgrade gears and skills first, as they improve your heroes' base stats, and make them deadlier and harder to hit in more difficult dungeons.
- DO NOT activate the Crimson Court and Colour of Madness DLCs as they increase the game difficulty drastically in the beginning, since they implement various, deadlier monsters that can spawn in standard regions. 
- Start with the standard vanilla experience with maybe new hero class unlocked, and activate Districts and other DLCs as you progress and gain confidence.
- Take your time, open the Wiki, seek resources
- Most of all: have fun and be patient, be mindful, be prepared

[h3]TL;DR:[/h3]  
[i]Darkest Dungeon[/i] is a dark and excellent turned-based combat RPG, especially for those who'll be patient enough to learn its core principles and let the game open itself to them. Its presentation, visuals, music and overall atmosphere are uniquely ghoulish and adequate to the setting. The gameplay loop itself while sometime frustrating after losing a hero, failing missions or because of what seems to be random factors, is a perfect proof of a steep, and unforgiving learning curve; it also tie in perfectly with the setting of an unforgiving story. This is probably the most discouraging aspect of the game though, as it can sometimes be a heavy grind and is also why it could potentially be a bad choice for some. Though for those who are looking for a new kind of challenge, a lengthy investment, who'll want to spend it theory crafting and learning the many systems will find an intriguing story, a satisfying loop of scrounging dungeons, gathering resources and obliterating the monstrous opposition, and overall a uniquely phenomenal game.

I can recommended this game but with a large * above it. The visuals, story telling and atmosphere are amazing and truly deliver on a Victorian era cosmic horror story. The core idea is insanely fun and addicting, building up a team of adventurers to go back and slay the evil in your family's manor. Managing things like plagues, hunger and the ever necessary sanity/stress mechanic a Lovecraft game should have. Hero's get traits that buff/nerf them, builds can be diverse with classes being able to be built in support/tank/dps kinda ways. The modding community is also insanely healthy adding new classes, skins and mechanics into the game. However all this good does have an * attached to it so lets get into it. 

This game is built to hate you, playing the game is a massive hate fest towards you. This stems from its largest issue RNG.
While RNG isnt new to turn based rpgs its used way to much as a crutch in DD. To the point some fights feel less hard and more of a dice roll to see if you can win. Death spirals can occur from an unlucky crit by the enemy. A wandering boss can just appear and end a run. This is especially prevalent in the early game where losing a single hero can be extremely punishing. It tilts a bit too much in the "unfair" category where you are often left frustrated more than elated from the RNG. 
However when you reach late game it swings in the opposite direction. Meta builds can completely steamroll certain sections of the game. Sometimes RNG will kill one of your god heroes but you have built up such a force and resources its just a minor set back and annoyance.

Over all I love DD despite its flaw of overusing RNG for difficulty. The game has a lot there and if you either can stomach the coin flips (or down load some mods to make it more fair) the game is extremely enjoyable and atmospheric.
Just stay away from the DLCs

Fuck, this game is hard.

This is a harsh world, and a harsh gameplay loop to go with it.  
Permadeath looms for your troops, any decision could cost them their sanity, or their life.

And the aesthetic fits the harshness of the game, sometimes too much.  The game asks A LOT from a player who wants to complete it, with endgame missions requiring perfect builds, perfect strategy, and even sometimes, a little RNG to avoid fatalities.  

Maybe that's the design, you can't save everyone, especially not in this place, but for someone who strives to keep all of their soldiers alive, it is pain.

Darkest Dungeon is a brutal and unforgettable experience that tests both your strategy and your nerves. The combat is punishing and sometimes unfair, where every decision matters and mistakes are never forgiven. Yet the game never lies to you, you always have a choice, and every action is permanent. Even though it’s hard, it feels much better this way, every victory is earned, and every loss has weight. For me, Darkest Dungeon is a must-play game, especially if you like challenging turn-by-turn combat, and a dark oppressive atmosphere.

I love turn-based RPG and Roguelike + lite but I just can't have fun with this game. There's nothing wrong with the combat or roguelite aspects, it's the gameplay that I have problems with. Endless grind for very little progress, constant micromanaging, RNG for RNG's sake.

I think this game was a response for the lack of challenge people felt was in their games and lives when this game came out. I think this is a pendulum swing that swung too far.

Once you get the knack of the game, it isn't so much that it's hard, but rather that it's tedious in a way that isn't fun. Your characters aren't characters really, they're resources to be expended for progression. The mechanics of the fights are extremely RNG dependent, so you have to look past the current dungeon and plan ahead. It leaves little room for strategy, and more like you're reacting to the RNG that occurs, which is always tilted against you.

 At first it's frustrating as hell, then you get used to it and it's just boring and kind of depressing. You don't feel like you have much control of anything because in order to get anywhere, you have to roll the die and hope your party doesn't self-sabotage itself too hard before you can finish out the dungeon. When you inevitably lose characters, or gamble your entire party and lose, then you have to spend time rerunning content to build new characters to flip the coin all over again.  

This game doesn't allow for the player to have much agency, the strategy is to stay patient and take the smartest risks you can, all of which are stacked against you, and don't get attached to any of your characters because eventually rng will claim them. 

If you crave struggle for struggle's sake, or if you're an outright masochist who enjoys grinding, you might like this game. Maybe you just want to feel like you accomplished something but withstanding the punishment, so you can hold it over other people's heads or something if that's your thing. Otherwise, I don't recommend it. This game isn't fun, it's just a long lesson in learning how to move on from loss.

Where Courage Is Tested: Defy the Darkness with Darkest Dungeon
Darkest Dungeon is one of the most striking and harrowing examples of the rogue-like dungeon crawler genre. With its gothic atmosphere, challenging mechanics, and deep storytelling, it offers players not just a game, but an experience. If you're looking for an adventure filled with dark themes, strategic depth, and psychological tension, this game will captivate you.

A Visual Feast: A Dark Work of Art
Darkest Dungeon’s gothic art style and bleak atmosphere pull you in from the very first moment. Every pixel seems meticulously crafted to convey the game’s hopeless and eerie world. Dark corridors, decaying castles, and spine-chilling dungeons create a constant sense of tension and curiosity. The narrator is a phenomenal element that completes this atmosphere—every sentence, every inflection injects the game’s soul directly into your veins.

Death and Madness: The Dance of Strategy and Psychology
In Darkest Dungeon, you’re not just fighting enemies—you’re also managing your characters’ mental health. Psychological elements like stress, fear, paranoia, and even heroism create a unique experience every time you play. Your characters battle not only physically but mentally as well, making this one of the game’s most distinctive features.

The combat system is a strategic delight. Every move and every ability must be used at the right moment. A single misstep can cost you your entire team. Discovering the synergy between your characters’ classes and abilities is incredibly rewarding. By experimenting with different combinations, you can craft your own strategies with each run.

A Dark Legacy: Lost in the Depths of Story
The game tasks you with cleansing the decaying estate and dungeons left behind by a relative who bequeathed you a dark legacy. But this mission isn’t just a physical struggle—it’s an internal reckoning. Every expedition, every loss, pulls you deeper into the game’s dark world. The story isn’t spoon-fed; instead, it’s discovered piece by piece, keeping your curiosity constantly alive.

Difficulty: Brutal but Fair
Darkest Dungeon is definitely not an easy game. You’ll suffer losses, your characters will die, and sometimes all your progress will crumble in an instant. However, this very difficulty is what makes the game so compelling. Every success, every small victory is rewarded with a profound sense of satisfaction. If you enjoy challenging games, Darkest Dungeon will undoubtedly satisfy you.

Conclusion: Dive into the Darkness and Lose Yourself
Darkest Dungeon is not just a game; it’s an experience. With its dark atmosphere, deep strategy, and psychological elements, it mesmerizes players. If you’re looking for a tough, thought-provoking game that keeps you constantly on edge, Darkest Dungeon is perfect for you. Playing this game is like embarking on an adventure. And remember:
"In the dark, even the boldest hearts tremble."

You need to play many almost completely identical missions in order to level up your heroes in order to encounter some new event or boss, said event or boss then decimating your team since you specifically needed heroes and/or strategy you could not have known in advance.

Then, without your best people and items, there's no choice but to engage in a lot of boring leveling up grind again as pushing on unprepared will certainly be fatal.

However, nothing guarantees you will succeed on that attempt either so this is basically a try and error game (which is great) but where each try is preceeded by a whole lot of boring grind and time wasting.

This is too bad as games where you have to figure out how to win through trial and error are among my favorites.

However, the only way one could go through a playthrough of Darkest Dungeon successfully without spending an inordinate amount of time being bored and frustrated would be by just looking up how to approach bosses and challenges, but that would also make the game pointless.

I'm usually not someone who complains about RNG, but there are just so many variables to manage in this game that I find it hard to really plan for anything. Even on easy mode, the grind is insane. The art is very nice, but dungeons are also made with just a handful of assets. The zones feel different from each other, but each run feels exactly the same. There isn't really a story to hook you either. I feel like there are much better tough as nails, emergent storytelling, RPGs out there.

Honestly not worth the time or grind. Extremely repetitive in the mid-game and doesn't take much strategy once you figure the systems out. 

I really the other aspects of this game like the visuals and wanted to give this a fair chance but unfortunately it just isn't that fun.

This game is not fun if you're not masochistic. It's challenging but not in a fun way like say dark souls would be. What do I mean by this? In dark souls any challenge can be overcome with skill like learning attack patterns, knowing when to dodge and parry. This game? No, you could go in a prepared as you fucking can and still have your entire party wiped because the game decided the enemy should land 6 crits in a row while 3 of your teammates either miss or the enemy dodge. This game has features to make losing a character less frustrating like giving you their trinkets back on death or upgrading the stage coach so that higher level characters can join so you don't have to start entirely by scratch. Other than all that the game IS NOT for people who want a challenge that actually requires you to use every bit of brain power you have, this game just masks complete rng bullshit as 'A challenge' the game even says this game is about making the best out of a bad situation but you physically can't because its just luck based at the end of the day. Even on its easiest difficulty you will struggle to the point of dropping the game entirely. Bad game design if they want reoccurring players or players recommending this. 

Is this to say its a bad game? No, this game is amazing. Just the game being designed around losing literal HOURS of work by luck based shenanigans is something not everyone will put up with.

In my opinion, [i] Darkest Dungeon [/i] is the very best of the turn-based genre, and presents an incredibly ludonarrative experience. Playing it is also one of the cruelest things you can do to yourself.

At the forefront of this game's many strengths is its tightly-knit concept and execution. Every element of the experience is interwoven with the game's central themes: we are mortal, to battle despair is an uphill battle, and there is never enough rations— nor morale— for us to come back the same, if at all. The game is drenched in an incredibly congruent atmosphere of despair and gloom that seeps from every orifice. The sound design, music, writing, gameplay- it all comes together seamlessly to form a methodical waltz with the reaper.

The central gameplay loop is a simple to pick up, incredibly difficult to master dance of positioning, resource management, risk assessment, with a healthy initial dose of trial and error. The learning curve doesn't drop you off the side of a cliff by any means, difficulty increases smoothly throughout the game and the true tests of patience are saved for much, much later. The combat mechanics are both simple enough to immediately intuit and complex enough to have players contemplating the best courses of action for genuine stretches of time even after learning everything there is to know about a given encounter.

The aforementioned strength of this game, its unrelenting consistency, shines through not only in the gameplay. You have likely heard its iconic narration at some point as an audio clip or elsewhere- and for good reason. The late Wayne June delivers an extensive set of unforgettable lines both poignant and sardonic for every scenario. All of the art is lovingly rendered in a gritty, hand-drawn gothic 'comic-esque' style that is immediately both memorable and effective. The score is harsh and tense, and blends both orchestra and ambiance while merging seamlessly with the sound design.

The UI of the game blends in perfectly with the style, and monster design is exceptional- striking atrocities whose visuals genuinely stuck with me. The bosses take this even further in the right direction. All of this is to say, every single damn aspect of this game comes together flawlessly to make an absolute masterclass of being relentlessly depressing, all while dangling slivers of hope overhead.

This game is not without its challenges- it does not hold any punches, and that is precisely why it is both great and terrible. Rarely have even horror games made me so nervous and frustrated as the Estate had at its nadir. There is a definitive level of randomness that can at times feel unfair- though this is largely able to be mitigated with careful planning, such knowledge often comes from failure. You cannot learn responsibility until you see the effects of your negligence.

It should be said that this game can be, at times, genuinely infuriating- which is absolutely a valid reason to pass on this game. It is not enough to preserve the flesh- you must constantly contend with your heroes' ever-rising levels of stress, threatening to unravel all your hard work in an instant. You will have to accommodate for disease, for negative quirks, and for sheer happenstance. I had to restart my save from the ground up to successfully finish the campaign and even then I struggled through the entire way. It is only by standing again after the fall that you will see this game through, so if you struggle with motivating yourself after being beaten down or dislike when games take things away from you this is certainly not up your alley. Of course, without such dire stakes the tension and dread I've waxed poetic about throughout this review would all but dissipate like a bad dream under the morning sun.

If you like horror (cosmic or gothic!), turn-based strategy, or difficult games you owe it to yourself to play this one.
Overconfidence is a slow and insidious killer.

Darkest Dungeon feels like a fist fight in your dreams. You know what you want to do and how to do it but your arms, your legs, your reflexes are too weak and slow and you just end up getting your ass kicked. But as you keep playing the feeling of masochism keeps growing, you get addicted to the pain and before you even know it you've developed stockholm syndrome for this game. Horrible experience that you can't get enough of. 10/10 would recommend to give it a try and go in blind it just adds so much to the experience. The game is amazing and fun, the learning curve is kinda steep but after the first 5-10 dungeon runs you pretty much know what the gameplay loop is... until you don't... then you're 30 hours in and you pretty much know what you're doing... except you don't, because your whole team just got critted 7 times in a row by an enemy that has 3 moves per turn...... I love this game

Of the handful of hours I have dedicated to this game, I have to say this is one of the more fun dungeon type crawlers I have played. It is a unique gem that has stood the test of time in my eyes. Offering a nitty gritty strategy turn based combat system with a wide cast of party combinations.

This game by far isn't for the faint of heart, it will test your management skills and patience and sometimes it really does come down to luck. There is a bit of a learning curve when it comes to the game and even the easiest difficulty can be challenging at times. 

A great plus is the mod community for this game has really expanded upon the longevity of the game. If you ever feel like combat is too slow? There is a mod that speeds it up, getting tired of the same team comp? There are mods that add new classes. Finding the game too hard? There are mods that make some of the mechanics easier.

literally just masochism incarnate. I have restarted this game half a dozen times because when it calls itself "unforgiving" thats code for God himself will use RNG as proof of his existence to give you the absolute worst outcome feasibly possible. There is literally no amount of micromanageMENT (hi) that will spare your entire squad being wiped from what would otherwise be an easy combat. Attack? miss literally 9 times in a row...no that is not a joke. Try to debuff? once again miss. But dont worry the enemy will land every attack on you and drive your characters insane so they will do more damage to eachother or cutting their own wrists like an emo girl whos mother doesnt understand her than they can on a pack of rabid mutts. But hey at least you can always back out right? thats how gambling works where you realize the fates are lubing up the strap on you can nope the fuck out...right? fuck no youll fail to flee an encounter several times so your squad is wiped and you're stuck trying to decide how to proceed when your best characters are worm food, the rest are drowning in mental health issues and diseases and oh ye youre fucking broke...the only feasible solution if you are as blessed as myself is to simply treat recruits like revolving slave labor to be tormented until theyre killed or thrown away like a cheap abused condom in order to grind enough resources to level up all of your facilities...what a fun game

It actually took me several attempts to complete this game, but ya, I enjoyed the stress inducing systems, the risk vs reward systems. I would say the dlcs offer a little diversion from the "main" quest line, offering a few bits of new loot, characters and enemies to face. What I would say though is that the dlcs always seemed a lil expensive for what they were, though they go on sale fairly frequently. I prolly should warn you that this game was no cakewalk for me, I played on the difficulty below "darkest" or hardest and found the game challenging and stressful at times (as it should be.)

Strangely, though I didn't watch any walk-throughs for this game I found that most of the bosses reasonably fair. What you need to be aware of is that there are times where the RNG feels to be actively fighting against you, certain runs will just fail regardless of the tactics you use or employ. Maybe the RNG got better over the updates but there are times when you aren't getting more than a few fights into a dungeon before it goes horribly horribly wrong. I confess I pushed myself to complete this coz I purchased the Black Relinquary. I hear that Darkest Dungeon 2 doesn't have the same love as the first one, but the first game was good as far as I was concerned. You never know, in 5 or so years I might get the second one.

This is not only a great tactical game with a beautifully presented grimdark style, embodied visually, with original game mechanics and exciting music, but also, as it turned out during the game, one of the best infusions of Lovecraftian ideas into the game world!
Never really liked or understood "Lovecraftian" in games, probably due to poor implementation and often poor balanced mixing with other styles. In this case, I saw, in my opinion, a perfectly smooth and moderate injection into the medieval dark fantasy world! Things are not revealed much, which makes you look for answers, many of which will remain open for your imagination!
Thank you for this experience! I'm your fan now!

Masterpiece, no doubt about it.
The artstyle, lore, and the wonderful soundtrack coupled with clever and interesting game mechanics give an experience like no other. Your heroes will be crushed by either/or a lack of knowledge (which is how you will learn) the unforgiving nature of the Darkest Dungeon, and finally by fickle rng. Beat it with wise choices, cutting losses and not letting the game roll its loaded dice against you.
The dlc is alright, although the crimson court is borderline masochism as you're literally adding mosquitoes to your eldritch horrors. The multiplayer is a fun idea but doomed to fail because of human nature.
I bought this game twice (first time was on another platform, without the dlc), which, to those who know me, should speak volumes about this game.
Wayne June as the Ancestor is VA masterclass. A voice you might've heard in H. P. Lovecraft audiobooks tells of the grim and terrible tales which explain how things got so bad, each one compelling you to push forward and hear the next one, until the very end.
Rest in Peace [*]

I want to like this game, I really do, but it’s just not for me.

Tried playing through this game three times years apart. The last time even on the lower difficulty. But this game is just a never ending grind.

You nearly always play the same two mission types, that basically don’t really differ in what you are doing. The map layout seems to be random, often leading to a metric ton of backtracking. Also the enemy placement seems to be random, so sometimes it’s just a walking simulator.

The jump up in difficulty between the 4 levels of quests is insane. The first level is trivial after a short while and some of the heroes you have are not even going on them anymore. But the next level enemies one-shot people because I have not yet grinded out enough stuff on the low level quests to fully upgrade my heroes. So it seems like I’m just supposed to grind out low level quests forever.

I would highly suggest not getting this game unless you really, really don’t mind grinding.

Darkest Dungeon, what is there to say about this game. Is it fun? Yes, to a degree. The art style is great, music and basic gameplay is solid, and the eldritch lore is fun. However, this game is frustrating, it is hard, and it is usually very unfair. As frustrating as it is, the community is also a mixed bag. There are a lot of modders creating great mods, new characters, and all sorts of fun things that make the game so much more enjoyable and less of a grind. However, if you have anything to say negatively about the game, you'll also be met with "get good" and "you're playing wrong". 

Is Darkest Dungeon a great representation of what Red Hook Studios was going for with their vision? For sure. Is the game a FUN game, if you like grinding, randomized chance with your characters, and needless repetition and pointless limits to make the game longer, then also yes. You may be thinking, why is this a positive review then? Well, for all my criticism of the game, it is still good. I did beat the Darkest Dungeon, and I did have fun doing so at times. The game is a very unique and provides a lot to players that enjoy this type of game, although that isn't me persay. 

The DLCs make the game worse but offer new gameplay mechanics that spice up the game and adds greater difficulty for the masochists who enjoy it. The base game is great and while there are better ways to speed up the grind, and I would recommend downloading mods to do just that, I can't help but say that there is a reason the community who loves this game is so fiercely loyal to it that any criticism is shut down. This game fills a unique niche that deserves to have this game, and if you find yourself to be a part of that then this is for sure a buy. For anyone else? Look into it, do your research, and if you end up wanting to give it a chance then get it on sale. You may like what you find.

I only recommend this to try-hard, patient, with lots of time to play and grind).

I played the game on radiant (less hard mode) - and I only found when I finished by getting the achievement for radiant mode. And it was HARD.

And by HARD I mean, grindy, slow, unforgiven, boring. It feels like does not want you to complete it.

Buuuut, is it fun? YES. The game has very nice mechanics, atmosphere, variance. The most fun I had was leveling different heroes, trying different party formation, mixing and matching. Doing mid-level dungeons and some bosses were really fun.

But then, to push to final dungeon, the stronger bosses, it becomes and endless grinding. You can't play easier dungeons with a stronger hero, for the sake of passing weeks, or simply farm money and heirlooms - nope. You have to either recruiter new low level heroes or TRY to grind in more difficult dungeons, and that is where it starts to get slow, boring, and of course, unforgiving - heroes get worn out, too much, to the point where grinding resources becomes not optimal. And that was the "easier" mode. I will not try the "normal".

And finally, without mods to revive fallen heroes faster, and to allow any hero in any dungeon level, I would never finish the game.

It is not my type of game, at least not at the current moment in life, with short time to dedicate to games, and with less energy to do repetitive tasks (in-game) with almost no rewards and with lots of frustrating outcomes - real life is already unforgiving and frustrating enough. I would say this game is the "Souls-like" of turn-based party combat games.

Still, good game overall, I understand its targets and for the target player, it will probably be a ton of fun.

Darkest Dungeon has quickly become one of my favorite games of all time.

It's the perfect combination of rogue-like and base-builder with intense difficulty spikes.

I'm not really good at this game, because I grow way too attached to my heroes and can't stand to loose them, but it's still a very fun game I could only recommend. Figuring out party synergies is fantastic. The way you're forced to handle your heroes with care and give them their well-deserved time off is so good at forcing you to make use of all your heroes and not just your favourites.

Sure, the game could explain a little more about negative and positive inflictions and how to keep an eye on them and not just how to keep them and get rid of them, because it's really expensive in the beginning and it definitely still contains a lot of BS, I lost my first hero to four consecutive critical hits.

Also the atmosphere and visual style are superb.

It's a really hard game for newcomers, but it's pretty great.

Great atmosphere, design, lore, and narration. The combat is initially fun, lots of different party compositions are viable. There is quite a bit of strategy involved in who to bring, and what skills to equip them with. The issue is that this game absolutely does not respect your time. 

You'll spend many many hours grinding up characters on apprentice level, only to repeat the same missions and combats over and over on veteran, and then finally champion. There are very minor additions and tweaks to enemy parties on the higher level dungeons, but ultimately the game is a repetitive slog that turns boring long before you're even close to finishing a single playthrough.

Darkest Dungeon uses a fantastically thematic stress mechanic and Xcom-style character progression system to really invoke the eldritch and gothic horror it portrays; tied together with a solid procedurally-generated dungeon system and turn-based combat - this one's a winner.

Been playing this game on and off on both GOG and Steam for about a decade now and it's definitely one of my favorite games of all time with roughly 300 hours between both versions. Great concept, great gameplay (if you're willing to accept how brutal it can to those who are inexperienced/unprepared), and an overall memorable experience. Each playthrough is a campaign in itself that'll last you days, weeks, or months depending on how you choose to pace it and I would recommend all of the DLC besides the butcher's circus, but that is completely free and has no impact on the main game so it wouldn't hurt to try it out and see if it's your thing.

If you're something who wants a challenging game that'll keep you busy I would 100% recommend this!

This game is so rigged, its unwinable by normal means.

This game is intensely fun. It is fun and frustrating in the best ways. It's fun to try and put together a team and level them up. You get attached but sometimes you have to let your adventurers go and replace them. It's challenging, creative, lots of great story, and the ambiance and narration are top notch.

132 hours I have in this game, and I have to consider carefully whether I want to recommend it or not. Hmm.

I've spent a lot of time and energy with this game, trying to do what it asks of me: build up a roster of flawed but powerful heroes; acquire the trinkets and estate upgrades necessary to attack the dungeons; work my way through the bosses to the Darkest Dungeon to finally complete it. It's not easy and failure is expected, and I appreciate that in a game's design when it's up front. 

However, this is not a game that respects your time or a particularly large amount of freedom of choice. There are better hero classes than others, there are trinkets you'll never use despite them being Legendary, and there are fights that your party are completely over-tuned for yet you lose because of dungeon balance. It's the last problem, fundamentally, that I take issue with. 

In the early and mid game it's possible to maintain heroes, the estate, and to progress without too much difficulty, although the game balance really fights you at each turn. It's not an enjoyable experience, and don't get me wrong, I like a challenge and I like having to made trade-offs. Darkest Dungeon's approach to this isn't fun though, certainly not beyond mid-game. It becomes a chore, a grind, and it feels like the higher level dungeons and monsters weren't tuned properly. The game goes from being challenging (with not much in the way of reward either) to being frustrating and incredibly disrespectful of your time invested.

I could go on but to be honest, I don't want to. I don't want to play this game anymore. I've tried so hard and so many times to complete it and it just feels like I'm fighting the wrong numbers that were entered into the monster stat blocks. There's no satisfaction anymore and I honestly feel like I'm wasting my time. There are better designed, more fun, and definitely less frustratingly unfair turn-based games like Darkest Dungeon. I think it's time I just forget about this game and consign it to the "almost fun but ultimately a let down" pile.

Mechanically speaking, this is complex and highly involved. But when you clicked purchase, you signed up for some grueling shit. This is some grueling shit. You can sweat the min-maxxing as much as you like, there's some random chance that your favorite characters could get killed off and you lose your investment in them. So you diversify your investments strategically throughout a campaign, building capable warriors and squads to send into dungeons. It may not be enough. The game is bleak, lurid, cursed and bathetically sad, but overall, in a very good way. The skill curve forces you to come to terms with dark and secretive hidden mechanical knowledge. Not one bit of it comes easily, you have to intuit and wrench insights from the game's sheltered hints, like some kind of philosopher of the esoteric.
It's a neat game, but it's just too hard for me to recommend to the average person. Even the "easiest" difficulty has provoked more gamer rage tears than the rest of my gaming history combined.

You can play smart as you want and be careful, but the AI design just screws you over.

Listen, I fully understand that there is a whole audience of people who love games like this and the ruthless suffering that it evokes even on normal difficulty. However, that is what this game is, in my opinion. This is a game built on making the players suffer massively and the good feelings a player is supposed to get is when they manager to get by.

I get that there is a whole world of optimization and trinket farming and management and class structure and skills and everything in the world. I get that you can read the guides and the wiki and the videos and keep plugging away and eventually figure out at least a little bit.

I still hate it. I hate how much this game wants you to suffer. From the theme and artwork to the gameplay and regularly losing characters you invested in and losing money and managing stress and bad quirks and diseases and afflictions. Everything about this game is antithetical to what I think is a good time and on those grounds I wholeheartedly do not recommend it. There are much better ways to spend your time in this world than relentlessly throwing yourself into repeated suffering and struggle. I have enough of that in my life, thanks.

I tried so hard to love this game and I just simply cannot get behind how awful and RNG based the game play is. It is the first game I have ever deleted out of sheer frustration. I have died numerous times on bosses to stupid RNG that just makes winning actually impossible, things happen that you cannot predict nor plan for constantly ruin the gameplay and the amount of hours a squad wipe has is beyond reasonable. 

I am a big fan of Turn based strategy games and have played a wide variety but Darkest Dungeon is the only one to leave such a bitter taste in my mouth after defeats, in which it feels like losses have come to pure bad luck that I could have never overcome, and this happens way more times than it should. Even the concept of whose turn it is being RNG makes no sense to me as it makes planning each battle and move practically impossible because you don't know if the enemy will attack or which one of yours will, if any.

The art is fantastic and the ambience is amazing, it is the main thing that kept me coming back. Honestly I just feel the gameplay would only need a few tweaks to be excellent. 

Online gameplay is also just a pure dumsterfire and any new players looking to get into it will have zero chance of even sniffing a win due to how cheesey and gimicky the multiplayer gameplay is.

Gameplay can basically boil down to a roll of the dice, if I wanted to do this I would just go to a casino.

The wonderful art style and an interesting turn based RPG combat system that has a heavy focus on building a team, preparation and planning results in a very appealing game. My big gripe with the game is that I think the overall design and concept goes very badly with the difficulty. It's sort of designed as a rouge like where characters are disposable and the dungeons change in design randomly. However, it takes hours of gameplay and a lot of resource investment to build up a character. Their deaths also don't really offer any sort of progression, it is just a straight downside. 

Bad RNG can lead to a countless lost hours and certain fights you cannot flee from, resulting in a potential wipe of hours and hours of gameplay. I personally think it's just not enjoyable to play this way. Because of how time wasting mistakes are, it's a pretty bad idea to go into things like boss fights blind. Which really kills a lot of the magic of the game for me, it's not super reasonable to actually explore and be surprised by playing blind. You can, I have gone into fights, lost people or had to retreat and then take it on later. But especially in the later levels it's just extremely time wasting. 

There is charm to challenge and the risk of losing big, but it's too time wasting for my tastes.

Don't take my words personally, I'm genuinely happy for those who like the game. It's not a bad game—I can see why people enjoy it—but it's just not my type of game. It’s been sitting in my library since 2021, but I always had other games I was more excited to play. I bought it because of many positive reviews. Honestly, the fact that only ~4% of players have finished it should’ve been a red flag for me.

I’ve heard people praise the combat, but in the two hours I played, it felt like the same repetitive cycle of switching between different attacks. I know that different class abilities can complement each other, but I didn’t get far enough into the game to really explore that—and honestly, I don’t think it would change how I feel about the core gameplay. What makes the combat and the main gameplay “varied” are the random events you can’t control—and that’s just not the kind of gameplay I enjoy. 

I get that the core of the game is how you respond to unpredictable, often negative events and try to minimize the damage. I know losing heroes is part of the experience. But the idea of spending hours leveling up a character only to have them die just kills any motivation to play the game. I don’t see the appeal in games that deliberately try to make the experience miserable by artificially ramping up the difficulty. 

Also, the lack of options to speed up or skip animations is a major downside for me. I don't want to watch the same animations over and over again.

[i]And before anyone says, “You only played for 2 hours”—I’ve been gaming for 30 years. I know pretty quickly whether something clicks with me or not. I’m confident that even if I put in more hours in the game, it won't change a thing. I'll just waste a couple of hours of my free time a day instead of playing what I like.[/i]

At first I thought the game was really fun, but the more I played, the harder it felt to rank up my heroes. I just don't think it's fun to play a game where my heroes get strenghtened negative traits because they open a crate twice in 1 round. Nor do I think it's fair to play vs a summoning boss in the third week, not even having the opportunity to upgrade a single skill or equipment. Wether they have low/high stress amounts at the end of a round doesn't even matter, statistically it didn't have a significant difference in the amount of positive/negative traits? Only high amounts of stress (100+) gave significantly more negative traits. Gaining negative traits left and right, and if I dont cleanse it in 2 weeks after, it becomes a strengtened one which costs 2k+ to dispell. Whether I use items to open crates, ditch heroes who have to many debuffs, and check which one act has an impact on the performance, it became boring pretty fast. 

I understand people think this game is fun, I like stress management games, but this is enduring, not managing

My opinion might differ again in the future, but this is my current standpoint
