As much as I want to enjoy this game, and in some ways do,  it is ultimately what could be a fantastic game, hampered by several critical failures of game-design.

1. Hunger strikes randomly, independent of when party members have last eaten or when hunger has last struck. This mechanic is also not really explained. I only discovered it when I lost a party member to starvation despite them having eaten recently and having rations in my pack (but not enough for the full party to eat all at once). Even worse, members of your party can become "full" from eating too many rations and can no longer consume them to gain health. Despite this, they can still take damage from a hunger event. Terrible.

2. You cannot bring heroes on missions that are a tier below them. I understand what the devs were going for here, but it unfortunately just does not work. It means that, as you level your roster, you may not have enough low level heroes to create a viable, or even complete, team for tier one quests. It also means spending way more time grinding out levels, rather than having your high level heroes help teach your lower level ones. It doesn't particularly matter, but the in-universe explanation is a bit flimsy, too. Thankfully, this is easily addressed with mods.

3. The biggest issue with Darkest Dungeon is that Red Hook Studios simply has a poor understanding of numbers. As you progress through the game to more difficult missions, enemy speed, dodge, etc. quickly outpace your own to a point that, difficulty aside, it starts to make lots of game mechanics irrelevant. Dodge stats, for example, already don't make sense. Enemies with relatively low dodge stats of 10-15 still manage to dodge constantly, but during champion level missions, you regularly encounter enemies with 40+ dodge, meaning that you simply won't do much damage if you don't build specifically for accuracy, disregarding all other aspects of combat. If an enemy gets a 50% damage reduction but still has 50 HP, the player just has to spend 10 turns grinding down the enemies health. Making gold and other quest rewards that are needed for advancement scarce doesn't make them seem more precious, it just means you have to grind out way more missions without doing a whole lot in between or feeling like you've progressed.


When Darkest Dungeon hits, it really does. The system it employs for positioning during fights is really cool and adds a new dimension of strategy to party planning and combat. I like the system for mental breaks. Characters in general are allowed to have so much depth and development, that I start to feel very attached to them. Unfortunately, getting to the fun bits of the game requires a massive grind that I'm trying to power through, but would not recommend to other players unless they are very much aware of this going into the game.

Dark, creepy, difficult, and fun, these words describe this game more then anything, you'll fight many things, creepy spiders, eldritch horrors, humans, and strange beasts, on your side are lepers, hound masters, abominations, vestals, men at arms, and more, and if for some reason you want more characters the modding community has many a fresh face for a new play though, heralds, cannoneers, krakenslayers, lamias, steel drivers, vigilantes, and much much more, 

The game is dark and atmospheric, and narrated wonderfully, "In time you will come to know the extent of my failiures" should become annoying because of how often it's played, but instead each time I hear it it just seems yet more bleaker, 

This game is also something of a turned based rpg, so if you like those this game will certainly scratch that itch.

I have such mixed opinions on this game, on one hand its super fun when the game plays ball and when the RNG goes your way genuinly amazing, but to get that you have to suffer so much. there are some outright stupid mechanics that completely ruin the game for me. the one that completely ruins the game for me is, if your character is too high level they cant compete in low level missions. which sounds fine on paper level everyone equally but considering the fact that you at the start only get 1 - 2 charecter per mission means that certain party memebers will eventaully level too high so you cant use them making them virtually useless until 4 charecters are the same level, or you rock a team A and just use the same 4 to level them equally. which ever way you did it you bring your high level team into a mission and its bound to happen but one will die its the nature of the game, when that does happen all that effort you put in makes them virtually useless with the game not even allowing you to deploy a 3 man team. and its the same thing over and over again, and i understand its the nature of the game that your party members are meant to die and you can change the game files to fix this issue but that just annoys me especially that a certain guy can just randomly spawn in kill a party member and force you to leave. 

I really dont think the game is bad if steam had a 50/50 review i would but it doesnt and i think the game is more annoying than it is enjoyable so im done dealing with the games nonsense

Darkest Dungeon excels because every mechanic feels meaningful and interconnected, turning each run into a thrilling test of skill, foresight, and adaptation. From the first click into the Ruins to the final boss confrontation, the game constantly challenges you to think, plan, and react — and rewarding you for doing so.

🔹 Stress as a Core System
Unlike most strategy games, Darkest Dungeon treats stress as a combat stat. It influences performance, triggers quirks, and creates dynamic personalities that change how your heroes behave. That means every fight isn’t just about HP — it’s about managing fear, trauma, and morale, making each decision feel weighty.

🔹 Positioning & Tactics
Positioning isn’t cosmetic — it dictates which skills can be used and how enemies will respond. Do you protect your squishier damage dealers up front? Do you shuffle mid‑battle to set up a powerful combo? Each placement choice directly impacts your strategy.

🔹 Combat Depth
Abilities aren’t just numbers — they have positioning requirements, cooldowns, and strategic uses that reward smart play. The turn‑based system feels fluid yet challenging, encouraging you to exploit enemy weaknesses, guard, stun, and outmaneuver your foes.

🔹 Resource & Party Management
Camps, provisions, and hamlet upgrades are not afterthoughts — they’re integral to success. Deciding when to camp, how much food to bring, what trinkets to equip, and who to send on which mission all require calculated planning. Poor logistics can be just as punishing as bad combat.

🔹 Permadeath & Consequences
Character losses aren’t merely setbacks — they reshape your roster and force you to adjust builds and tactics. This makes victories feel earned and losses deeply memorable. The constant threat of permanent consequence gives every expedition real stakes.

🔹 Synergy & Build Variety
With dozens of heroes and myriad upgrades and trinkets, the combinations of builds are deep and satisfying. Finding the synergy between skills, quirks, and trinkets becomes a strategic puzzle that never stops rewarding experimentation.

Darkest Dungeon’s mechanics turn stress, positioning, and resource decisions into a rich tactical tapestry. It’s demanding, smart, and deeply satisfying — a game that rewards strategy, adaptation, and mastery at every turn.

10/10 — one of the richest, smartest tactical RPG experiences ever made.

This is one of the most frustrating and unenjoyable games I have ever played. It's an exercise in pain and suffering. 

It's like an orphan abandoned in the streets of a third world country, scared and alone, hungry and wet, cold and anxious, searching and yearning for love, warmth, shelter and food. 

But there's hope, eyes that mirror twinkling stars in the dark sky. The occasional leftover still mildly warm that it finds scavenging. But there's hope when a kind stranger gives something nice, there's hope to study and learn. But there's that tinniest hope that everything will be alright even while getting beaten, violated and left in agony and pain. 

That hope, my friends, that small, tiny but significant hope is what makes you keep playing. And that because we are humans, we always strive to look for the best in the most difficult of times. Maybe it'll never be alright, maybe our time will never come but we are humans who can dream. 

Darkest Dungeon is a masterclass in design to bring out that small, clinging hope that we all humans have. I don't want you to play it but I recommend this game for I am human.

Darkest Dungeon does not ask the question, "What if something goes wrong?", because something will inevitably go wrong. No matter how well you prepare, no matter how well you play, something will go wrong. You will get crit, your weakest hero will get ganged up on, a random curio will decide to ruin your day, and you will find yourself perched at the very precipice of oblivion. 

The question the game asks is not, "What if something goes wrong?", but instead "What will you do when something goes wrong?" It is against the backdrop of despair set up by the dungeons that the brightest moments of valor can shine. It is thrilling to thread the needle and snatch victory from the jaws of defeat, and you will feel equal despair when your strategies fail and your heroes die. This game will bring out of you some the highest highs and the lowest lows, and for that I cannot recommend it enough.

Darkest Dungeon is a masterful blend of turn-based combat, dark atmosphere, and psychological tension. Its art style and narration create an unforgettable gothic experience, while the deep combat system rewards careful planning and strategic risk-taking. The game’s focus on stress, failure, and perseverance makes every victory feel earned, delivering a uniquely challenging and immersive experience.

Darkest Dungeon is an immersive downward spiral simulator in which the player bites theirn nails and pulls out their hair at the sight of enemy crits and their domino effect on their disposable, yet precious rag tag team of disfunctional wierdos.
It is a work of art carrying with it an atmosphere of lovecraftian cosmic horror that is carried by its gloomy comicbook style art and the absolute best narration ever put in a video game.

Darkest Dungeon is one of the best “hard but fair” games I’ve played in a long time.

One of my favorite things about it is how easy it is to play in short sessions. You can quit anytime and it autosaves (even mid-fight), which is perfect for me because I’m the kind of gamer that plays a little bit each day. I don’t rush games, so I really appreciate that it respects your time and lets you make progress without needing a long uninterrupted play session.

The art style is incredible and the whole game has this grim, gothic vibe that never gets old. The UI is clean, the animations are satisfying, and the combat system feels like it works exactly the way it should—punishing when you mess up, but rewarding when you start making smart choices.

It’s definitely challenging, but in a good way. Managing stress, taking risks, and trying to keep your team alive makes every expedition feel tense and meaningful. Even when things go wrong, it feels like part of the story instead of just “bad luck.”

The voice acting is also a huge highlight. The narrator adds so much personality and atmosphere that it honestly makes the whole game more memorable.

Overall, Darkest Dungeon is a super addictive strategy game with amazing style, great pacing, and real challenge. If you like tough games with strong atmosphere and satisfying progression, I 100% recommend it.

Oh boy where do you start with darkest dungeon.
The game is incredibly tantalizing to say the least, either you love it or you hate it.

Darkest dungeon is a rougelike that promises to take every ounce of your soul with it.
The core gameplay is pretty good and decently engaging, the atmopshere is absolutely fantastic, the visuals, the soundtrack, the narration, even the smaller ambient noises all work together to create an insane feeling of dread or triumph depending on the situation.

That being said, if you plan on playing without any mods this game can be a serious grind, leveling up, curing stress and ilness, gathering heirlooms. It all takes a while.

The game is incredibly polarizing as you could have incredible triumphant moments of victory as one of your party members lands a lucky crit or a virtue roll, but that can go both ways. You can have a member go insane despite the odds, miss one too many moves, or have a boss crit you at the wrong time, and losing a character you put in a lot of time into can take the wind out of your sails.

In summary - Darkest dungeon is a fantastic turn-based roguelike, it will drive not only your characters mad but you aswell, buy only if you're up for the grueling task.

I'm in quest 2 of 4 in the Darkest dungeon level, and can't seem to get the perfect party together to get it completed. I think it's on me for not having the perfect party (a plague doctor in there didn't work out like I thought), but having to be perfect turns me off a game. I've seen some folks suggest playing on radiant difficulty, not because it's easier but because there's less grind involved, and I would echo that suggestion if it's true.

Getting to the end does start feeling like grind for it's own sake. Each of the final quests takes a party of lvl 6 fully upgraded members to have a good attempt. I've lost 4 parties to the darkest dungeon quests so far (1 complete and 3 fails). Someone likes me starts doing the math after a while. Assuming you get them fully upgraded from the coach, you still have to invest 44,000 gold into a party for them to be fully equipped and skilled and the runs to get them from lvl 3 to lvl 6. I'm effectively down 176,000 gold on darkest dungeon parties, and after you complete one of the final quests, that party won't go back in. It's worn me down.

Darkest Dungeon remains one of the most distinctive and rewarding turn-based RPGs around, and one of my personal favorites.

The art style is iconic, immediately pulling you into its bleak world. Combat, despite being turn-based, is brutal and tense thanks to the outstanding sound and visual design — every encounter keeps you on edge, and felling an enemy feels incredibly satisfying.

The cast of heroes is fantastic — every character is unique, with clear roles and strengths, and experimenting with party compositions is a real highlight. The enemies and bosses are just as memorable.

The DLC are well worth playing, adding a great change of pace and meaningful new additions and mechanics; if you enjoy the base game, they’re close to essential.

My only real criticism is the late game. Progress starts to lose a little momentum, and managing your large roster of heroes can feel slightly tedious at times.

Even so, Darkest Dungeon is an easy recommendation — stylish, challenging, and deeply atmospheric. If you enjoy tactical RPGs, this is a must-play

This game is brutal, it even gives you a message saying as much when you start the game. Recruit and ship out a group of 4 to various dungeons to find treasure and complete tasks in turn based combat dungeon exploration.  However, the enemies often have a huge advantage and there are many mechanics that work against you including disease, lighting, insanity, and more. What little achievement you feel from conquering a dungeon is very quickly lost when you even lose a SINGLE party member as they are not only lost for good but you’ll have to retrain a whole new recruit if/when they appear. This isn’t too bad early to mid game, but late game when the dungeons get particularly cruel… it’s just completely disheartening and a slog since it takes time and gold that you will gain very little of.
Still working through the DLC and though I enjoy their themes… they also get a bit sluggish. Otherwise it’s decent enough if you don’t get too unlucky… but you will get unlucky VERY unlucky. A bit of a reluctant recommendation but a recommendation no less.

One of the hardest and most rage inducing games that you will ever play, But I love it! It's a turn-based dungeon crawler. You pull adventurers off of the wagon and throw them into hellish dungeons. You needn't worry about health as badly as you do their stress. If their stress is too high, they will refuse to listen to commands, interfere with your party, or even attack each other altogether. Then you need to spend your limited money to help them feel better. 

Your objective is to restore your hamlet to its previous glory as your uncle passes away and you inherit the land. You'll endure lovecraftian horrors and difficult enemies. If the fights aren't enough to frustrate you, consistent dungeon crawls where you will literally endure, back to back missed attacks from your party. 

My advice, do not have a favorite hero, because if they die, they are dead, forever, all your resources put into them is gone when they die, aside from some equipment. You can easily replace them, all heroes in this game are rteplacable. 

Enjoy raging!

Darkest Dungeon is a beautiful game with unprecedented tone. The pacing, sound design, visuals, and mechanics together seep through the monitor and impress its heavy motif on the player in indescribable ways. Because of this, its flaws become exponentially more frustrating and completely unacceptable.

The mechanics are presented at a base level quite well, but the intricacies that divide early and late-game success are entirely left for the player to discover and remember, with no in-game record or essential reminders of important modifiers, symbols, and terms. This turns simple human mistakes a player of any skill level can make into horrible blunders that kill characters and revert progress. As a Roguelite this is expected, by principle supplementing a valuable takeaway to entice the player to try again - [i]but there is definitionally no takeaway from simple human mistakes[/i]. By design, losing the mission in this common manner [i]has no inherent value[/i].

What inflates this flaw to immense size is the theme and spirit of the game. The demoralized narrator, harsh artstyle, and dirgeful soundtrack all remind the player of the thesis statement made on the opening text of the main menu: [i]Make the most of a bad situation[/i]. It convinces the player to accept the course of events and continue. The thing is, accepting a loss with no inherent value [i]can never be fun[/i], in any sense. To advise the player that it ought to be is some (extremely benign) form of emotional abuse.

⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐
Bought a “dungeon crawler.”
Ended up managing a therapy group for traumatized murder‑hobos.

You recruit heroes, send them into eldritch hellholes, and somehow the real boss fight is against stress, paranoia, fear, and masochism.

Turn‑based combat? Yes.
Permadeath? Oh yes.
Stress levels through the roof? Absolutely.

Every time you think “this run will be fine,” two party members go insane, one eats a trap, and the last screams “why did I sign up for this?!” before dying.

It’s not just a game — it’s a psychological horror RPG where your real enemy is your own poor life choices.

10/10
Perfect if you want your heroes traumatized and gloriously obliterated.

You open the game.
Everything seems fine.

Twenty hours later you’re thinking, “Yeah, this game is actually pretty good.”

Then strange insects appear. Your heroes get cursed and develop an unhealthy obsession with blood.
Suddenly you’re desperately trying to keep these geniuses alive.

You find a mysterious letter and decide to hunt the Baron.
On the way, you meet a crocodile.
The crocodile disagrees with your life choices and almost wipes your entire team.

Somehow you survive, find the Baron…
and he wipes your entire team properly.

You rage quit, accept that it was all a horrible fever dream,
restart the game, and pretend everything is fine.

10/10 suffering. Would descend into madness again.

Ruin has come to our family. You remember our venerable house, opulent and imperial, gazing proudly from its stoic perch above the moor? I lived all my years in that ancient, rumor shadowed manor, fattened by decadence and luxury - and yet I began to tire of conventional extravagance. Singular, unsettling tales suggested the mansion itself was a gateway to some fabulous and unnameable power. With relic and ritual I bent every effort towards the excavation and recovery of those long buried secrets, exhausting what remained of our family fortune on swarthy workmen and sturdy shovels.

At last in the salt soaked crags beneath the lowest foundations we unearthed that damnable portal of antediluvian evil. Our every step unsettled the ancient earth but we were in a realm of death and madness. In the end I alone fled laughing and wailing through those blackened arcades of antiquity until consciousness failed me.

You remember our venerable house, opulent and imperial. It is a festering abomination! I beg you. Return home; claim your birthright, and deliver our family from the ravenous, clutching shadows of the DARKEST DUNGEON.

Darkest Dungeon is a masterclass in punishing design—brutal, relentless, and utterly captivating.
⚔️ Difficulty & Challenge
- I’ll admit it: I’ve never beaten this game. The difficulty is merciless, and every run feels like a battle against despair as much as against monsters.
- Heroes break, parties crumble, and sometimes the dungeon itself feels alive, conspiring against you.
- Yet that’s the beauty of it—the challenge is the point. Every setback makes me want to try again.
🎭 Atmosphere & Presentation
- The gothic art style and haunting narration set the tone perfectly.
- The soundtrack and voice work immerse you in a world where hope is fragile and every decision carries weight.
💡 Why I Keep Coming Back
- Even in defeat, there’s satisfaction in pushing a little further, surviving one more encounter, or managing stress just enough to limp back to town.
- The game rewards persistence, teaching you to embrace failure as part of the journey.
✨ Final Thoughts
I may never conquer Darkest Dungeon, but that doesn’t stop me from trying. Its difficulty is its allure, and every attempt feels like a story worth telling. If you crave a challenge that tests not just your strategy but your resilience, this game is unforgettable.

I generally don't go for roguelikes unless they are phenomenal because it's a fine line to walk. It's a balancing act wherein the worse a game in this genre is balanced, the more awful the experience becomes. Well, not only did they nail a roguelike, they nailed a roguelike base-builder.

Nailing one is worthy of praise, but two? I'm not surprised that even after the release of the second game in this series, the first is still going strong and receiving updates.

✅ Art style: Unique and reminiscent of dark Fantasy comics.
✅ Replay Value: Impossibly good.
✅ MTX: the only "microtransactions" in DD are well priced DLC that expand the game.
✅ Difficulty: Punishing but flexible.
✅ Sound Design: Excellent, both in music and SFX
✅ Gameplay: The loop for this game is superb for the genre.

(A note on MTX: the DLC for Butchers Circus and the Musketeer Character are FREE, thereby adding a free character type and Multiplayer free of charge post-release)

I initially picked this game up because I thought the artstyle was cool and gritty. Now 100 hours later I understand that this game is not some hero's journey where the game tries to appear challenging through spongy enemies and terrible dialogue. No, this game makes it ABUNDANTLY clear that the odds are stacked against you by ripping away your precious heroes permanently when it so feels. It does not matter how leveled they are or what gear you give them to improve, there is ALWAYS a chance that your heroes die. 

Although the challenge of this game is immense, I do find that it is fair. Yes the enemies hit very hard, but if you build your characters out properly, you can hit them back just as hard if not harder. For example, if there is an enemy that completely negates 80% of damage taken, some heroes have skills that fully punch right through that for full damage, every time. Darkest Dungeon very much rewards smart tactics (unless the random dice rolls don't land in your favor). 

Darkest Dungeon also focuses in on the concept of risk/reward. For anyone considering buying the game, there is a torch that you can keep lit, and it grants you a myriad of bonuses. It's presented as this beacon of hope for your heroes lore-wise. However, you do not have to keep this torch lit. If you let it go out, the fights get harder, which put your heroes in danger, but you also get significantly more rewards for doing so. 

There is so much that this game has to offer, and I am honestly shocked that I had not heard of it before I bought it myself. I genuinely have not been challenged by a game this much since the first time I played Dark Souls. I love this game with all my heart. If there is anyone out there that is unsure if this game will be worth the money, let me assure you beyond a shadow of a doubt that it is.

[h1]BEST GAME I HAVE EVER PLAYED[/h1]

My [b]first purchase[/b], and still [b]the best game I’ve ever played[/b]. Argue all you want ——  your rebuttal won’t be accepted.

Darkest Dungeon delivers a [b]brutal[/b], [b]unforgettable experience[/b] that punishes every mistake but rewards every victory with pure satisfaction. The [b]stress system[/b], the [b]atmosphere[/b], and the [b]constant tension[/b] make every run feel meaningful. Its art style, narration, and music create a world that’s oppressive, haunting, and strangely beautiful. If you are looking for a [u]turn-based combat[/u] game, this is definitely [b]the best choice[/b] for you.

It’s [b]harsh[/b], it’s [b]punishing[/b], it [b]refuses to hold your hand[/b], it's [b]Darkest Dungeon[/b]. That’s exactly why I love it.
love it, plays well and takes a while to get used to but there's so much depth despite being a 2d sidescroller.

I like this game concept-wise and mechanic-wise.

However, I find a few problems with it in general. I played the game in Stygian the hardest difficulty.

I get that the point of this game and Stygian is to be the hardest possible it could be, but even the hardest difficulty must be fair. For example, I finished Metro Exodus Best Ending with Ranger Hardcore difficulty and it's a pretty balanced difficulty for me, since the enemies are greater in intelligence, but they still have the same limitations of the player.

On the other hand, Darkest Dungeon Stygian Difficulty just lazily buffed the enemies HP, buffed the enemies attack, and add 1 new simple feature which is death limits. No shame to the developer, but for a game that glazed itself to be the "darkest", it could at least try to be more creative in making the enemies harder instead of just increasing the enemies stats with no thoughts behind it.

I was hoping for a more mental gymnastic game like Metro Exodus Ranger Hardcore, not just this silly RNG stuff.

Before any of you accuse me of not using any tactics, I used up every single tactics I could develop from what the game teaches you:
1) I made sure my light levels at the highest level possible in every single battle.
2) I made sure my team composition is as balanced and using their full personal preference as possible. Even if the team I got were fully RNG.
3) I made sure all the items I bring for my adventure is sufficient and befit every single situation as if I'm Goblin Slayer. Even having trinkets based on my team composition.
4) I made sure all my actions in battle are calculated.

After using all of that, I've used up all of the skills I could find as a beginner of Darkest Dungeon, but an experienced player at challenging game in general. Yet, it's not enough and still comes down to pure luck.

Even Fear & Hunger at least have the common sense of rewarding the players for having in-game knowledge of what to do. Maybe this game is just not for me, or maybe some of the negative steam reviews are right.

Although, I can see why people would love this game.
If you are one of those people who love this game, congratulations, you found the right game for you.

If you are one of those people who don't like this game for certain reasons, that's fine, you could choose whether you want to complain about the game or not, but don't linger too long, and just move on to find something else for you.

Personally, I left this negative review, because I spent money to purchase this game, and I was left disappointed.

If you ask why I don't just check reviews and playthrough of this game instead of going in blind. It's because I love uncovering the game inside and out without any public opinions to deter my own judgement. After all, the best thing in life for me is seeing something for the first time, to feel and experience it for myself. For examples, Metro Exodus and Don't Escape: 4 Days to Survive pleasantly surprised me. However, it seems my luck had ran out with this game, which is pretty poetic considering that my main problem with this game is that it's luck-heavy.

Anyhow, I hope whoever is reading this has a good day, and I'm sorry for leaving this negative review.

I definitely have a bit of a love hate relationship with this game.  First off, the classes and combat are really well designed. I'm not a big Lovecraft fan, but the themes are extremely well done and fit the game amazingly well. The game studio's name "Red Hook" is actually a Lovecraft reference itself, so you know these guys are really passionate about the material.

The turn-based combat system is great. Character position matters. Abilities can only be used in certain positions making for lots of possible team compositions based on what classes you choose and what positions you put them in.  Positioning also creates a lot of frustrations though, since several enemies will move your characters around and surprise mechanics may completely shuffle your team out of order at the start of combat.  An S tier team comp when in an exact order can easily become an F tier team when shuffled at the start of combat, causing you to lose a few early turns to fix your order or continue with it sub-optimally.  It's important to consider that and have some flexibility in your team for when you inevitably get moved or shuffled around.

The game really punishes you for lack of game knowledge, which is why the game is most difficult at the start and when playing blind without guides.  All the bosses have a mechanic that you need to understand and build your team around.  Not being prepared for it will often cause things to go south pretty quickly.  Earlier difficulties are a little more forgiving though, so it's up to you to quickly formulate ideas for an optimal strategy and remember to bring a good set-up when you take on the more difficult variations of those bosses later.  

My biggest gripe with the game is just that there is a lot of repetition.  You'll enter the same dungeons, fight the same kinds of monsters, fight increasingly difficult variations of bosses and then eventually take on the darkest dungeon.  Your characters and teams will die as you learn through a bit of trial and error to develop your game knowledge.  That's all fine, but having to re-level characters again, going through the same minimally randomized dungeons, just starts to feel like too much of a grind after a while, and not always particularly fun.

With all that being said, I still enjoyed the game overall.  If you like difficult turn-based games, then it's definitely worth playing through a run.
this game made me who i am today. i could not recommend a game more than this one. all hail darkest dungeon and all hail redhook studios

After about 7 hours of playtime, I can say this game was definitely not a wasted purchase.
The art style is both grim and beautiful, and while the game can be pretty tough at times, that’s honestly part of what makes it so great. Once you start figuring things out, every little victory feels super rewarding.

The dungeons really test your planning skills - building a solid team takes some thought, since each class has its own strengths, weaknesses, and quirks. It can be brutal, but it’s also very satisfying when your strategy pays off.

There are also a bunch of cool mods on the Workshop, though it’s worth checking if they’re still up to date. Some are a bit outdated (probably because of Darkest Dungeon 2, but there’s still plenty of great stuff out there.

Overall: Definitely worth playing and easy to recommend. If you’ve got a few bucks to spare and enjoy a challenge, give it a shot - you won’t regret it.

i've never been more on the fence to recommend a game or not get a game. this game has one of the  coolest aesthetic and concept among games i've played but its heavily ruined by how much of a slot machine the game is. if you get the game go in knowing the game is about 80% up to luck. some runs youll go into and the enemies will target 1 of your guys exclusively and kill them by the 2nd room some encounters the boss will hit your entire team stunning every member and then do the same again and again doing like 80 damage divided roughly 4 ways before you get anything close to a turn. debuffs in this game range from doesnt matter to you have a complete waste of space in your party. example i get hit with a vomit attack on combat 1 of a dungeon the hero fails the slot machine roll and gets a disease this disease gives them -20 dodge (basically the enemy never misses them) and -10% max. other disease effects like -20% damage and anything that reduces move/stun resist makes the hero borderline useless . this isnt exclusive to diseases. traits range from useful to useless and nonrelevant to completely neutering the hero. anything that affects damage, movement resist, stun resist, speed etc. makes most characters useless. the 3 difficulties are basically the 3 levels of unfair the game is. how rigged against you do you want your run to be? radiant difficulty? ok the enemies will only hit 85% of the time, stun you 75% of the time, bleed/blight you 75% of the time, and will only get 2 turns per your 1 turn. its just a shame that the game is so up to luck when it could be based around tactics

Edit: I originally said this game wasn't worth buying, due to the explanation I explained below. I thought about and I realized that it was a game I got on sale for like 3$. Even if I think the game design suffers a large fundamental flaw, I do like the game and enjoyed it. I just think its not the game for me. I like punishing games, but not when it all come down luck determining if you do well and skill is so limited that one turn can ruin everything. So I guess 5/10. Like the idea and enjoyed playing it, but don't think I want to keep playing it anymore, considering it would take forever to get back to where I was and can loose it all regardless of what I do.

Game is really fun, and I have enjoyed a good bit for the very cheap price I got it. I am having to leave a bad review over its game structure. I understand if a game needs to be punishing for a challenge but it just gets so ridiculous at the later game that its annoying. First you get to level up your characters to prepare for future challenges, with lvl 6 being the highest difficulty and lvl for characters. Once you lvl a hero beyond lvl 2 and 4, you lock them out of the easier difficulties. So I had lvl 6 characters pile up while trying to complete the medium difficulty missions and it just turned into a grind. You get new people that can rarely start at lvl 3, but normally 0-2, then run easy missions that are kinda boring  once you've done them a lot until they have a chance at the side quest, often needing to cycle missions to reduce stress. Then you run the side quest, have an easy prelude then just the maximum bs against the boss. I used an event to bring my lvl 6 dream team against one of these, and I don't know how I was supposed to do it otherwise, it was one of those where a crit saved my party, despite feeling like I played it well. It was the hag and one of her few moves is incapacitate a hero and steal its life, every single time anyone takes a turn. I freed my heroes and pounded the hag, but she got everyone to half health then chained crits on two heroes. I decided to attack instead of heal and I got really lucky. The real issue I think is the high difficulties at 5&6. A lot of the early game bosses, just turn into common enemies. Lvl 6 heroes can handle them, but the sheer volume is insane. I admit I'm writing this review after loosing my dream team in an instant, but I think its inevitable no matter the situation, which is where I think punishing you goes too far, and it frustrating for a game where you need to commit so much to each hero. Like in dark souls, if you play well, you don't get punished, and I think that is where game developers miss often in good difficult games.

I should have known that mission was doomed when I thought I'm safe unless a necromancer spawns and that happened right after I left the room I was in. I patched everyone up and had to deal with several more of the like, especially this sailor that deals massive stress damage and is tough and can be guarded by tanks. I had a full health squad with higher stress than I liked but I was pass halfway through the mission. One turn later, my lvl 6 healer was dead from every enemy attacking her sequentially. I retreated, to escape and used my last bonfire. The healer had the thing to prevents ambushes so I risked it. My plague doctor gets a heart attack cause he's sad at the bonfire and an ambush starts, another previous mini boss. I somehow escape that, then one by one everyone in my party dies of heart attacks. There isn't any good way to deal with stress, all you can do is have a character or two always spam low impact stress reduction actions instead of fighting and starting with 0 stress and bonfires, which I did. It was a lvl 5 mission, where most my heroes that have died passed similarly with no modifiers to make it harder. 

A lot of this is just I'm upset, but if I can loose everything in one turn, with deathblow protection and decent strategy, it turns into a game of intense extended rng. I'm not really building my characters, just giving them better rolls and hoping the enemies don't gang crit my entire team every single turn
It hurts so good. I'm so stressed but when a run goes clean it feels amazing

This game is very fun. I love the challenge that it brings as you progress further along into the story even though sometimes you can get really unlucky and lose some of your favorite heroes, but that's what makes the game so good. The game does a great job at creating a sense of peril when you get into a tough fight, sometimes you are forced to abandon a quest because of fights not going your way, or running into a boss fight unexpectedly at a bad time like the collector, thing from the stars, etc. The best thing this game does is force you to make tough decisions, these decisions aren't just limited to the combat either. You have to make all kinds of decisions about whether you want to spend gold on your heroes by upgrading them or curing them of illness or getting rid of annoying quirks or whether you just want to dismiss them altogether to save yourself the hassle. You also get to decide what kind of build you want to have on your heroes and what kinds of comps you want to take into the differing dungeons. This game does a great job of providing a problem and giving you tons of ways to solve it and that freedom to choose is what makes the game so interesting and creates a great gameplay loop. I have over 200 hours in this game and I still haven't tried every build and every class in the game yet, I still haven't tried using certain trinkets and haven't finished the DLCs but I always get super into this game for awhile and then stop playing for a year or so but I always come back. The best part about this game is that when it goes on sale it is 10000000% worth the price because it's super cheap for one, but you also get a ridiculous amount of value for the amount of fun you have. Just a warning ahead of time for new players, you WILL get to a point in the game where RNG just goes the worst way possible for you. You will run into bosses at the worst possible time, you will get hit with multiple crits and lose a hero before you can heal them, you'll forget to change a skill out or forget to bring certain supplies, etc. The key to this game is patience and not getting too upset about things not going your way. That being said, enjoy the times where everything is going right an capitalize on it. Definitely get this game if you have the money and are looking for something new to play, I would recommend waiting for a sale, totally worth I promise.

Every expedition feels like gambling with your sanity — your heroes can go from brave crusaders to broken wrecks in a few torchless turns. And that’s the beauty of it. Victory in Darkest Dungeon doesn’t come from brute force; it comes from managing stress, trauma, and the slow corrosion of hope.

The voice acting? Absolute perfection. The lines — “Remind yourself that overconfidence is a slow and insidious killer” — stick in your head like scripture from a deranged priest. The combat is brutal, strategic, and deeply satisfying when you claw out a win.

It’s grim, it’s punishing, it’s unfair at times — but that’s exactly what makes it brilliant. Darkest Dungeon rewards patience, planning, and a taste for suffering.

Oh boy. Were do I start with this game?

Behind the gothic tattered curtain, the game is really a constant series of RNG and knowledge checks, followed by town micro management. Now, I know that sounds kinda annoying, but actually playing the game for awhile it's a lot more bearable then it sounds. 

That being said though. This game, objectively will filter people out. Especially towards mid-game.

Know this game is unforgiving by design. The game's bleak, Dark Fantasy, and Lovecraftian inspired world will constantly remind you that eventually; things WILL go wrong. 

That is to say, this game can be beaten. All of it's RNG can be pre-planned and can be worked around even when things are actively going wrong. Just give some patience and plan out what can or can not go wrong. 

Ending with a bit of advice for a healthy mindset when taking a loss for both newbies and veterans. 

Take it for what it is. Take a break. Plan accordingly for next time. Trust when I say, it's fine to take a loss or two. Again, it's by design.

[h1] 8/10 - A Frustrating but Rewarding Dungeon Crawler [/h1]
Let me preface by saying that I adore the game's environment, artstyle, music & story. These things, combined with the sublime narration by Wayne June, really helps sell the premise of this game; Facing insurmountable odds, and dealing with the stress of it all. This game can be really frustrating; Permanent Hero Deaths, Random Crits, Quirks/Stress causing unforseen events. There's a lot of stuff that just keeps getting thrown against you over and over again. As such the game really rewards preparation and flexibility, as you'll need to plan well for the trials ahead, but also be able to adapt when things inevitably go wrong. While I enjoy this experience, I think the game as a whole stretches on for just a bit too long, which means that you start mixing in tedium with the frustrating moments, and it can make the lategame feel really painful. Despite that, I think it's worth a shot - You'll know whether or not its worth finishing the whole thing depending on how you feel after a few dungeons.
This game is reasonably fun, even if you never actually put in the necessary effort to beat the final boss.

Gorgeous artwork, fun and unique character concepts and unique, challenging combat mechanics make this a very fun roguelike to spend time with and really dig into. It rewards you the more you learn. It's very punishing, but that's what makes the rewards actually feel worth it. Victories have weight to them, especially if you've lost a hero you loved. The sheer variety in character classes make it easy to pick the game up and play a different strategy every time. There's something for everyone who enjoys this genre in here, I find. It's definitely one of the funnest games I've played in a long time. Also, the soundtrack is absolutely fantastic, it fits the mood and atmsophere of the environments perfectly. The narrator has the most talented voice actor I've heard in quite a while. His unique inflection and interesting role as a character which narrates battles and navigation through the dungeons, but does not participate, makes him a fascinating and fun addition. There is also a ton of enemy variety as well, to keep things fresh. All in all, I highly recommend to anyone who has a bit of time to put into learning how this one ticks.

Forget your standard power fantasy; Darkest Dungeon masterfully turns the tables, making survival the true victory. The game's oppressive atmosphere, stunning hand-drawn gothic art, and the relentless pressure of the Stress mechanic create a uniquely captivating experience. Each delve into the unknown is a thrilling, tactical nightmare, where carefully planned assaults can crumble into tragic chaos with a single ill-timed affliction. Recruiting and investing in a roster of flawed, compelling characters—only to watch their resolve snap—is a strange, beautiful form of agony. It’s a roguelike that demands respect, rewards meticulous preparation, and proves that the greatest horror is often the one that resides within your own mind. Truly a triumph of design, this game is a must-play for anyone seeking a turn-based RPG with real, psychological weight.

Darkest Dungeon is an addictive yet brutally hard game. Its dark atmosphere, strategic combat, and stress system make every decision feel intense and meaningful. Victories are satisfying, but failure is constant — reaching the end is a real challenge. A great game, but not for the faint of heart.

Darkest Dungeon is, without a doubt, one of the best games I have ever played. I’ve spent over 100 hours in it so far — and I still haven’t finished! That alone says a lot about how deep, challenging, and rewarding this game is.

What makes Darkest Dungeon truly stand out is its unique approach to stress and mental strain. Making stress an actual game mechanic was a brilliant idea — it adds so much realism and emotional depth. You don’t just manage health bars; you manage the sanity and morale of your heroes. Every expedition feels like a psychological battle as much as a physical one.

The heroes themselves are fantastic — each class feels distinct and full of personality, with different abilities, strengths, and flaws that make team composition a thoughtful, strategic puzzle. The enemies are equally well-designed, both in visuals and in behavior, always keeping you on your toes.

And I absolutely have to mention the game’s non-stop commentary — it’s perfectly executed. The narrator’s voice and lines add so much atmosphere and weight to everything you do. I genuinely enjoy every single comment; it makes every action feel significant and meaningful.

The levels and missions are varied and atmospheric, perfectly complemented by the game’s dark, gothic art style and haunting narration. Every small victory feels earned, and every defeat hits hard — but that’s what makes Darkest Dungeon so special.

It’s a brutal, beautiful experience — a masterpiece of strategy, atmosphere, and emotion. I absolutely love it.

Darkest Dungeon is a very solid game.

The premise is quite unique; essentially, you're leading a party of heroes that are very much human. Thus, they are simultaneously imperfect yet capable of exceeding expectations. The Ancestor's commentary & stress systems add so much flavor here!

The introductory text is apt: this game is about making the best of a bad situation. Much of this comes in the form of your combat decision-making, which relies greatly on RNG. It makes use of damage ranges, dodge, accuracy, and so on. This aspect of the game is manageable, but certainly can be frustrating to new players or just certain enemies / across the game in general. 

I would also say that some mechanics do not feel great, such as the fact heroes refuse to return to the Darkest Dungeon. They do stop taking slots in your roster, however; so they aren't a detriment, but it did draw the game out. While mechanics such as these can be tedious, they are very thematic.

Ultimately, that is what I feel it comes down to. This game is incredibly thematic, with a focus on unique core systems. This game reinforces that you are not mind-controlling your heroes; you are commanding them. 

I love it. It isn't perfect, and probably isn't for everyone, but it's a game that has me so engrossed for every session. 

Absolutely worth a try.

Darkest Dungeon is a masterclass in mood, mechanics, and madness. It’s not just a dungeon crawler — it’s a psychological descent into despair, where every choice carries weight, and every victory feels earned.

The art style is grim and unforgettable. The narrator? Iconic. The stress system adds a whole new layer of tension, forcing you to manage not just health, but sanity — of both your heroes and yourself.

It’s punishing, brutal, and completely addictive. Failure isn’t just possible — it’s inevitable. But when you claw your way to survival against all odds, there’s nothing more satisfying.

If you crave challenge, love Lovecraftian horror, and aren’t afraid to lose a few minds (or limbs) along the way — Darkest Dungeon is a must-play.

A unique twist on turn-based RPGs. The game cuts down on story telling aspects (even though it does have a Lovecraftian atmosphere) and emphasizes more on tactics and preparedness for each dungeon you explore. The dungeons are unique with each type having its own dangers. Characters each have their own abilities, and the game encourages using different characters for each type of dungeon. So far so good!

I've had this game for like a decade. Jumping on and off, quitting runs as the frustrations got to me or I overwhelmed myself piling up mods.

Even if you find yourself losing your finest adventurers and at 0 gold. You can still recover with fresh meat sent to the slaughter or pawing off trinkets you never used anyways. Unless you play on highest difficulty, there's no real way to lose.

Darkest Dungeon is a game that has not been succesfully replicated yet. For anyone who enjoys expendable troops with names you grow attached to seeing them grow, with all their moments of glory and faults, such like XCOM, this is a great purchase and be bought dirt cheap nowadays.

Where do I start with this one?
Right to the point, this game is best enjoyed on PC with Modding Support.
The only DLCs that you should have are: 'The Crimson Court' and 'The Color of Madness'

For anyone who is curious or likes the concept about 'Dungeon Crawling / Exploration' this is your game.
The Modding Support gives this game a lot of flexibility than the other versions from other platforms doesn't have.

Up to this date Modders continue to support the game with new content, just make sure to use don't use a Mod that affects the same 'gameplay' element twice.
Just to try the mod compatibility, I had to create 2 game 'Estates' (Game Files) before I started playing for real.
My advice is to 'Subscribe' to the Mods you want to play them and don't and more mods once you check out if they are compatible (Don't crash out your 'save file' once you 'activate' them in 'Estate' selection).

You can take on multiple areas in any order but keep in mind the 'Stress' each party memeber suffers while they are on an expedition.
A good idea is to have at least 2 different teams of 4 people and arrange them in a formation similar to this one:
Healer      ->   Ranged DPS   ->     Melee DPS   ->   Tank
4 Position  ->   3 Position   ->     2 Position  ->   1 Position

Mods with 'Custom Class' can give you some aditional choices, the only one that I think every one should have is: 'Skadi the corrupting heart' and 'Mordekaiser Class'
Other mods that gives the exploration a nice twist are: 'Crystar_music_replace', 'Mimic Miniboss' and 'It Followed You Home: Otekh' 
Some QoL (Quality of Life) mods are: '8 Trinkets + 24 Inventory', 'Level Restrictions Removal', 'Immersive Area Backgrounds', 'Infinite Gold & Heirlooms', 'Faster Scouting', 'Better Trinkets', 'Cure Crimson Curse', 'Affliction Chance: Virtuous' and 'Eliminate Catching Diseases', 

The are some mods that add new areas to the map, the ones I tried and know they are compatible: 'The Sunward Isles (New Dungeon)' and 'The Mountain - Updated Version'
The DLC that I enjoyed the most was 'The Crimson Court', it long dungeon format is quite the twist from the set in stone map layouts from base game.
'The Color of Madness' add more powerful items and many 'Custom Class' mods are made to work with it, plus you get a chasser boss on normal dungeons.  

This one is one of the best games I had played recently, strongly recomended it now that the modds gave it a more accesible and forgiving gameplay.

I kind of hated this game for the first 6-8 hours, but after that I started to really like it.

The art style and general aesthetics are very appealing. I like the dark tone, and the modding community is very active — there are so many custom classes that you could make a whole new game out of it! The same could be said to some extent for the enemies. 

I really like this game — it's top quality. There is nothing I seriously dislike about it. The combat is decently challenging and requires you to utilise your tools properly. The game provides a basic explanation of how things work, but doesn't hold your hand too much. It respects your intelligence and is designed in such a way that it leaves enough room for you to figure things out on your own. The bosses are fun, even if a few have rather annoying mechanics. This is especially the case for the Crimson Court DLC. If you've never played it before, give it a shot — the game is dirt cheap when it's on sale, and even at full price, you're getting a lot of game.

The different variables also provide a fresh experience every time you head into a dungeon. No two runs of this game from start to finish will be the same. If you love dungeon crawlers with good aesthetics, an iconic background announcer and Lovecraftian horror elements, this is the game for you. Give it a try!

It also wouldn't hurt if you've ever enjoyed a roguelike game before.

Let ruin come to you.

From the second you open this game you are forewarned that not every scenario is winnable, and tactical retreats, and cut losses are to be part of your campaign against the raging darkness. At first you might think "sure whatever..." And then you wander into your first real dungeon run, and a skulking horror oneshots a vital party member. Directly after, another party member suffers a complete mental breakdown and takes down another team member with them, and then you are faced with the harsh reality... Overconfidence is a slow and insidious killer.

You think you learn your lesson, and begin to muster an army, you find resolute heroes capable of war with the dark forces. Several champions emerge with varying skills for both combat and survival, and having carefully planned and weighed the risk, you wager an assault onto a boss. During which your favorite champion goes out in a blaze of glory allowing your other 3 heroes a desperate escape. A success such as it is.

Darkest Dungeon does its work both on and off the screen. It is a game both played on the cosmic stage and in the darkest corners of the players mind. As successes mount, emotion becomes tied to emerging heroes that are forced into more-and-more difficult scenarios as their individual resolve and quirks mount. You will watch as they fall  (an excruciating experience) in places where there is no ability to react. Some complete failures, you'll want to walk away, you may even uninstall (I have several times).

But then you think... But then these heroes (with no individual stories, who have naught but a name) have all died in vain. So you start again. Your stress becoming their stress, a dizzying rush of pride when you do summit a particularly difficult encounter.

In time you will see your failings in the graveyard, offset by a reborn hamlet surrounded by more willing heroes ready to brave the Darkest Dungeon. When it is your time, you will be ready.

An insanely masochistic game, wherein both luck and strategy are required to win. I honestly love it to death, but there are definitely flaws with the mechanics -- though I understand why they are included. Something like not being able to heal nor stress heal your party in-between rooms. There'd be no challenge or threat if you could do that. Same reason why stress heals don't match the level of stress you take, otherwise stress wouldn't be a very threatening mechanic. But, I wish you could see turn order. 

The amount of party compositions you can make are borderline insane and almost all of them are viable -- even if it's just the same hero 4 times over. I couldn't recommend this game enough if you want a more hardcore turn-based strategy game with threatening mechanics and an insane atmosphere.

I initially tried out the game 6 years ago and gave up from frustration due to its unfairness difficulty. I recently decided to replay it, and given its formula and inspiring storytelling, horror-fiction RPG that this game is, I wanted to persevere through the game. This game's formula is a more unique take on the dungeon crawler types, with a team formation and combos that lead to creative ways to bring characters to each missions. Despite its repetitiveness, there are many creative opportunities to derive from this game as you play. Most importantly, EVERYONE will be frustrated from playing this, because when you lose heroes, you lose them permanently, which is the challenge factor of such a harsh game. IF you look for a very challenging RPG that will test your patience and stress, then I recommend this game for a shot. I also praise its sound effect design choices a lot, and the creative artwork despite its simplicity.

The dungeon is unforgiving, as it won't hesitate to wipe out over 6 hours of your progress with a single bad decision or poor planning. It can be so unpredictable that you can save a dying member of your party at the very brink of death, only to miss all your attacks against a single enemy. It’s fun and far more challenging than most turn-based games I’ve played (even on ‘easy’ difficulty), and it definitely has the RNG and replayability of a typical rogue-like game. The art style and atmosphere are as grim and disturbing as any Lovecraftian/Eldritch title can get, accompanied by the mysteries of the story that pushes you further into your quest.

Overall, it’s truly one of the most memorable and addictive games I’ve played, and I genuinely recommend it to anyone who enjoys a challenging rogue-like or turn-based RPG. 10/10 without a doubt."

The game isn't kidding with it's whole "Overconfidence is a slow and insidious killer," quote, since a single enemy crit is enough to make me immediately sit right back up and lock in for what I was thinking was a mindless expedition. With a lot of RNG-heavy RPGs, it's necessary to build around minimizing the detrimental effects of RNG; preparation's everything, and Darkest Dungeon makes no exception, ESPECIALLY with permadeath (and I've already had quite a few die despite not being that far in). Darkest Dungeon's going to toss diseases at your heroes, make them weirdly obsessed with corpses and thus making them get even MORE diseased and blighted, and will constantly stress them out to the point of one stressed hero snowballing into all four being stressed out. Despite all this, you can tip the balances in your favor just as much. Your heroes [i]will[/i] be thrown through the wringer as you learn this game, but this can still be mitigated through knowledge and preparation. I love this aspect of the game, but it's understandably not for everyone (neither does it make someone a "bad" player if they simply don't want to deal with this kind of challenge. Every game has its own varying challenges, after all, this is just Darkest Dungeon's).

Some people also say to "not get too attached to your heroes", but I suggest you to do the opposite. Darkest Dungeon has managed to get me attached to my heroes in the most hype ways possible. In Week 7, before I started really understanding how the game works, I was about ready to just toss my heroes into expeditions for the sole purpose of getting as much money and materials as I could and backing out before my party wipes. I went into an expedition with a Houndmaster, Abomination, Jester, and a Man-at-Arms, none of which I particularly cared about. I managed to get my party to the very last fight of the expedition with my HM and MAA both at low health, while everyone but my ABOM being Afflicted (for reference, I didn't understand how necessary Stress Heals were). Both my MAA and HM died to Carrion Eaters, and when it was finally time for my ABOM's resolve to be tested, he became Virtuous for the first time and won the fight alongside the JES. I'm now determined to bring my ABOM to the Darkest Dungeon, or at least as far as I can towards it (I had to make the tough decision to dismiss my JES due to him having WAY too many negative quirks for me to salvage him. I feel bad, but I'll remember him all the same).

This is honestly a really enjoyable Dungeon Crawler type game.

One of the best parts about this game is how you have to manage the characters fear, health, and other conditions as you also complete the task you've sent them to do. 

The combat is very intuitive, and while simple, it is enjoyable.

The gameplay with its turn-based combat and base management sort of reminds me a bit of my dream job XCOM, but slightly less tactical and with a macabre vibe instead of a militant one. But since it does remind me so much of that, makes sense I would be cleaving through like a dog devouring cooked beef! 

(Of course I am admittedly going on easy difficulty, but offset with the self-imposed challenge of seeing how far I can go without a single one of my guys dying - typical Hero Team doctrine.)

One word of caution: the game is HARSH, and that is by design! Even on easy, I had a couple of absolute close calls, like surviving a hit at Death's Doorstep close call, through sheer luck pulling through. And the nastiest part is, the game FORCES a "hardcore ironman" experience, so no cushy save/load time machine. I get it, and I appreciate how that ruthless game design compliments the sense of dread the entire aesthetic and story is going for, yet after a while, the process is just thorny. Stops being fun after the first few boss fights who make it their mission to disrupt your party and all too easily destroy them unless you've over-leveled, excessively prepared, just plain lucky, AND an experienced Commander of XCOM. Then, after that, the game's like, "How about we make you do the same gimmicks THREE TIMES?" Like, dude, just once is enough, thank you very much. So, safe to say I won't be finishing the purging of evil here, not because I can't but because it stopped being fun about 1/3 of the way in (or 1/4 if you count the final, namesake "Darkest Dungeon").

Don't get too attached to your characters! This game is a good experience of resource management and risk/reward. I loved the atmosphere and recommend as an easy to play game mechanically, but difficult otherwise!

It's a very unique game that's very challenging. It's great fun. After 36 hours I'm able to make a few months (in game time) with out everyone just getting annihilated and dying of heart attacks. 

Managing and upgrading hero's and buildings (which allow for recruiting new heros, upgrades of weapons/armor and skills, as well managing stress, illnesses and afflictions) is both challenging and rewarding.

Plenty of turn based combat until you can't take it anymore. 

All the different kinds of heroes (with the expansions) give a randomness to the hero selection that forces you to pick parties with different heroes, which forces you to really explore the game fully. If you like heroes A B C and D, well A is on a bender and didn't show up, B is too stressed from last time because you didn't have enough gold to help them, C is too high level now, and you have D. And now next round D will likely have to recover, so do you even use D? There's a lot of strategy just in the heroes you pick.

It's a great combination of being simple in concept, while deep on content, and challenging in the type of way where you have to learn and be really thoughtful about your decisions and tactics or you'll just get wiped out, and I mean literally wiped after possibly tens of hours put into it.

Love it.

I love dungeon crawlers and this particular one scratches an itch that is hard to reach for me. I tend to favor rougelike/hack and slash dungeon crawlers over turned based ones, but I feel Darkest Dungeon is just as engaging. I feel that the difficulty of the game at the beginning and the challenges you continue to face is what keeps me coming back to this game. Figuring out team compositions that optimized each hero was such a good puzzle to solve, especially when your work builds up over time and you are able to defeat more powerful enemies. 

I enjoy the numerous amounts of skills and status effects that each of the hero's have. Every single hero can be used in a way that can make them useful in a variety of situations (even if you don't see that use at first). I also like the enemies and bosses, as they simultaneously are fun to defeat and occasionally scare the shit out of me because they nearly TPK my runs hahaha. This game will certainly get your heart rate up.

This is more than just a mere computer game. It is a challenge, a complicated task to overcome, and not only on your screen, but in your mind and heart as well. Darkest Dungeon despite being quite random based and highly stress filled game is a true masterpiece of turn-based combat.

The music and atmosphere is a whole another level of game development, and quite exquisite system of different mechanics, sometimes logical, sometimes not. The enemies, the hamlet, the heroes, I could say a lot about them, but keeping it short... This game definitely is worth a try. 100% Darkest Dungeon is not for everybody, less than 10% of players have actually beaten it, but it is more than dozens of hours slaying monsters and planning expeditions, it is a bunch of lessons that you need to learn about how tough life can be sometimes, and that frequently (but not always) it is not afectable by you or your actions, sometimes life just hits with a random 60 hp crit, and you fail your first death door check. 

There are some bugs and a little lack of variety in the quests, but it doesn't make the game less outstanding comparing to the others, it makes it...unique.

When I first bought this game, I was in the middle of my introduction to roguelites and the challenge that often comes with them. My initial expectations were more on par with an easier Darkest Dungeon 2, so naturally this game was quite a shock. I dropped it after a grueling 30-40 hour first campaign where my progress felt stalled.

This game is neither a roguelike nor a roguelite. Not only is the intra-run progress made up of key mechanics, this game will punish you if you don't intimately learn and harmonize them with your strategy. At its core, I would call this a dungeon crawler: an RPG-lite dungeon crawling strategy with turn-based combat.

I came back for my second campaign many years later and have been approaching gaming with a different mindset. Like we all do, I want to get through my backlog. But the goal is no longer to get through it; it's to enjoy the games while I naturally make progress. This mentality is what led me to ranking Darkest Dungeon amongst my favorite games ever and beating the campaign & Crimson Curse after another 80-90 hour campaign, with some help from ShuffleFM along the way. If completion / end game is the goal, know that this game is an absolute marathon. One more run can turn into yet another long night, and will, but the payoff from beating bosses, checking off Caretaker goals, and eventually clearing DD raids is on par with that of From Software bosses. Party management, that first seems like a chore, is the strategic backbone of a successful campaign. RnG will be your best friend and your worst enemy until you learn to effectively use trinkets and efficiently spend your money.


My only 2 suggestions: 
1. Enable the fast walking and any other fast mods that stick out to you, or you'll be around for longer than I was.
2. Buy this game.

The dungeoning is a lot of fun and definitely the best part of the game, but it definitely falls short in other aspects - the feeling of progression is not very good because of level gating, grinding anything is a huge pain. The combat and dungeoning do offset this, but it's still there.

The game is also definitely repetitive, there is only so many different builds and strategies you can try before running into the same 8-9 enemy types gets boring. The difficulty, in my opinion, is not the main reason only around 4.5% of players finish the game.

Still, if you can get it on a discount, it's fun to play for quite a few hours, just don't focus too much on trying to actually finish the game.

That being said, I don't recommend the DLCs - Crimson Court introduces mechanics which make the base game worse and the content it brings is just worse version of the base dungeons and Color of Madness is straight up busted and has a bug that makes it pretty much impossible to gather the new resource it introduces.

The game shines in its class variety and synergy. You can build teams around DOTs, stuns, stress heals, raw damage, or utility. Different comps work better in different areas, and experimenting is a big part of the fun (and pain).

The RNG is harsh but mostly fair. Misses and crits can make or break a run, but smart planning, positioning, and skill choices reduce the randomness. It rewards adaptation and punishes tunnel vision.

Not only that, there’s trinkets that aren’t just stat boosts - they shape your strategy. Some are high risk/high reward. Others specialise what your heroes can do. Managing the collection is almost a game in itself.

I grew up loving Lovecraft-type stories and the dread in this game absolutely tickles that love. The narration is iconic and the minimalistic storytelling leaves a heavy impression. The world feels oppressive, decayed and cursed - and that’s the point.

Gold, heirlooms, stress, food, torches - everything matters. The game constantly forces tough choices. Do you upgrade your Stage Coach or your Blacksmith? Do you push a bleeding hero one more room, or retreat and lose progress?

If you enjoy tough, strategic RPGs with meaningful consequences and a haunting art style, Darkest Dungeon is a must-play. Just don’t get too attached to your favourites - they’re already dead.

Darkest Dungeon is a deeply rewarding, punishingly challenging tactical RPG that rewards smart decision-making and adaptability. The variety of team compositions and class synergies offers endless experimentation, making every run feel unique.

Darkest Dungeon by Red Hook Studios is a punishing, atmospheric roguelike RPG that challenges players to manage a team of flawed heroes as they delve into cursed dungeons filled with madness, monsters, and misery. Set in a crumbling estate plagued by dark forces, the game tasks you with cleansing various regions while keeping your adventurers alive - physically and mentally.

The game's standout feature is its stress system. Characters don't just take damage - they suffer from fear, hopelessness, and irrational behaviour brought on by prolonged exposure to terror. Heroes can develop quirks and afflictions, lash out at teammates, or even die from a heart attack under extreme stress. This psychological element makes each decision weighty, adding tension to every turn and making success feel genuinely earned.

Combat is turn-based and tactical, demanding smart team composition, positioning, and resource management. The odds are often against you, and failure is frequent—but that's part of the experience. Losing a veteran hero hurts, but it also reinforces Darkest Dungeon's core theme: victory has a cost.

Visually, the game is stunning, with a gritty, hand-drawn art style that fits perfectly with its grim tone. Wayne June's narration adds a layer of foreboding that enhances the oppressive atmosphere.

While its difficulty and grind may not appeal to everyone, those who embrace its merciless design will find Darkest Dungeon to be a deeply rewarding and unforgettable journey into despair. It's a rare game that makes you feel the weight of every victory and every loss.

Darkest Dungeon is difficult but ultimately fair. Although some things are completely out of your control due to RNG, it gives you the tools you need to mitigate it. Heroes are expendable, and trinkets let you both move first and avoid missing. Similarly, the game rewards you for both cautiousness and game knowledge.

A wonderful mix of a roguelite, turn based RPG-esque combat and base/squad management, presented in a beautiful gothic style and a memorable narrator that dynamically commentates on your progress. 

Quite hard at first and you might feel wronged by the RNG at times, but preparation and knowledge mitigates a lot of the bad luck. Plus, the game does allow you to fall back and regroup at various moments, with little to no downside besides time lost (which is only a real factor for achievements or if you're playing at the highest difficulty).

All in all a must play for whoever enjoys the genre. A big bonus as well is the modding community, which is incredibly active and has made top quality mods, giving Darkest Dungeon even more replayability than it already has!

i'm writing this before i finish the game because i feel like i understand everything the game offers.

this game is REALLY impressive in it's depth. every single character has a situation or role that they excel in, and every ability has a specific use case. its so deep and intricate that its incredible that it comes together so cleanly, not to mention that the mechanics hold up for the entire runtime. the game is SO LONG that it genuinely feels like a long, harrowing adventure where the goal is so much larger than the adventurers themselves. the plot stakes are perfect imo

but the game is just crushing. its one thing to punish the player for mistakes, which the game does. you can come back from that, its a core theme that the people dont matter, they're just meat for the grinder,,, but it just gets to be too much for me near the end. late game areas REQUIRE high level characters- which require hours of successful missions and tons of money to upgrade them- and then you can get totally screwed by RNG crits and misses, no matter how much prep you put in. so the gameplay stakes are high, and it takes a good amount of time to recover, but you can always flee so it doesn't feel unfair... MOST OF THE TIME.

what DOES feel unfair are the huge endgame missions that don't let you retreat without losing a hero. these missions can absolutely destroy you if you dont have the correct trinkets, provisions, or heroes.. but you wont KNOW what a viable setup entails until you go in there, meaning youre almost guaranteed a loss and at least one hero death when you retreat (assuming nobody died in the dungeon).
it feels like a time tax, where you have to waste your time in order to learn how to even TRY the mission. and then you know how to build a comp, but thats just for the ENEMIES, right? then you get to the boss and it requires an additional layer of setup, and if you didn't luck into the right comp, you lose a guy again.

it really is just too much for me, to the point where i either have to spend hours and hours training new guys and farming more gold,, just to throw two teams into the grinder and have to train MORE guys for the final push to victory. at that point, i SHOULD turn to the wiki just to cut down on the time requirements, but that feels bad and defeats the whole experience of the game.

this is basically to say that i understand how you're SUPPOSED to progress through the final missions. but that time requirement is just too much for me personally.

the gameplay is good, scrapping together teams from whatever broken fools are available is fun. but you cant do that on the high level missions, you HAVE to optimize, and then its just a massive time suck- if you like learning and mastering games, its probably for you. but my motivation to do that can only go so far when the game keeps demanding more and more of my time at every turn.

i've beaten nearly every boss. i understand the different characters' strengths and weaknesses. but i don't want to farm for all the required god-tier trinkets and train up two dozen different characters just so i can ATTEMPT the finale missions. the gameplay just isnt engaging enough for me to commit to that, so that's my breaking point. i'll play the game off and on with the steam deck, but its just too much of a time vampire to be a main game for me right now. i want to play other stuff.

and that break MAY destroy my knowledge of the game and any motivation to continue, but i cant do anything about that. the game is just too long and too time consuming for me to try to beat at this point in my life.

recommended because its a good game that just lost me near the very end. maybe play on radiant difficulty if this review felt relatable
