Honestly a masterclass of its form, very few games bring me such innate joy when I think about them. Darkest Dungeon is grueling, unforgivable, punishing, and most of all painful. All of those wrapped into a beautiful turn based combat system with stress and resource management, upgrades, trinkets. It's got a lot that brings to the table and brings it well.

These are things I love about this game.

1. The Stress System: This system can be the make or break of a run, always being at the forefront of your mind much like your party's health bar. You have to manage your stress properly or find your heroes will start to crumble. Easily one of my favorite aspects of the game. It adds a human aspect to the characters and makes them more relatable creating that attachment more and more every run.

2. The Combat: The combat is turn based style but at a unique camera angle, the entire game being from a side scroller perspective. This creates unique visuals which are stylized and very beautiful. However the combat can be incredibly frustrating with seemingly random misses based on a calculation that implies the miss should of never happened. Call it bad luck but the Vestal out here looking like shadowhart from Baldurs Gate, only good at healing. Miss Queen.

3. The Story: I love Lovecraftian horror minus all of the old school racism, the atmosphere in this game is so thick you could cut it with a knife. I'm not going to go too far into the story and how I feel about it because it should realistically be appreciated completely blind.

4. The Narrator: Rest In Peace Wayne June, what an incredible voice and display of beautiful word play. I know he didn't write the lines for his narration but he brings them to life. Even after hearing his lines repeated a hundred times, his voice so gripping and adds a layer of horror to the game. It would be half the experience without him.

It's really unfortunate this game never got a sequel.

Mistakes happen pretty often and they can make the grind more tedious, but the game is built around them and offers some solutions, while you also learn from these losses. Even if luck messes you up, preparation and your knowledge of the game turn it back around. Besides the gameplay, the artstyle and design of the enemies are top-notch. Wayne June did an incredible job as the narrator of the game, all his lines are memorable and perfect for any occasion.
Overall, a really great game that's both challenging and pretty fun.

TLDR Rating: 76/100 

Positives: 
- A solid turn-based game. 
- Classes are quite different in their capability - this creates a lot of play-styles and tactical combinations. 
- It's quite a challenging game. You will probably restart your campaign several times before you can finish one run. I put this as a positive as I would much rather have a difficult game than a walking simulator. 
- Tactical layer does require a lot of experience on high difficulty (e.g. killing/healing phases). 

Neutral: 
- I am not to involved in the storyteller fan-club. But I am not against it either. It creates a decent atmosphere fitting the game. 

Negatives: 
- The game requires ahead knowledge to be played successfully. Unless you know ahead what the bosses can do, there is a very good chance you won't be able to finish the campaign. Having knowledge of the boss mechanics and events PRIOR to embarking is pretty mandatory in my opinion. This creates a situation where you either google the boss and its mechanics (which removes a lot of tactical decision making) or restart a LOT of campaigns.

Sometime ago, I negative reviewed this game hardcore. Shortly after, I decided to give this game one last chance. And well... Even I can admit to being wrong. As hard and unforgiving as this game can be, it did eventually click for me and here I am over 150+ hours in. The modding capabilities alone is what makes this game great! It's a hard game, no doubt about that, but even if you get a party wipe and even if all of your party members freak out over being spilled wine on themselves... Well, remember that RNG gives and it can easily take. If you're looking for a challenging game, look no further than this! If you're like me and want to have fun with making modifications to the game, it's good for that too. And if you decide to download mods to make the game easier, ignore the try hards who give you shit for it. At the end of the day, you play it how you want to play it.

It's good, very good, it'll sink its [red] hooks into you, and drag you in, thrashing and clawing.
However, to play, you need tactical acumen AND a tolerance for some, at times, heavy RNG.

This is the darkest dungeon, a turn based dungeon crawler where you recruit mercenary and do turn by turn combat in a 4vsthe dungeon ,  i don't enjoy turn based combat, however the atmosphere of this game, the narrator voice, and the stress mechanic are so good that i not only managed to look past it but actually enjoyed my time with the game

I tend to roleplay my rpg, i have like character archtype  that basicly cameo in most of the game i play, and the thief lady that throw dagger with white hair fitted perfectly, so while this game kinda promote the insanity of hiring meat shield to dwelve in the dungeon, i kinda did the opposite, i had some meat shield too, but from the begining i had like some main characters that their life mattered at all cost and, atleast For the thief lady (i think she is called graverobber iirc) she survived until the end of the game for me , even in the dlc's and the like

I however have not finished the game, for the same reason described above, fleeing from the last few dungeon have a random chance of permanently killing a character wich obviously mean that im not going in there with the main characters since , i am what you would call unlucky, if i roll a dice it will most likely be under the half score most time, unless its narrativly funny/ rolling high actually is bad for me, i never win a coin toss , so after noticing the scouting party experience in the last dungeon i just kinda lost interest

However i think this game want you to embrace the insanity, i beleive there is like a system that punish you for doing good, and kinda increase your "luck" in the most dire moments, and seeing a few people play it in like an insane type of way with no care for the life of the party, yet like the high and low point would go up and down almost per turn in a single combat while my playthrough had the low and high aspect but i played more conservativly so i was a lot more in control i guess is a kind of word to put it .

Still there has been no game that come close to how i felt playing this, in the Turn based genre and it kinda opened the window for me to try those game more, not sure ill ever play the sequel i liked the dungeon aspect im not sure i like the cart on road aspect and didn't felt like people received it with the same hype as this one is aclaimed.

Darkest dungeon is a game that managed to get me through a rough time in my life (Yes I know its stupid that a game as hard and frustrating as this managed to help me mentally but here I am still standing and writing this review.)

I wanted to get DD2 however.. it was pretty expensive at the time and DD1 was dirt cheap back then. So i decided to get the game and I did not regret it.

I went back after reading the wiki, going with actully strong hero's to kill that fatass. And i did along with butchering Willbur.

Thank you Wayne June for voice acting The Ancestor (Rest in peace)

This is hands down my favourite game, I really love the characters writing and design, the artstyle, gameplay, the use of lovecraftian themes, and most of all the amazing narration done by Wayne June (rest in piece). The opening speech would always send chills down my spine even if it was my 100th time hearing. The Modding for the game is great, people are still making new things 9 years later and it is very easy to start modding if you want to try something new. I 100% get that these kinds of games are not for everyone but this is my JAM. If you love management, Lovecraft, and the crushing force of grounded human pressures like wealth and those who also try to survive this world, alongside unknowable Cosmic, Eldritch, and Flesh-like gods that work at no end to destroy all that you hold dear, then you will love this game.

Darkest Dungeon is an amazing game, a beautiful Gothic dungeon-based RPG where you lead a growing group of adventurers into nightmarish, randomised dungeons again and again to defeat the evil unleashed by your ancestor. The combat is complex, but still approachable, and while the game is absolutely difficult at times, it is never particularly unfair, or cheap in it's challenge. The art, music and voice acting are all incredible, the game is almost bug-free and I enjoyed the first hundred hours I spent on it. HOWEVER, if you're a completionist like myself, please understand that some of the achievements in this game are absolute torture to get, particularly the butcher's circus and colour of madness DLC achievements. This game, for all it's great elements, really does not respect your time. I know there are mods that can speed it up, but I personally didn't use them. Perhaps I should have, either way, get it on sale

Honestly, Darkest Dungeon is awesome. It's a bit of a specialized game; it's not for everyone, but if you like turn-based strategy, dark fantasy (that doesn't go into... GoT topics), emergent narratives, resource and base management, and stylized art making gore and such more palatable, then I highly recommend this game! Despite some people putting out mods that are, shall we say, not to my tastes, the mod community is one of my favorite things about the game. Between skins, custom heroes to send on missions, gameplay tweaks, custom enemies, and whole added regions to explore, the modding community around Darkest Dungeon has breathed an incredible amount of extra life into a game that already had a lot going for it.
I am sensitive myself, but I will say that it's not for the faintest of heart in that there's a lot of (cartoon) gore, dark topics touched on, and a bit of (cartoon) body horror that might be disturbing for some... If it were realistic AAA graphics, I wouldn't play this game, so thank you cartoon art style!

It's an absolute goddamn shame that it's followup is Darkest Dungeon 2, a game that completely misunderstood what people loved about this game and made a bland, combat focused game with a horrible UI, unity engine jank, nonsensical excuse for a plot and an obnoxious gameplay loop. I understand the devs wanted to try something different, but they should've never used the DD name then.

Absolutely loved this game, From the Characters to the Enemy design. it always kept me on my toes thinking about my next move. To but to be fair I gotta share both Pro's and cons

Pro's (My opinions) CW: Minor Spoilers.

- Amazing Character Design and story. (I just think their all pretty)

- Everyone is good! All of the characters feel good to play and have their places. Sure there is the "Best" characters to do a run with. But that changes depending on what you're doing. Going to fight the prophet? Probably not a great idea to bring leper. But Fighting Swine god or Countess? (if you do the Crimson Court DLC) Leper absolutely Slaps! Going to deal with Shambler or Thing from the stars? (Color of Madness DLC) Plague Doctor, and Flage are great at doing DOT that ignores their Damage resistance. You can also run Bounty hunter, Hound Master, and Occultist who are Great at reducing those damage resistances.
Point being all of the characters are good for different things.

-Player Expression (Sort of? also kind of a continuation of the last pro.) There are several ways to deal with each situation. You're not required to play the game a specific way. Sure it makes it easier to run a million stuns and big chonk damage.  But it's not a requirement to do any specific build.

-The combat system (I know Hot take) I love the combat system, I feel that it's actually surprisingly fair, While getting crit 3 times in a row sucks, I mean RNG. on the other hand sometimes you deal 3+ crits in a row on an attack that has a 5% chance to crit, There is no objectively "correct" way to do combat, again while stunning everything and bursting it down before it get's a turn is really strong and probably the "best" way to do combat when Stunning is an option, it doesn't make other routes "incorrect" I came up with several solutions to combats, some better than others, some more goofy than others. I intentionally built the goofiest team I could think of to beat the game with because I thought it would be funny. this wasn't on the easiest difficulty either.

-Trinkets. I appreciate the trinkets adding another layer to the character building, both in story (Via Crimson Court Trinket quotes) and in team building, The fact that I can make Vestal the defacto healer into a front line tank with the right trinkets brings a whole nother level of enjoyment to team building for me.

-Quirks. I love the fact that characters can develop certain quirks both negative and positive, it adds a layer to the personality of each character as well as another element to the team building, ie Let's not bring someone with Cove Phobe to the Cove, But someone with Eldritch hater? Oh yeah, it's all comin together.

Now the Cons.

Cons

-The game is slow, like really slow. Movement through dungeons, Interactions, Scouting, Combat animations, and so on, Are all pretty slow. I don't personally find this to be much of an issue especially considering this game came out about 9 years ago at the time of this review (05/26/2025) But I understand for some people it is. 

-Some encounters are INCREDIBLY annoying. I Absolutely hate The hag, and the Siren can be annoying if you don't know what you're doing. I cannot even begin to go into all the reasons why I absolutely hate the hag fights. but to summarize....STOP TAKING MY PARTY MEMBERS YOU STUPID F*** I SWEAR TO GOD JUST LET ME KILL YOU I HATE THIS STUPID MECHANIC I SWEAR TO GOD I'M TURNING YOU INTO A STEW AFTER THIS AND FEEDING YOU TO MY ABOMINATION!

-The game is very....very Grindy, It takes so much time to get a character from 1-6 that I started just throwing characters into the DD just so that I could skip a week to try and find the right character at level 3 in the stage coach. When you start the game resources are so hard to come by that one bad run could ruin you financially and the only real way to recover is by grabbing some rando's from the stage coach and sending them into a dungeon and hoping they come back with something. Which if you get attached to all of your characters like I do, Sucks. 

-Butcher's Circus (Free PVP DLC) The Balance is kind of wack, really all I can say, Flage and Shield Breaker are kinda busted, but that makes sense since this is in fact made to be a solo PVE game. It could really use some balancing, but I doubt that'll happen anytime soon if ever considering the second game exists now.

Common Points. This is where I will address some of the common negative reviews on this game.

I could some most of them up with "Git Gud" but that doesn't really help anyone.

"Fake difficulty, and meaningless upgrades that never actually make you feel any stronger. They could literally just remove the upgrades entirely and simply add new enemies as you progress and the game would be the exact same."

I Greatly disagree with this point, I find myself Struggling to play earlier level dungeons Due to the lack of upgrades and Trinkets. It's not at all uncommon that I find myself Missing attacks on low level enemies with a low level party or having a bleed/Blight/Stun get Resisted, while against the same mob in later level dungeons I find this happens a lot less often, though I could see this being an issue if you aren't building Bleed/Blight/Stun Chance and Accuracy. 

"Balance wise the game is also wack. Seems like the only real choice to make is to stack accuracy on all your heroes because high level enemies have such ridiculous dodge chances. Stuns are OP, consumables take no action and healers are only useful for topping you off so there's very little actual meaningful decisions to make during combat."

I can understand this point, Accuracy is an important stat to consider but there are Many ways to deal with the issues of an enemy having a high dodge. Which by the way this review greatly exagurates the level of dodge the enemies get.

The Highest Dodge I could find that isn't a boss is the Madman which at max level have 40 dodge. Which if you have 100 ACC (Accuracy) Means you have a 60% chance to hit, And the madman much squishier than a lot of enemies. It kind of makes sens for this particular enemy to have this high of dodge. sure that's pretty high, but this mob in particular is pretty rare and this level of dodge is also not common.

The Highest level of dodge I could find on a boss was the Shrieker at 62, Which Yes is VERY HIGH, but is also Much squishier at this level than (Level 5 minimum) in terms of actual health than other bosses. With only 154 HP (185 on the hardest Difficulties) The only bosses with less health is the Hag with 135 (162 on Hardest difficulties) But also Steals one of your party members which requires you to split focus. 
And the Collector. My Arguement for the Collector is that summons 3 extra people who can protect it from damage and heal it. 

This is also not including the fact that your characters will have anywhere between 20-50 Dodge Unmodified at this level. and most of their accuracy will be over 100, meaning you'd have more of than a 60% chance to hit the madman. 

"Tedious. Obscure instructions. Punishes experimentation." 

This one makes sense but kind of depends on your definition of "Punishment" 
The game tells you from the get go that characters can and will die, it's about making the best of a bad situation. The Whole point is that it sucks and it's hard and the odds are stacked against you. If that's not for you, That's Entirely Valid. 
That doesn't make the game bad, nore do I believe it justifies a bad review. 

TL/DR: Game is Great, It has it's issues but the game is 9ish years old at time of review, what game doesn't have it's issues? Addressed some points on negative reviews with much nicer ways of saying "Git Gud" and if the game isn't for you that's valid. The game is hard and it states this every time you launch it. The game being hard and not for you doesn't make it bad.

Dark Dungeons is a critically acclaimed indie game, and here are some reviews of the game:


Game play

· Strategy and depth: The game adopts turn-based combat system, and players need to match the lineup, position and skills of four heroes. For example, the Robber's "Close Shot" ability is powerful, but it can only be cast in the front and will fall back one space after casting, which requires the player to carefully arrange the standing position of the team and the skill release order.

· Character development and resource management: Players need to run small towns, recruit heroes, and manage resources as they explore dungeons. At the same time, they also deal with the stress and quirks of heroes to prevent them from falling apart or slipping.

· Difficulty and challenge: the game is difficult, fault tolerance is low and there is some randomness. Players need to constantly try and adjust strategies to make progress in the dungeon.


Game Features

· Dark and depressing style: The art style of the game is dark and depressing, and the background follows a pessimistic line. This style complements the theme and atmosphere of the game, and creates a tense and mysterious game experience for players.

· Unique pressure system: The game has a pressure system. Heroes will accumulate pressure during the process of fighting and exploration. When the pressure is too high, it may lead to collapse. This system adds complexity and realism to the game.

· Rich character setting: Each character has a unique backstory and personality traits. Players can learn more about their characters' stories by completing their individual tasks.


Gaming experience

· Immersion: The music and narration of the game create a tense atmosphere and enhance the player's sense of substitution.

· Repeatability: The game has high repeatability, and players can constantly challenge the dungeon through different character combinations and strategies.

· Learning curve: the game is difficult to get started, and it may take novice players some time to get familiar with the game mechanism.


limitation

· Insufficient novice guidance: The novice guidance of the game is not perfect enough, which may confuse novice players.

· Randomness affects the experience: The high randomness of the game may make some players feel that there is too much luck.

Overall, Dark Dungeons is a deep and challenging game that attracts a lot of players with its unique gameplay and dark style. Although the game has some shortcomings, its advantages far outweigh its disadvantages.

Darkest Dungeon is a game about struggle, it's about surviving at the best of your capabilities in an overwhelming and desperate situation. Don't expect to constantly win, it's not about "how" or "if" you lose, it's about when, and making sure those "whens" are as few as possible. Any run can quickly go downhill even with the most prepared team just because of some bad luck.

However, while this is true since, after all, it's the whole point of the game, it still does a fantastic job of making you understand why you lose and how you can overcome your losses. The game often reminds you through the ancestor that you should never approach a fight or a dungeon with overconfidence, you should always be as prudent as possible because the game WILL make you fall sooner or later.

So if your run ends with a team wipe (worst possible outcome), it's most of the time your fault, and the sooner you realize that, the sooner you understand how the game works and how to make the most out of its mechanics.

Team wipes come from overconfidence so if you ever suffer one ask yourself: "What did i do wrong this run? Was it a poorly put together team? Not enough damage output? Scarse healing? Maybe i should have taken a safer path instead of trying to get more loot?"
You can get really good at the game once you understand the heroes' synergies, their best position and combinations with different kinds of playstyles but most importantly their weaknesses and how to make sure their impact is minimized.
If an hero dies on you, always remember of what the ancestor often tells you and start considering leaving the run. It's always better to leave with some stress and little loot than to leave a run broke and with 3 more dead heroes. 

Talking about the heroes, they have some amazing design and playstiles allowing for a lot of creativity with teambuilding. It needs some time to get used to every hero's movesets, but once it clicks the only problem you can run into is bad luck. Just remember that bad team combinations are most of the time fatal. I don't want to talk about the heroes too much, you should see for yourself and find your own favourite combination.

If i had to make an actual criticism of the game would be its repetivity if you don't particularly like the gameplay since it's a very very grindy game and also the speed mechanic is a bit random and can feel unfair at times (basically every round start everybody gets a hidden roll based on their actual speed, meaning sometimes a monster with 6 speed can go first than an 8 speed hero and viceversa).

Otherwise i think the game is a masterpiece especially for its time thanks to its innovative mechanics, even today, its super-unique artstyle, the hero design is fantastic and the enemy designs specifically are phenomenal in my opinion and the gameplay loop, while harsh at times, is really rewarding.

"Remind yourself that overconfidence is a slow and insidious killer.": A not very loved local man

Darkest Dungeon: The Game That Gave My Anxiety Anxiety
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️ (5/5 — would get emotionally wrecked again)

Let me start by saying Darkest Dungeon isn’t a game — it’s a full-blown mental health simulator wrapped in a love letter to H.P. Lovecraft and sealed with a blood-soaked wax stamp. Imagine if Edgar Allan Poe, your middle school emo phase, and a sea of tentacles had a baby. That’s Darkest Dungeon.

You start with a happy little group of adventurers, all bright-eyed and bushy-tailed. Fast forward five minutes: one’s paranoid, one’s abusive, one has a gambling addiction, and the last one is hugging the corner whispering “the abyss gazes back.” Classic team-building!

Tentacles? Oh, you bet.
If you don’t like tentacles, first of all: how dare you. Second: this game isn’t for you. There are more slimy appendages here than in a late-night anime forum. By week three in-game, you’ll start questioning if your real-life soup is trying to mind-control you.

Inspired by Lovecraft?
Absolutely. If you’ve read Lovecraft, you’ll recognize the vibes: unexplainable horrors, relentless dread, and vocabulary that makes you say “do I even speak English?” The narrator (voiced by Wayne June — a man whose voice could narrate my grocery list and still make me cry) basically reads excerpts from the Necronomicon while you watch your Crusader have a nervous breakdown because someone looked at him funny.

Mechanics?
Your characters stress out over everything. They’re like Tamagotchis with PTSD. Step on a weird tile? Stress. Teammate coughs? Stress. Something squelches in the dark? Double stress. I’ve seen less drama in reality TV.

And when they die — because they will die — the game just shrugs and tells you to “recruit more meat shields.” Heartwarming.

Final thoughts?
Darkest Dungeon is a beautifully cruel game that teaches you life lessons like:

Never open an ancient tome.

Tentacles are never friendly.

Trust no one. Especially yourself.

And for the love of sanity, bring a jester. You’ll need him more than therapy.

If you’re into atmospheric horror, tactical punishment, and existential dread with a side of calamari, you’ll love this game. Just... don’t get too attached to your party. Or your sanity. Or hope.

I was hesitant about buying this game. I always read the reviews of games before buying them, and it seemed like some people had conflicted oppinions about the game; how it's too grindy, the gameplay is slow, it's too hard etc, but I gave it a try anyway. I've been playing for the last 5 days nonestop, I LOVE this game, and let me tell you why I don't completely agree with every negative thing I said earlier:

1) I don't mind the grinding at all. The game is literally about doing the same expeditions all over again, but the fact that the game is hard (so it's always a challenge), and that you can use different characters every time and even different builds for each character, I don't feel like it's that repetitive, and you'll find yourself going over the same missions by your own will, because you want to get a certain item, or because you want the money reward. So yeah, even though I believe the grinding might not be for everyone, just letting you know that for many people (maybe even yourself), it isn't an inconvenience in most cases.
2) The game is not that slow, but if you have played other games like balatro and slay the spire, you're probably familiar with an option to increase the game's speed. Even though it is very helpfull and I believe they should implement it in this game as well, you can 100% enjoy it the way it is without it, so don't let that hold you up.
3) The game is hard, yes it is, and some people may not like it, but if you're up for a challenge, this is the game for you.

Remarkable rogue-like strategy game.

Takes considerable effort to learn hero strengths, possible dangers, and--every-time you do anything-- there is a final dice check to decide the outcome, really like the tension and relief these random elements provide. 

I also love the rough early game, which forces risk-taking, and the late game which lets you experiment with all that you have gathered so far. 

Unfortunately, the game can be very grindy, so I would recommend using workshop mods to speed up movement, actions, and quests with a sprinkle of inventory stack, to curve time/enjoyment. 
Do buy the DLCs, they add richness to a second play through after you are comfortable with the basics.

It's just good, like damn good.
It makes you make calculated risks and hard choices.
 deaths hurt, resources need to be used wisely, you need to figure out what to keep and what to replace in your inventory and sometimes that call isn't easy and you would give anything to undo it with new information.
Grindy (the bad kind), punishing for the sake of being punishing and overal uninteresting. At times, feels more like a chore than something fun and engaging.
I found a cool looking totem thing and it asked me to put a torch in it, suddenly my whole team was butchered. 10/10 would reset again.

Very Good!  An RPG stripped down to the battles and tactics.  Great for when you just want to do some battles without all the other things bogging you down.  Not to say the story and writing is not good because it is.  The narration and the extremely dark mood is just awesome, as well as the music.  So well done and challenging for what might appear on the surface to be a game without much depth.

Highly recommend!
Extremely addictive, its a good game if your trying to replace alcoholism or smoking crack with something healthy.
Great game and even better modding community.

Perfect execution of a concept and oozes style out of every orifice.
Core gameplay is a party based loot delve with turn based combat and character progress that defined a genre.

A great balance between punishingly hard and rewardingly satisfying.
Great game for recovering perfectionists. Get ready to make peace with bad RNG, less than ideal outcomes and pushing forward regardless.

Brutal, unforgiving, premadeath game.

10/10

I am currently playing this game for the second time, first playthrough was on some other platform.

The sinister atmosphere and the dark cartoon graphics are amazing. It was my first encounter with roguelikes and I liked it and still like.

From time to time, it is a bit grindy though.

The game punishes you for not mindlessly grinding a perfect roster on stygian difficulty.  Reminiscent of games like Final Fantasy 2 which are barely playable today, but this has the Dark Souls "get good" attitude surrounding a game mostly fueled by randomness.  The fact that there's no way to mitigate enemy dodge potential ruins any skill component as I've had a miniboss with 19 dodge (no spoilers, swamp) evade more hits than an enemy with twice its dodge stat, and no it did not have the dodge buff which makes me think there's an actual glitch maintaining the buff regardless of presence.

I've completed games like Slay the Spire and Monster Sanctuary which also have pretty heavy RNG mechanics (card drawing and critical hit percentages respectively), but this game's randomness is pointlessly punishing to the extent that I'd prefer a game that doesn't conceal its RNG like For the King.
Big learning curve with high punishment of losing characters early but totally different gameplay to other RPGs where there is little to no consequence to losing. Very fresh in that regard.
My favorite game of all time - I love the artwork, the voice acting, the game mechanics, and the many mods. Even though I have never been able to beat the game, it keeps me coming back for more.

This is one of my favourite indie games ever. I played so much of it on my Nintendo Switch before deciding to sell it and play it for free on xbox game pass. Then I played even MORE of it....but was taken off xbox gamepass before I completed it so I've yet AGAIN bought it on steam. I love naming the characters after people I know and being really sad when they perma-die but I also love the satisfaction you get from (almost) every successful mission

The game presents itself as an unfair, possibly even BS challenge at first, and that is a key part of the appeal, but from there there's a lot of satisfaction in eventually learning how it all ticks and overcoming that difficulty. 

If the gameplay loop clicks for you, with modding and DLC you can probably get a few hundred hours out of it before it gets stale, which is great value.

This game is great, but it's hard to pay long bouts because it's tension leaves me feeling drained quickly. 
Highly recommend, I'll be playing a lot more of it albeit slowly!

I do have to recommend Darkest Dungeon to fans of rogue-likes, eldritch horror, and turn-based rpgs, but I also have to say, it's not for the faint of heart. If you're going in blind, be prepared to lose everything, and I do mean, everything. This game has a delightful understanding of the assignment of engendering the attrition and stressors of the setting in a masterful ludonarrative blend. This is a difficult, and unforgiving game, but has a rewarding gameplay loop and interesting lore. Can't wait to get my hands on the sequel to see how the team have improved on this formula.
such a great game where your choices really matter. Would definitely recommend and I have. Get the game if you are a true dungeon crawler. Its a definite must have.

This game lives and breathes by the Rule of Cruel. Murphy as my witness, the character you can not afford to get hard focused and targeted by enemies WILL and with their strongest possible moves. Go ahead and stack virtue chance, you'll never see a virtue anyways. Your stun WILL miss on an enemy with a measly resistance chance. This game is evil and smart enough to use that evil well. 

However, this is still an incredible turn based gem. The art style, the characters, the raw masculinity emanating from the phenomenal performance of the narrator's voice actor; these things will keep you in the game long enough to build up a futile defiance to this game to carry on just to prove that you are worthy of existing in such a hateful game. 

Frustrating to a fault, but the payoff for pushing on is satisfying. Worth playing through. Goes on sale often enough and is easily worth its cost on the discounts you often see.

It's a good Lovecraftian horror game.  Set in a period where guns mixed with swords in a world where monsters and sorcery are more than legend, Darkest Dungeon is a side-scrolling game that is strategic and turn-based.  It fills a niche that has been missing in all the real-time games.  While your characters will not recover from death, many illnesses and wounds can be treated as the game progresses.  Money and resources are limited, though.  Will you dismiss one that is too wounded rather than see them fall in battle?  Will you focus your resources on a single set of characters only to watch them face impossible odds?  The game doesn't promise easy success - that's part of the appeal.  It does promise progress.  

Learn a little about it in advance if you want to increase your odds of keeping favored characters.

Very engaging and captures the theme perfectly. Later on you see the limitations of the dimensions and game design but thats easily overshadowed by the game progression which is very steady paced and keeps you engaged. The modding community is dedicated and very alive. If you like slower paced and calculated decision making, I highly recommend.

P.S. Crimson court is absolutely unforgiving (i love it).

I'd recommend it, but barely. The squad management is alright, but I prefer other squad-rpgs like XCOM or Fire Emblem. I think this game has less depth than it appears.

None off that is to say it's not fun; you'll likely get your money's worth if you stick with it.

The atmosphere in this game is truly amazing. The music by Stuart Chatwood and narration by Wayne June (RIP) elevate the immersion so much. Even while I am getting my ass torn to shreds, it feels epic thanks to the ancestor's voice. And of course, massive props to all the people in Red Hooks for creating such an incredible game. If you want a challenge paired with great aesthetics, I definitely recommend Darkest Dungeon.

Darkest Dungeon with all the additions is a much less repetitive game than its basic version, at least if the player looks forward to only complete the major objectives of the game. The minor objectives, like building the Mill or the Red Hook, can drag the game way, way too long than it is enjoyable to play it for, and it does ruin the experience of a normally very unique, constantly thrilling and challenging experience. As someone who grew up with turn-based RPGs, Darkest Dungeon showed me the potential that the combat system still has, for a designer who is willing to risk and do some experiments.

This game is a REAL challenge. People may like to cry "RNG! RNG!" at the game when they lose and write a crappy review over it but truly believe it is a good game. A great game even. Because it captures what so many other games are missing. i cant put my finger on it but you can put hundreds of hours into this game and still walk into a dungeon feeling unsure. You can be doing fantastic and the game throws a curveball and half your party is dead. RNG doesn't make this game "unfair". Its gambling. The anticipation of not knowing is a high all on it's own and it feels crappy when you lose but when you win you feel relieved and a wave of dopamine washes over you.

If you TRULY love RNG in all her ways i highly recommend

Steep learning curve.

Okay, so I was gifted this on Steam by some friends (Specifically Ancestral Edition), and I can say after coming back to it on PC that it is a emotional rollercoaster. The challenge is brutals, the odds are against you, characters die without any way to bring them back, gold & time is put to waste when a Hero is fell. But... the game tells you this. It's hardcore as hell on purpose. If you want to get the most out of this game alongside its DLCs, the modding scene is incredible. The Workshop for this game features new enemies (Including Bosses & Minibosses), trinkets, fixes, UI changes, new Heros, Hero skins, New Dungeons, etc. It's probably one of the cooler games when it comes to its modding scene and I heavily suggest going slow and being patient when you play this; expect death at every corner and play it smart.

Nonetheless, I'd say the game's a solid 8/10 if you love yourself a brutal turn-based dungeon crawler.

You've read the wiki and guides. You've prepared the party. Things are going good. You lose it all in one fight just because the RNG decided so. Not because you haven't prepared, but because the chance decided to bend you in half.

This game scratches an itch similar to a souls-like game or a hardcore gamemode. You start off super weak, put a couple hours in playing, and the game is pretty difficult, but then you sorta get the hang of it. It starts to make sense, you learn combos, you equip items, characters level up, then you get really good at it. But it all gets ripped away from you in an instant. Your favorite character dies from a heart attack. Your party is in shambles. You have no healer. You have no gold. Half of the characters you recruited and leveled are now going insane. There are only difficult quests and expeditions left to choose from. You have to sacrifice some characters you spent time enjoying because there's no other options.
...
10/10 Love the art style and narrator too.

I recommend this one, but with some caveats

The positive aspects of this game are widely praised, and for good reason. That being said, I do have some gripes with the game. To give some context, I’m a player with limited time due to life commitments, so this game works well for me. It's nice to just have it running, pause, and come back to it when I can.

What I can't quite wrap my head around (and honestly, find frustrating) is how RNG-heavy the game is, especially when you're thrown into events and late-game dungeons with no guidance and no way to escape without losing a character. Given the time it takes to level up your toons, gather trinkets, and figure out team synergies, this feels poorly thought out. It basically forces players to keep multiple backups of the same class just to be safe. While it's a time sink that's usually fun, it gradually turns into a chore, especially in the endgame. I also have to add that a complete run of the game takes very long !

I don't think this gets criticized enough, so I wanted to leave my thoughts here.

oh Man! This game is addictive. If you like roguelikes and rpgs, you will love Darkest Dungeon. It has a methodically team crafting (create a team of 4 with 17 pre made heroes), tons of trinkets to collect to empower your heroes, difficult bosses to beat and amazing side content to indulge in. Darkest Dungeon will consume your time if you aren't careful, also don't get attached to any of your heroes!

this is not a game to play after work to relieve some stress, but the dopamine hit after a victory is good, better than my wife asking me what do you want to eat. As the man with the voice of God says "There is a sickness in the ancient, pitted cobbles of the Old Road, and on its writhing path, you will face viciousness, violence, and, perhaps, other damnably transcendent terrors." Couldn't have said it better myself, so, steel yourself, and remember, there can be no bravery without madness. Because the Old Road will take you to Hell, but in that gaping abyss, we will find our redemption.

The game doesn't support ultra wide even though the devs promised it would almost 10 years ago. I can't even get the game to go to full screen on my ultra wide. It goes in and out with my brand new controller as well. No other games I own have these issues and you have had a decade to fix them.

Edit: You can get at least black bars to work on UW monitors in Win 11 but it's a bit indepth. 
Go into game files and find the steam version folder and the file darkest.exe right click and go to properties. Go into DPI settings and change it to application. I also put the game in compatibility mode for Windows 8. These things together seemed to have done the trick it also allowed me to use the game in full screen. Now it's great but this isn't common knowledge and should be put out there for folks buying the game and playing on ultra wide with win 11.

Darkest Dungeon absolutely hates you. And that's exactly what makes it so unique.

The satisfaction of the game comes from just the worst person ever asking you to juggle a molotov cocktail two 4 month old babies and the spiked ball portion of a medieval mace and slowly, surely over endless runs, you actually manage to pull that act off and surpass it: very few games make you feel like you've mastered it quite like Darkest Dungeon.

This game undeniably has some really questionable design choices that comes inevitably with its nature: you will get frustrated, rightfully so. A great game with an atmosphere like nothing else. I know that the turn-based genre isn't very popular these days, but I think this is something that those who are averse to it can give a try. There are only two negative points I can make. One is that the last few maps can only be completed in several tries, which wouldn't be a problem, just replacing a lost hero and upgrading to level 6 is a grind. And not the fun kind. If you could hire heroes that don't start from level 3, but from say level 5 it would be a different story. The other is the introduction of multiplayer, which is an interesting concept, but no one plays it because it would lose the essence of the game. Still, it's a great game with the most epic narrator I've ever heard. 8.5/10

This fun game will teach you that you always need to be prepared for surprises.
After all, this game is about:
When you can beat all the heroes one monster at a time for three rounds, and never get hit.
When you can return from cleaning the crypt, and see that your hero has contracted diarrhea from skeletons.
When you sent a character to a tavern to relieve stress, and that fool drank your legendary item.
When you sent a Hero to pray, and then it turns out that he fled the city.
When you, saving your hero from death, heal him to a powerful 0, and then the saved one dies from bleeding, which was caused by this incredible trick.
When in the midst of the battle, your character can hit you in the back, because he is stressed, and he needs to be taken somewhere).
When you took a new character on a hike, where during a halt, he dreamed of snakes that killed the entire squad, including himself.
When your character is made into a delicious soup, while everyone else can only watch, because he was the only one who was able to deal normal damage.
This is one of many that awaits you when you dare to descend into the darkest dungeon.

There are two quotes that do a good job of summing this game up, the first line you read upon entering the main menu and one of the battle end lines:
"This game is about making the most of a bad situation"
"Overconfidence is a slow and Insidious killer"

Darkest Dungeon is probably one of the most rewarding games I have played. It is a masterclass in combining game mechanics with intended tone and subject matter. It is hands down the most pure example of dark fantasy that I can think of, blending in a little bit of cosmic horror as well. Not for the faint of heart due to difficult themes and a very hopeless tone, but the folks at Red Hook handle them very well and it never feels like they added something just for shock value. 
I would highly encourage people who are interested in the content but worried about how the gameplay will feel to give it a try. Even though it seems difficult to understand the complexity of abilities, roster management, trinket interactions, and the overall goals of the game at the beginning, you will learn, and after many, many heroes in your graveyard, you will prevail.

As an added bonus, the Ancestor's narration is some of the most memorable dialogue in any game or movie I've experienced.

So, I highly recommend that you gather your deeply flawed gang of ruffians and sinners and delve into the madness of the Darkest Dungeon.

Pain.

That said, I’ve never managed to finish it; the game is quite difficult and extremely punishing when it comes to death and failure, which can turn away more casual players.

just mod the game. its very easy to add, modify, and alt characters to make the game more "tasteful" both visually and gameplay wise. in all honesty the base game is fun but after modding it with extra classes , some UI changes, and new skins for the characters it makes a world of difference. Unlike any other roguelike i've ever played. The gameplay is so ADDICTING, even when dying and full wiping over and over and over. Not to mention the niche things that games dont really dive deep on anymore. Your character might be a hero, but they are flawed, every human is. This is shown in the form of bad quirks, ranging to being weaker in the dark, or being an alcoholic. Stress also plays a huge roll. Stress affects everyone, even the most veteran of people. And at some point, people break. Whether they are virtuous or afflicted just come down to the person, and other factors. The announcer is just spectacular, RIP unfortunantly. The music also goes so good with the theme and setting, not the mention the gritty artstyle. The game is hard, expect to lose and die over and over, but thats the fun of it. 11/10 would recommend to ANYONE
Love the gameplay loop, sound and aesthetics although I hate grinding which I was able to mitigate thanks to some mods.

I didn't finish the game when it just released as it just seemed like too much of a skill issue for me. I must say, while still difficult as hell, the town events help a ton, and you feel like you can bounce back even when you lose your best people. Great game - simple controls and combat with complex stradegy and tactics.  Love all the classes and finding new combinations of 4 heroes.  The difficult keeps the game interesting.

Gorgeous art, really fun and creative mechanics, plus I love the music and the flavour text! Great game if you just want to chill out for the afternoon.

By the gods themselves, this game is HARD. When i tell you i've played this on Xbox, PlayStation and PC, this game and its.... many... many unique instances, events and challenges even modded characters aren't even close to being overpowered should say my spite for me. This game consists of four things i have noticed: Character choices making a difference (cant and shouldn't run same party even twice in a row), Stress almost number one killer in the game (funny how similar to real life it is), 
Being prepared and RNGesus still saying... mmmm.. Nahhh (hurts to bring in sooo many torches and enough food for your party to still die of stress in the dark or of hunger at a camp site), And last but surely not least the pure RNG of trying to gather the materials needed for the many upgrades needed (however as you aren't guaranteed even 1 of them, you could spend several runs just trying to gather meager portions of what you need) Overall very well made game have enjoyed it even through the struggles and will continue to do so even through the second game too. 8)

Very punishing but in a way where you feel fully in control of your mistakes and deaths of your team. Amazing art, sound design, and top notch voice acting from the ancestor.. I want an audio book read by him!
i really love the mechanics of Darkest Dungeon-they're intricate yet well-designed,and the characters are constantly driven to madness

Beautiful art combined with resource and party management in a gritty and tense dark fantasy. Turned based combat with unique elements such as stress management and roguelike elements for dungeons, party members and the positive/negative traits of the characters. Can lead to some morbidly funny situations, such as party members gaining phobias, but can also be pretty unforgiving and brutal. Overall, a great time.

tl;dr is that luck plays too big of a factor in this game to warrant such heavy and punishing consequences.

In a regular roguelite or "rogue-adjacent" game, if you lose a run, you simply lose the current run you're in. In Darkest Dungeon, if you lose, your whole team gets wiped causing you to lose HOURS of time and investment towards those units and I genuinely don't think the consequences blend well and match with how sh*tty the RNG can be in this game. You can have the best knowledge of this game and most meticulously crafted builds ever but if your RNG decides to f*ck you over and you wipe your team, you WILL lose hours of progress and I just can't respect this kind of game design, no matter how incredible that game was initially.

darkest dungeon is a very intense turn based dungeon crawler where everything wants to kill you and you have to think quickly on your feet. if you enjoy challenging combat and relentless game mechanics this is for you.

Absolutely addicting game and really emotional at moments. Going through a dungeon with a team that plows through just to get massacred by some boss (just happened to me with the Brigade 8 pounder, nearly lost 15k in gold) is a truly great experience
this game is so fun and addicting. art direction is great!

absolutely time consuming story about a turn based dynamic position battler adventure becomes a deep journey down a path of curiosity and exploring your ancestors secrets as you dive into the Darkest Dungeon.
I installed a couple mods, literally only a few and now I can't read the descriptions of any items or moves, even after uninstalling all mods AND starting a new save. Incredibly frustrating.

Darkest Dungeon is a masterpiece of tension, strategy, and atmosphere. This game doesn’t just challenge your skills—it tests your resolve. From the haunting narration to the oppressive art style, every element pulls you into its grim, Lovecraftian world.

The turn-based combat is deceptively simple but incredibly deep. Managing your party’s stress levels, quirks, and relationships adds a unique layer of strategy that keeps every dungeon crawl fresh and nerve-wracking. One wrong move, and your carefully built team can spiral into madness or be wiped out entirely. It’s punishing, but fair—every failure feels like a lesson learned.

The art style is stunning, with hand-drawn characters and environments that ooze gothic horror. The narrator’s voice is iconic, delivering lines that are equal parts dramatic and chilling. The soundtrack perfectly complements the mood, making every moment feel like a descent into hell.

Yes, it’s hard. Yes, it can be unforgiving. But that’s what makes Darkest Dungeon so rewarding. When you finally overcome a brutal boss or survive a harrowing dungeon, the sense of accomplishment is unmatched.

If you love strategy, horror, or just a game that doesn’t hold your hand, this is a must-play. Just remember: Overconfidence is a slow and insidious killer.

The game is a classic for a reason. Solid gameplay, grueling and difficult but immersive and stimulating. The downside is that, like XCOM and other %-chance based games, you WILL get unlucky sometimes but at least the game offers many options to compensate and work around it. Playing it in 2025 means that it's also pretty bug free and all the content is out so you won't need to replay the whole campaign when new DLC hits the market.
This is fiendishly difficult, and you constantly feel like you are about to break the back of it... but you never seem to. Even on easy!
Great game. Takes a while to learn, but it keeps me coming back for more.

This game is a masterpiece. Everything from the setting, to the enemies, to the characters, to the music/sound effects, and the HEART, the SOUL, the VOICE of this game: Wayne June. RIP, sir. 

This game is as cold in its mercilessness as it is euphoric in the light of triumph. It is brutal, it demands so much from you: one mistake will cost you champions that you have put so much time and resources into, even bestowing a name onto! -- extinguishing as quickly as a candle's flame would to the passing wind. This game will beat you down and fling you to the bottom of the world, but the one thing that this game beats into you through your mounting failures is that you MUST learn from your mistakes. You MUST think carefully, or you will lose at least 7 additional hours to make up for your shortsightedness as I did. If you can't, you may as well just quit playing, 

The best thing that I like about this game is its stress mechanic, which goes from 0 to 100 to 200. At 200 (or around 180), the champion suffers a heart attack and all their HP goes to 0, which may lead to them succumbing to a deathblow: they actually die. The reason why I bring it up is because once they hit the 100 mark, they make two choices: to fall to one of their vices ("abusive", "hopeless", "fearful", "paranoid", "selfish", "irrational", "masochistic") OR they can press on and showcase one of their virtues ("stalwart", "courageous", "focused", "powerful", vigorous"). 

While we may never encounter otherworldly beings or the horrible nature of "cosmic truth", this game almost subliminally asks you: "when you are pushed to your so-called limit, will you fall prey to yourself and doom those around you or will stake your life for yourself and the people around you?"

There's a good amount difficulty and challenge in both planning and team building.

I found the planning for each expedition to be a bit tedious

Onw of the best PC games you can play of all time if you like old editions of D&D, Call of Cthulu or just about any old-school TTRPG or CRPG.
In terms of discount price this game is a Steal if you factor quality and quantity. Atmosphere, gameplay, visual design.
The great divider is going to be challenge and it's going to be the thing that makes you love, hate or love & hate this game.
Part of the experience is to accept that failiure is inevitable but not the end of the game, that to experiment is to try chances, and take note of what works and what punishes you. If you don't have this kind of resilence but still want to play this game, the wiki has a very nice overview of both the basics as well of it's secrets and outcomes of certain interactions, information that will help you feel that you playing with better chances, but even then remember that the ultimate ancient is not the horrors of the mind but of the dice, that sometimes and some challenges are stacked against you and that to fail or to triumph is not always completely on your hands, that the only certanties are the risks that you take and when you decide to run for victory or for your lives.

Addictive gameplay with dense, turn based combat and grim vibes.

What to say about Darkest Dungeon?  I love the art style, the narrator is possibly one of the best voices I've heard for the spot in a long time, and though the story is somewhat miniscule, it's really not that important.

Combat at a glance is a simple turn-based affair, but with a metric ton of deeper nuance that can be overlooked if you're not paying attention.  This game absolutely does not hold your hand, and aims to cut it off if given the chance.  Don't get too attached to your characters because this game can and will be a meat grinder.  Pay attention.  Look at enemy details.  Experiment with item interactions, and learn what not to touch at all.  An absolute masterpiece to get lost in.

Nice game i LOVE IT. It have tactical, turn-based combat that demands careful resource and stress management.Hero death is permanent, and every run feels different. A must-play for fans of tactical RPGs and dark fantasy. Prepare for frustration, but also immense satisfaction!!!

[h1]This game is an acquired taste.[/h1]
[br]
I remember trying this game back in 2016 and having an adverse reaction to it. Without the correct mindset you can't enjoy this game. This is not a game about defeating the horrors of the beyond one turn at a time. It's a game about all the bad, mental and physical, scars you get for adventuring. [spoiler]And to quote the narrator "Scars can be healed; But never hidden"[/spoiler]

Last year i saw a huge discount on the game and was in the mood to torture myself, i thought. Oh, boy was that pain enjoyable. In this game you don't get attached to the heroes, you don't care if they go insane. Death is inevitable. All your hard work can be gone in a flash. But there are mountains of bodies to throw at the problem.

Besides the awesome aesthetics, what kept me hooked on the game were the mechanics. The way that stats interact with buffs and debuffs. The way that every single quirk of a character counts. The way they are humanized, with all their flaws, yet so distant that they don't have to linger on your mind. How [b]stress[/b] plays such an important role in the game. How you have to care for your heroes not only physical, but also mental.

[h3]I strongly believe that this game managed to strike the perfect balance between making you care about the people under your command and detaching yourself from them, by making sure this is not a hopeful setting to be in.[/h3]

[br]

[h1]UPDATE: After finishing the game[h1] (no spoilers)

OH MY FUCKING GOD, IT WAS SUCH A CATHARTIC ENDING!!! So good! Some would say it's the best... one of the best!

Great game, wonderful balance of story, narration, and difficulty. Carves out a niche that is difficult for another game to fill. Has upgrade permanence while never allowing you to get so strong that you're always safe. I can't recommend this game enough, definitely worth full price, a must buy if it's on sale.

I don´t have over 500 hours in this game because I like completing it over and over. I actually haven´t entered the final Darkest Dungeon once. What I do is that I download around 100 mods, mostly new characters, and I just spend a hundred hours leveling and gearing them up. It does take so long and it is that fun. 

I repeat this every once in a while when a dozen or so new character mods have been released and that is how I ended up with this playtime. Be careful that you don´t overdo it with the mods though, I have lost a 200+ hours "campaign" to corrupted save before. Just don´t spam too many mods that alter the game too much and you will be fine. Don´t be inside a dungeon when you install new mods!

It helps when you can edit character stats in notepad. You can really make the game as easy or hard as you want to. The gameplay never gets old, neither do the legendary narrator lines. Rest in peace Wayne June.

I love this game. It's dark, it's gritty, just the right level of difficulty. This game has given me so many hours of fun and the workshop/modding support from the developers only increased that level of fun. 20/10. Buy it.

One of the best RPG's ever made, and one of my all-time favorite games. Absolutely not for the faint of heart, this is a game that will test your mettle like no other RPG has before. Difficult, even on the easiest setting. Don't get too terribly attached to any character... you just may lose them, and when they die, they stay dead. The town management aspect adds a ton of depth to a game that was pretty deep to begin with, this is a game that you will definitely be totally absorbed in for many hours, and boy, oh boy, is the satisfaction level high when you do finally get a good run going.

100% recommend, this is a game that I would buy again and again on any platform.

Edit: I've been playing this again recently, and while I 100% mean everything that I said above, one thing that I HAVE TO mention is: if you don't like stressful games, or a lot of management, stay away from this game. This is a game that you absolutely need to put many hours into, and it's quite easy for things to go horribly, horribly awry late (or early) into your run. You will most likely be restarting a few times. You WILL be on the edge of your seat on multiple occasions. Yelling at the screen in frustration inducing sometimes. You WILL get hammered by RNG more than once, and when you lose a character, you also lose their equipped gear, which can really hurt when they are max level with rare gear. There were times when I considered uninstalling the game a few times. If you're into a challenge, this is the game for you, if you're not... maybe look at other options.
It is a hard game, espcially the final dungeon. Still very fulfilling.
Fantastic art, storytelling, and overall atmosphere with one of the best turn-based combat systems in recent memory.

One of the best Turn-based I've ever played. It was so good that after 3 years of not playing it since work, I bought a SD just to play it again.

A challenging and maddeningly infuriating game, its easy to pick up but hard to master as it constantly puts you on the edge of your seat as encounters quickly sway in and out of your favour. That said, permadeath mechanics combined with heavy rng elements in the form of crits and dodge mechanics make for some unfair and almost unpredictable losses. Overall would recommend if you're fine with such infuriating setbacks, otherwise you'll find yourself dropping the game for a few weeks at a time like me after raging.

You know when you start that you have little chance to succeed. It's maddening, annoying, unreasonably difficult, borders on a waste of the player's time and is one of the best games I've ever played. It's all worth it.

Legendary tier game

This is a good and challenging game. I do not understand why this is very positive (I thought this game is overwhelmingly positive)

I guess the reason would be some randomness. If you are unlucky and lose all hero, then you may feel bad on this game. However, I believe the game design does not strongly depend on the luck. Everything can be overcame by preparation.

(Time played not representative of total time; also played on Epic) 

The art direction of this game is so unique, I don't quite have the words to describe it. The entire game has a dark feel to it, executed in the best way possible. The narrator has a perfect voice that carries throughout the game. 

The gameplay itself is also really fun. Never quite are you safe, and something can always go wrong. I personally loved the scaling and the pace at which heroes get stronger, along with the enemy. 
The combat is just turn-based fun - I find the position system unique as it forces you to consider implications of abilities that move heroes from one to another. 

Very highly recommend, one of my favourite games of all time.

I have tried so many times to like this game. I have even given it multiple year breaks, multiple times because I like so much of it and wanted to give the developers to patch the obviously broken RNG and stop trolling the fans instead of catering to the "1337". I have never wanted to love a game more than this one but have been left with no choice but to hate the game and the developer Red Hook. I cannot in good conscious recommend a game that intentionally makes me actively hate the characters I'm suppose to care about, level up and command while actively hating the sadism of the developers cheap reliance on fake, sadistic "RNG". 

I don't mind losing a toon or two, but losing my highest ranking toon on a short/mid level run, because the "RNG" decided to crit one specific toon with every single enemy after all my toons were done, then crit that same specific toon with every single enemy before any healers on my team could even take a turn, killing the healer I spent over a dozen hours leveling because "F" me in particular.

Too much difficult for difficulties sake.
Everything in this game punishes you. Punished for taking too long, punished for bad rolls. 
You have to spend resources to destress your characters. Except, those can punish you too! Now they've obtained a quirk just by fucking relaxing. No way to stop it, reduce. Now you have to deal with that permanent debuff or pay a ton of resources to fix it. And at this point they're out of action minimum two missions.

Would love a game like this with less upkeep baggage.

the combat makes me tired, the turn order is unclear but it feels like the enemy takes like 8 actions before i can do 1 attack. then when i attack, we simply just miss and die i guess.

it doesnt feel strategic or pressuring, just boring and one sided.

Even on the easiest setting, supposedly for new players, the game is incredibly frustrating.. All the characters are just terrified the whole time. Walking down the hall? GAIN FEAR. Hit by an attack? GAIN FEAR. My own guy transforms into a beast to attack the enemy? All other party members GAIN FEAR. And then GAIN maladies. And run out of money. Might have been a cool game if I could have succeeded in a few things and felt good about leveling up. Leveling up just makes everything harder. 3 / 10 . Its not worth the grind and all the time. Very cool game tho. Maybe if it was 10 hours shorter it would be better.

Don't believe the chances that are indicated in % - pure bs)))) Missing, dodging etc is just overwhelming, gunner missing 5 times in a row with the same ability is just a normal run in the dungeon.

Yes, the mechanics of characters, their madness and interaction inside the team and with their own abilities looks great and this is the only thing that hold me for these 6 hours in the game.
However, too much of idiotic negative random cases that really caused me to Alt+F4 the game.

I've had my doubts about this game, around 25 hours in, now when I tried the last dungeon I just deleted the game. The question here is not about difficulty, but just a pure luck situations where there is nothing you can do, example - I enter the room and enemies play first, all four just give everything on my one hero, now my turn, they give me one, and again the turn goes to them, guess what, same thing happens. I just lost a hero that I was working for for a long time. What is my next step........ let's do it all over again. Same dungeons, same enemies, grind, grind, grind, so the next time, enemies will for two rounds beat only one of your heroes. I am 90% convinced that the game is rigged, some situations are just soooooo sus. If there was a percentage based luck, it would be so so different, but instead it is designed so you lose sometimes, and you rage, and you get exited from this??? It took me so much time, just to realize that I am trying different tactics but the game just stays the same, for too long, I noticed that some tasks become like work, and it is not good. I love the art and many other aspects of the game, but the times when you are just watching the game like a TV where there is nothing you can do, kills it. Here is my two weeks notice, I do not enjoy this anymore and I do not want to spend another 50 hours for the same tasks that I did 50 hours earlier

This game is hard, complicated and sometimes bullshit. But it's such a fun and addicting experience all the same. If you aren't a fan of XCOM type games, where a lot of preparation and planning goes into your decisions before you've even started a mission, then this game is NOT for you. Every decision is permanent with auto-save, meaning no save scumming, just living with the consequences of your actions. Whether they be mistakes or wild turns of good fortune. The production value here is top notch, with a wonderfully gothic art style, an exciting yet tense soundtrack that elevates the tension in the battles and a lighting mechanic that incentivizes players to take risks to increase their rewards that is also tied directly to the gameplay difficulty and music tracks. I highly recommend this to people who are okay getting beat down by a game at the start and get a thrill from overcoming a steep learning curve.
This game can be very, very punishing but equally rewarding. Definitely worth in a sale or if you're really into city managment AND tactical rpgs!
Great dark atmosphere, the game is not easy, but that's what I like. Great strategy. Would totally recommend.

The idea and what it's trying to be is so good, but it falls short cause of some truly annoying mechanics. Stress is way to punishing atleast when you first start out, i haven't come past the first 4 missions yet cause i keep having to abandon cause either everyone is to stressed or they are dying/dead. I love the theme, and the idea. If it was COOP and stress was less annoying it could be so good. But wasting my time by killing off or making my characters useless with 10 negative traits is just not fun sadly.

Plan your team, try to compensate for weaknesses and then watch as random illnesses, ailments and insanity pluck your team apart.  This game is not for me and maybe my review can convince and discourage specific people.  The game is not hard, it's unfair.  There are far too many ailments that can 'just happen' to you that will screw your team.  Survive a fight by the skin of your teeth?  Well done, one of your party members is low on life. You can eat, it restores crap amounts of health, no healing items better bring a healer that can only heal you at camp.  I played for four hours and I spent more time cussing and rolling my eyes at random things that happened to screw me that I had no power over whatsoever.  Like my favorite thief deciding to become a kleptomania and stealing everything he saw and there's nothing you can do but survive and hope he gets cursed at town which may or may not happen but also costs you money.  The people that like 'random bad things happening to you' and think that this is difficulty will love this game.  For me this game is actually bullshit.  If I prepare and think and plan I should have some kind of edge.  Not here.  Not my jam.

Pros: art style, voice acting, soundtrack fits the theme, subtitles available, 3 difficulty settings, tutorial available (although it can teach you better with the town upgrades/mechanics which are essential), turn-based combat, you can do a tactical retreat 

Cons: no borderless windowed mode, you have to restart the entire game to implement option changes, no advanced graphical settings, only 9 campaign slots, too small of an inventory system, it’s a stressful game (with stress mechanics, characters gets stressed too fast), tedious torch/light mechanic, characters die too easily even on the easiest difficulty (for some reason they did not add health potions), you can’t move around the mini-map (although you can only zoom in & out) 

Overall, a dark & difficult rogue-like video game. This type of game is not for everybody. You actually have to learn how to retreat from battles, even on the easiest difficulty. As of the writing of this review I have done at least 5 hours of gameplay.
Darkest Dungeon is a hit or miss.

This game is like darksouls difficulty of turned based games, after playing it for hours and fighting the bosses and going into the darkest dungeon, I have felt very challenged. Going on an adventure even with your strongest team and that feeling of will they survive? the tough choices of either leaving the dungeon or pushing forward to risk for the rewards. Yes it was frustrating but fun, I recommend this game it's fun, but in a challenging way if you don't like then it's not for you. Like I said this is Darksouls difficulty. Everything matters, every choice you make will matter if you survive or you don't and that's what I like about this game.
I had a pretty good time with this game until the grind near the end where I gave up. The game really disrespects your time and I don't appreciate that.

This game is quite fun, but it has a major problem: too much grind on higher difficulties or on default settings. Like the fact that you can't take the survivors that won in the darkest dungeon location can't go there anymore, just why?, it adds a lot of boring grind, each of the heroes that won in the darkest dungeon are completely useless now. Fortunately you can disable this dumb feature.

The DLC's are also utter garbage, the new locations (especially farmstead) they add are completely lacking the charm that the main game has. On the farmstead you are just endlessly fighting enemies and it limits the amount of team builds you can do, since you need to keep the stress low and heal constantly. Also why are the battle long buffs not lasting the entire battle, but just a single wave it makes them useless there and highly discouraged to be used, it also furthermore limits the amount of good builds.
The enemies are even worse, the most annoying is propably a minboss that has 80% damage resistant below 40% hp, removes DoT effects from itself and inflicts huge numbers of stress on the team is completly unfair as a semi random encounter, its the best to just avoid it all costs. Farmstead bosses that summon large amounts of enemies and also have self healing are also tortures especially cause you need high survival low damage builds to get to them. The Courtyard is a little bit better as it eases into main game progression better but the enemies are still a bit overtuned.

Overall the base game is quite fun. The graphics are beautiful and the horrorish setting gives a feeling of uneasiness, but the grind that you have to put into it just sucks the enjoyment out of this game.

I don't like this one. Combat stats make no sense. For instance, characters with lower speed often move before those with higher speed. Attacks with an 85% hit chance seem to miss two out of three times. The attack descriptions are so confusing that going through them feels like a chore. The game does very little to explain how the combat mechanics work. I enjoy a good challenging game, but this one is challenging for all the wrong reasons.
The game is really good but keeps crashing on my high-end rig after 10-15min gameplay. Some kind of memory leak? Couldn't find any fix for this so I refunded :(

I don't know guys. It's fun at first, like really fun--but it loses steam toward the end. I think the core issue I had is that as you progress through the game, you get used to the different characters and types of enemies, and the fundamental gameplay starts to feel really repetitive. This makes it feel awful when you wipe with a bunch of level 6 characters in the final dungeon. Now, you have to go through the entire repetitive slog of leveling up characters and collecting items, repeating the same exact gameplay you already did for several hours. Thus, as I started to explore the final dungeon, the game became more tedious and boring instead of becoming more exciting.

At it's core, this is a grindy, repetitive game where you frequently lose a lot of your progress. The formula works great at first because of a noticeable progression as you unlock more cool things, but once the game reveals to you all it has to offer, the repetitiveness starts to catch up.
