Despite the DLC issues presented by the community, the main game's story, the small quests and combination of the mental type mechanics management are quite intricate and unique in a way, that made the game interesting and each hero got their use case scenarios, even if not all of them were viable in the final quest series.

I was in a pretty dark place when I played this back in 2023 (ha, get it, dark – like the dungeons) and I don’t remember much of it but I know this is a good game. I plan to return to it at some point in time once the game is no longer tainted by the memories.

Most of the time spent playing this game is waiting for its repetitive animations to finish. 

As far as the gameplay goes: it is better than most Microsoft Excel spreadsheets, but worse than, for example, doing dishes. I would rather play this game than mop a floor, for example, if it weren't for the fact that after mopping the floor, the floor is at least mopped. 

The setting and storyline of the game is also pretty much about mopping floors, by the way. The plot is that "you" (the protagonist) have to clean up some abandoned ranch that's been in your family for a long time and is now very dirty, full of bugs and fish and stuff. There's a lot of "mechanics" in the way of getting the place cleaned. It is a lot more rewarding to just clean your apartment or house in real life.
That's good game with fun and hot mods. I like visuals, sound and core gameplay, it's simple yet entertaining. Good indie game,

There is a lot mechanically in this game that is just bad design, like why can I only use healing abilities in combat?
I have a healer, but I am supposed to go into my next fight with 3 hp because the dev is a moron. this is exactly the kind of thing that makes people complain about artificial difficultly.
your stats don't matter, I see enemies with 9-35 dodge who we will miss routinely. Meanwhile I can boost my dodge to over 70 and get hit nearly every attack. its really dumb, what is the point in buffing when it has no noticeable effect on performance.
and lets talk about stress, this is a mind blowingly dumb mechanic, on a long mission you might have to do 30 fights, you can reach 100 stress easily in 4-5 enemy attacks. fighting 4 enemies a battle if you take 2 turns to wipe them out 5 attacks come out really quickly, and the AI is not dumb they will target your highest stress character with stress attacks. 
At 100 stress you get a debuff that makes your characters stress their companions every turn and sometimes ignore orders. They will even refuse healing, they are going to die next turn but no, you aren't allowed to do anything about it. or worse they can literally commit suicide mid battle. 
This causes your whole team to quickly stress out, so you have 4 guys all stressing all of their teammates every turn in an infinite death spiral. at 200 stress you just die.
As soon as any character hits 100 stress you have like one battle before the run is over. This is a mostly unavoidable mechanic, as there are basically no ways to reliably reduce stress. There are some abilities that reduce it, but it only really works in low level missions as in missions at your level or above the enemy just out DPS's you.  A good high level stress heal is for like 12 stress on a single unit, most stress attacks do 20, I have seen it hit as high as 45, and may hit many units. not to mention you take stress walking around. your entire team take stress every time you get critical hit(a very common occurance), but only half your team recovers stress when you crit. 
So the only viable strategy is to kill the enemy as quickly as possible, when you out level them significantly this is possible, but at same level or higher it is not. Why you ask? because your level 6 team cannot reliably hit the lv 5 enemies, and even when they do hit them its at very low damage because enemies have armour. So you need to either debuff or blight or bleed them, which is fine except it takes time, and time means stress, which means death spiral.
And then there is food, needing to eat is random(again why, what moron comes up with this?) so you can go an entire dungeon and use no food, or you can be forced to eat 4 times in 4 hallways concurrently. 
And even on missions you do perfectly, you can still get negative debuffs and illnesses at the end of mission, again why? 
What kind of moron dev punishes players for doing good?
The game does have a one more battle charm to it, but all of its mechanics were thought up by a braindead retard.
Incredibly grindy. Starts off fun, but quickly devolves to repetitive "Crawl dungeon, level up, crawl dungeon..."

6/10 Just as your party likely feels in the game, fighting stress and their own demons, you, as a player, will feel the same. You are never safe and powerful enough, and regardless of how much grinding you do, you won’t have a pleasant experience in a dungeon of the same level as your team. Just when you think you’ve found a hero with useful positive traits, you’ll encounter a negative one that you absolutely don’t want. Just when you think the loot is finally worth entering the dungeon, you’ll notice it also brings negative stats. When you think you have enough gold for the desired upgrade, almost all of it will go into the next rationing for the dungeon, stress reduction, disease treatment etc... The game is certainly, alongside enjoyment, a real source of frustration. After about 20 hours of gameplay, I wasn’t able to complete 3 dungeons without taking a break. The game mentally wears you out, both because of the very detailed management and planning later on, and because of the insufficiently rewarding system. That’s not necessarily a bad thing; on the contrary, it’s very well implemented in this kind of a game. However, I was hoping that at least one out of every few dungeons would bring with it, if not more, at least an equal amount of positive and negative things. Random events will soon become a "no click" option because the chances for negative debuffs are much higher than the positive ones. If you want a game where you leave the dungeon with barely enough gold to survive the next one, with many diseases and stress you need to deal with as soon as possible, with loot that will only be useful for you by pure luck, with many upgrades that you’ll stare at for hours, wondering which to choose because of resource lack, etc, give the game a try. The inventory system is another brutally frustrating thing. You’ll often find yourself wondering what to leave behind because, alongside many torches, food, potions, keys, and shovels, you often won’t have enough space for full loot. The graphical design is immersive, and with excellent sound, it builds a great atmosphere. Don’t expect much from the story, nor from the characters, who are nothing more than expendable resources at your disposal. The game offers a lot, but it could have offered more and made the game harder with better mechanics, not through lack of resources, bad loot, and constant battles with diseases and negative effects, but through better AI and stronger opponents. RPG enthusiasts will likely not enjoy this. As a conclusion, I’ll just add, 'you’ll suffer for hours just to make some kind of meaningful and satisfying progress', if you want hardcore experience, go for it.

+ Immersive lovecraftian atmosphere with great graphical design followed by amazing sound and narration
+ Engaging tactical approach and creative party management
+ Great replay value if you find the game interesting

- One of the most stressful and frustrating games with negative rewarding system
- Meaningless characters and forgettable storytelling
- Difficulty is reflected in the constant lack of resources and the struggle with negative effects rather than through combat and more challenging AI

Darkest Dungeon®, developed and published by Red Hook Studios, is a punishing yet profoundly immersive gothic roguelike that redefined the tactical turn-based genre when it first launched. It is a game as much about the toll of psychological trauma as it is about strategic combat, and it wears its Lovecraftian inspiration like a badge of honor. From its haunting narration to its distinctive hand-drawn art style, Darkest Dungeon delivers an unforgettable descent into madness—both literally and figuratively—for players brave (or foolish) enough to explore its depths.

At its core, Darkest Dungeon is a dungeon-crawling experience driven by high-stakes risk-reward mechanics. Players inherit a decaying estate from a deranged ancestor and must recruit, manage, and lead a group of flawed heroes into procedurally generated dungeons to combat horrors both monstrous and mental. However, unlike many other games in the genre, Darkest Dungeon does not romanticize the idea of heroism. Characters suffer. They panic, falter, become afflicted with madness, or even abandon the party mid-fight. Stress plays a central mechanical role, as adventurers accumulate psychological strain through both combat and environmental factors. This system adds a nuanced layer of management, requiring the player to not only monitor health and resources but also the slowly unraveling minds of their party members.

Combat in Darkest Dungeon is turn-based, positionally driven, and surprisingly deep. Each class has unique skills that function differently based on where the character stands in the formation and where the enemy is located. This emphasis on positioning turns every encounter into a delicate dance, especially when a single death or movement-disrupting ability can completely upend a strategy. The roster of classes, from the stalwart Crusader to the plague-slinging Plague Doctor, is diverse and rich with synergy potential, but the game’s ruthless difficulty ensures that even the best-prepared teams can be wiped out in an instant. Permanent death reinforces the stakes, and every venture into the dark feels like a legitimate gamble.

What sets Darkest Dungeon apart is not just its mechanics, but its atmosphere. The art direction is striking—an amalgamation of grim comic book aesthetics and oppressive color palettes that reinforce the game's heavy tone. The sound design is equally memorable. Wayne June’s gravelly narration, filled with foreboding warnings and poetic despair, becomes a near-mythic presence throughout the game. His commentary reacts dynamically to your actions, lending weight to every success and especially to every failure. The soundtrack, composed by Stuart Chatwood, complements the game perfectly, ebbing and flowing with dread, melancholy, and occasional triumph. Together, these elements make Darkest Dungeon not just a game, but a mood, a slow-building pressure cooker of tension and ruin.

The metagame of managing the Hamlet—the player’s home base—is a vital counterbalance to the chaos of dungeon expeditions. It offers various facilities to reduce stress, cure diseases, treat quirks, and upgrade equipment. The loop of recruiting new heroes, equipping them, and cycling them through missions while trying to preserve the sanity of your best units creates a compelling rhythm. However, success is hard-won. Resources are limited, progress is slow, and the game is unafraid to punish overconfidence. Even after dozens of hours, the game retains its challenge and mystery, especially when tackling the endgame dungeons or attempting to complete the infamous Darkest Dungeon itself—a place where even high-level teams may not return.

It's worth mentioning that Darkest Dungeon is not a game for everyone. Its brutal difficulty, deliberate pacing, and psychologically taxing mechanics can feel overwhelming or even unfair. RNG plays a significant role, and the game often embraces suffering as a mechanic rather than an obstacle to overcome. For some, this will feel empowering—a raw and honest portrayal of desperation and survival. For others, it might feel too masochistic or frustrating. Yet for those who embrace the darkness and learn to adapt, there's a uniquely rewarding experience buried beneath the madness.

Red Hook Studios continued to support Darkest Dungeon after release with several DLCs, such as The Crimson Court, The Shieldbreaker, and The Color of Madness, each adding new layers of depth, mechanics, and narrative flavor. These expansions further cement the game's reputation as a complex and evolving journey. With the sequel now in the wild, the original remains a masterclass in atmosphere, tension, and systemic storytelling. It's a game that doesn't just test your skills—it tests your patience, resilience, and ability to find hope in the bleakest of places.

In conclusion, Darkest Dungeon is a towering achievement in indie game design. It is merciless, often cruel, but deeply artistic and philosophically rich. It explores themes rarely touched by other games, such as fear, obsession, and the crushing burden of leadership. For players willing to suffer through its trials, it offers a uniquely cathartic and unforgettable journey. It doesn’t just challenge your characters—it challenges you. And that’s what makes it great.

Combat is simple turn based rpg style where position matters more than anything, unless you're an enemy. Enemys can be anywhere at any time and use any ability they want to devastate your team. you have to be in a specific standing point to use a certain move one turn, then change your position wasting another turn to use a separate move. 3 turns to use 2 moves after your first set up your third move. by turn 3 you've been crit by 5 hits. 

The combat RNG isn't RNG. 85/90% accuracy? you're going to miss more than 50% of the time. Enemy accuracy? 90% with a 50% chance of crit. 

Do not play this game, do not waste your life or money on this trash. Bottom tier RPG go play any other RPG

Game has a lot of good things going for it, but it deserves the downvote due to how lazily the stress system is implemented in this game.

It's a good concept but poorly implemented and obviously not tested. You can use items to reduce stress, camp, and use skills in combat to mitigate but it only takes one battle and RNG on if your party loses a surprise roll to undo all mitigation and compound much worse.

For example, a completely upgraded skill that's dedicated towards stress wastes that units turn and will remove 7-10 stress. This is late game values. 

Where as a single common enemy unit can apply 15+ stress to every unit as just an additional perk to a damaging attack. On top of that your units will lose a virtue roll and then cause +15 stress to their entire team essentially every turn. There's no items to counteract this level of compounding even if you use a campfire and dedicate all your skills to de-stressing. 

This is another game where dev's threw a new mechanic as a selling point to being different but didn't put much that into after that. A game is challenging if you have agency as a player to circumvent these problems if you respect it enough, you can't do that here it's just an RNG dice roll that you'll sometimes lose. If a mechanic only relies on RNG for you to pass it's not a challenge it's gambling. I beat the game because I do like rogue likes and i'm going to get my money's worth but if I could go back in time I would choose something else.

I recognized stress is the biggest challenge in the game early and built comps around one shotting key units that apply stress along with the appropriate skills and items. So there are runs you can get absolutely 0 stress. But it literally takes one battle from trash fodder mobs to completely devalue all of your efforts. By then it doesn't matter if you cleared 80% of the dungeon with plenty of supplies and HP, you have to abandon the entire run. It's stuff like that where even if I enjoy something 80% of the time that 20% slap in the face makes me want to not endorse this.

Triumphant pride precipitates a dizzying fall.

And I'm always saying that.

Not a bad game, but not going to lie, I am not having fun.
You need to invest time in learning mechanics and strategies just to survive. While it is probably what the target niche is looking for in this game, for me it is too tedious to be enjoyable. 
Many other games are way more fan with less of the effort.

This game is hard, but not in an "RNG bullshit!" kinda hard, not a "Deeply tactically challenging" type of hard, just a grind. It's not bad, I'm more than ready to put a few more sessions of play to try and progres, but holyy shitt does the progression feel slow.

People will defend the game saying that the slow progression is intended, and while I might be inclined to agree I think it is still deeply punishing for newer players that might be trying to take a gander at turn based combat. (I'm newer players lol.) 

First thing I tried was mitigating risks by avoiding doing the hardest shit with my best heroes, but this stalls the gameplay loop into a harsh repetitive nature, so obviously I try to avoid that.
Second thing I tried was having a diverse lineup of heroes in order to enjoy some better variety, but then you're gridlocked into the early-midgame, and gridlocked out of many many deeply impactful trinkets that might make or break some types of playstyles
If you try to wait it out for those super impactful trinkets, or maybe you get your hands on one early game, then you'd obviously want to use that hero more often than the others for the sake of actually enjoying the benefits of such a playstyle. Soon enough that hero reaches levels that you actually enjoy playing in! Afterwards, you end up with a near permanent chore of leveling shittier heroes into a more enjoyable state.

The consistency of somewhere around +20 30 accuracy from tinkets, on top of the GUILD UPGRADES providing a lot more accuracy/effectiveness aswell, all lead to the upper crust of heroes playing much more consistently, and therefor much more enjoyably in a game that people may call bullshit on for being too RNG dependent.

I used accuracy for an example but most of the mechanics that some heroes capabilities lean on will be dependent on their higher capabilities. Trying to claw your way out of being forced to level up 2-3 veterancy heroes for the capability to actually use them on missions you care about, with loadouts that are infinitely more diverse and capable, is simply not that great.

Saying "Just upgrade the wagon!" doesn't stop the fact I need the guild hall to make higher veterancy worth it. Not to mention the blacksmith which adds more strength in terms of health and damage at a base. No matter what, to avoid the grind for the most part you need to reach a point in progression where nearly the whole town is able to uphold a meat grinder. Hiring new heroes is definitely a good prospect, but it sure is expensive getting their gear and skills in check!

This is all without mentioning the quirk system, where many negative quirks or sicknesses can be deeply annoying to deal with when mixed with all the already stated reasons above: *Another* cost that needs a remedy, more time that good heroes stay away from the field, a grind that tells you to go fix up some B tiers for a while until you get back to an actually enjoyable team composition.

Lowkey, I don't actually know how they could fix this game, plus they released a sequel so obviously I'm not exactly expecting an update that remedies any of this. If you enjoy the game as is I fully understand why (especially if you can enjoy the aesthetics and pace of combat for like 60+ hours?) But genuinely, this game will not be for everyone. It has a much thicker filter than others I've tried.

Good idea, too many menu's to click, very convoluted. Got annoyed by micromanagement pretty quickly because you keep going to have to go back to the main screen, the into another screen, then back to the main screen, etc.

I really wanted to like this game. BUT EVERY STEP IS TEDIOUS, and I don't mean the battles. I am talking about UI, what to click, making sense of items, constant popups, crappy instructions, and nonsensical controls...

When the difficulty curve for late game is if your character will lose their minds or chad up. 

RNG being the decider in a turn based combat game based on tactical decisions learned from 'faliure' is just begging for frustration and unfun realizations. 

'Oh, the knight who is supposed to tank hits and dish out damage is the first one to fold under the SLIGHTEST unholy chant'

'Ah, the ranged damage dealer keeps missing every hit and crit even though I've built them SPECIFICALLY for that job'

'Oh, the healer and stunner is being tossed around and stunned like a sack o taters even though I've built her SPECIFICALLY NOT TO DO THAT'

'ah, the bounty hunter who is supposed to make sure the enemy is either stunned or dead CANNOT STUN OR KILL the enemy due to them losing their minds and deciding to hit the healer TRYING TO HEAL THEM'

These are a very small amount of the realizations I've come to have in the heat of battle against foes my roster is specifically meant to beat, has beat and was expected to beat but the game specifically decided that only certain situations are things actually gonna work out. Why? BECAUSE RNG.

Took me a while to figure out what was pissing me off so much. It's that this game: through all it's in depth game play mechanics and party build systems, EVERYTHING is chance based and you should expect EVERYTHING to go wrong at the specific time that you desperately need it to go right.

Its a great game, but for whatever reason the mouse input just doesnt properly work. I have to click everything multiple times and pray for it to register. Its the only programme that has this issue, so its certainly not my mouse.

I want to like this game. I really do. I gave it many chances since everything is good here: The gameplay formula, the music, the art design, Wayne June's voice acting... 

Everything, but the core game mechanic. Games' core is built on such random that at one point you realize that almost nothing depends on you. The only thing you do is roll the roulette's wheel that is masked under all the buttons and options. And if you think that i'm exagerrating - I'm not.

Just two examples of what happened to me, one right after another:
My level 4 squad was entirely wiped by 3 spiders with 24 dodge. None of my character could hit them because every their attack was either a miss or dodged. Meanwhile the spiders were stunlocking my characters and constantly dealing crit damage while stacking blight. 4 characters gone with all their trinkets. And it was like... second or third room into the raid.

But okay, i'm not the one who is scared of losing. I gathered another squad from my other characters of the same level and embarked into the boss' dungeon. It was the The Prophet this time. I reached the boss just fine, almost no damage, no stress...
Can you guess that happens next? Yep, boss wiped 3 out of 4 chars in my squad with crits and immediate deathblows at, like, 4th turn. And THEN my 0 hp hellion, while tanking literally ALL damage with her death's door... Solo killed the prophet with Iron swan spam. Yeah, i won, but all the other characters are gone, time spent on grind is gone. Loot is gone since i'm forced to pick if i want to take valuable trinkets home or loot i collected.

Also funny thing that happened to those who died: My grave robber who had 54 dodge haven't dodged a singe attack in the whole raid while my musketeer with dodge 1 managed to dodge 3 attacks in the row during one of the fights.

Do you understand how random this game is? Again, don't get me wrong: I like challenge. But there's no challenge, just your luck.

Absurd game that is 100% luck. You will constantly miss your attacks while the enemies very rarely do. Anytime you actually hit the enemy, it feels like a grace from God. When it says 85% accuracy and you miss three straight times, it's simply nonsense.

This game has an unbalanced hardcore mode. It's impossible to reduce the chance of defeat to zero :/
Two hits from the Pig king, two stuns from Wilbur, while you can't escape the fight – you lose your entire team and top accessories for the Reserve and the Prince. Even though the accessories were chosen based on the enemies' weaknesses and the best for their heroes.
After such a defeat, completing the game in 86 weeks is unrealistic. Because you'll have to recruit and re-level the same characters to level six and get top accessories. There's simply no time for that. 86 is barely enough to complete the game without a single defeat (18 bosses + about 36 raids to prepare locations + time for quests in the Darkest Dungeon + time to level all characters to level six...). Autosave is limited to one slot. There's no way to rewind time. Such a poor setup for random game...
The bottom line: a loss of about 50 hours due to a critical failure.
How shitty it was to find out that the skill in this game doesn't work after 80 hours!!

So, for those planning to beat the game on the hardest difficulty, even if you assemble the best team with the best accessories against the Boss Pig, there's about a 10% chance you'll have to start the game over ;)

Also, the player isn't given a bestiary of bosses upon completion, so a newbie will never know what kind of enemy awaits them. Ignorance is death! Either memorize the stats and replay the game, or sit with the WIKI on your lap.

Spoiler!!!: the best tactic for winning is to perform namaz or pray for the dice to land on the right side. Sacrifice to Cthulhu: +5% stun resistance)
really good game super punishing but really fun

Not really recommend this game, 80% of it is RnG, no matter how good your character is chances are or maybe your strategies it doesn't matter you'll still be easily lose due to the shit ass RnG. Much more like a gamble, didn't recommend at all unless you really love to get dopamine from gamble
Most stupid silly little game I know. Can't pass the first room. Heroe dies before I can even give a hit. Nobody can hit. What's the point...

Is it a good game? Yes, especially with the ability for it to work with mods to customize or fix interactions (looking at you monster class that doesn't work otherwise).

Is it a fun game?......not really it's like a D&D campaign with a dice that's weighted to give you the absolutely worst outcomes to make things annoying. Bad and good traits are weighted more to the most annoying traits, accuracy for the player is everything is Focus Blast, and its just a constant fight to stay above water.

Personally I can't find it fun without playing in short runs, and heavily modded. So I can't myself recommend it, but if you've got patience go for it.

I like this game a lot. 

Strategy elements are nice to figure out, artistically it looks great, and there is plenty of events and interactions that add variety.
Relying heavily on grinding and cruel rng i okay, for about 90% of the game where there is progress to be made at all the time. I have a big issue with endgame, I've maxed out everything there is to max out, seen everything there is to see, except of the final location. I have took quite a few attempts at these missions, losing almost every time, the game forced me to just go back to previous missions and level up new characters, and then again and again, and the big risk, big reward mindset was thrown out the window, as there was no more any rewards. 

I quit playing this game back then. Came back last week. After playing for 20 hours I am still in the very same place as I was before. Once I almost won this damn mission, but got one of my characters oneshot by a critical + blight and entire house of cards fell apart. I give up. I loved this game, but I've got better things to do than farming mindlessly for hours just to beat it for myself.

TBH was intrigued from the beginning but it took a second for this game to fully click. But once it did...I don't write reviews for games but I did for this one. This game has a lot to learn but the pay off is super satisfying and I'm still figuring stuff out every time I play.

I quiet like the game,  I like the vibes , threw a couple of runs at the start .enjoyed the combat and all that so I got all the DLC . Then I found out that it has multiplayer achievements and not just a few achievements you can get over the weekend , thats looking at hundreds of battles on multiplayer and even very specific and rng dependent ones ON MULTIPLAYER . I cannot recomand a single player focused game like this with this much multiplayer achievements attached to it . If you dont care about achievements or multiplayer then this game is good but for me its a no and has drained my motivation to play it as well unfortunately

I really liked the atmosphere and the story, but after 10 hours the game feels like it would take ages to complete. You have to grind a lot if you want to improve your chances. Every battle you have to wait for slow animations without any setting to speed it all up. I don't have all the time in the world, man. Didn't like that I cannot see the order of turns for the heroes and the enemies, the damage that enemies deal, can't save the game etc. Also the game lacks clarity of how everything works

In short, this game provides some fun but is anger-inducing and frustrating.  Most dynamics in this game revolve random rolls (e.g., hitting, dodging, disarming traps, etc.) compared to a chance to do these things.  With the actions that you can perform, you see the percent chance of success.  However, the system clearly modifies the chances behind-the-scenes.  You can devote a hero entirely to debuffing an enemy, stacking up accuracy debuffs, but yet the enemy will still hit you regularly.  If you have insanely high dodge, the enemy will still hit you regularly.  You can have 90% chance to disarm a trap, but still fail multiple times in a row.  Things happen regularly that are statistically unrealistic.  For a game that is essentially always on ironman mode, where almost every choice matters, this kind of covert fudging is unacceptable, at least to me.
Pile of rng grind fest garbage with the power to send a keyboard through your screen at mach 12, genuinely hate this game and i hope the developer receives bamboo shoot fingernails. FUCK this game

I thought I quite liked the way this game played out and handled itself, but after 30 hours and trying to do the grind to level up to even try the earliest objectives, its just too much for me. I understand that there are a chunk of players that like doing the same thing over and over to earn the prestige of just getting through by following guides perfectly and banging their heads into the wall for as long as it takes... but if you just like enjoyable rpg elements that have a nice linear challenge, you wont find it here. If you enjoy tedium to feel accomplished rather than just playing a game, then you may like this. After trying to enjoy the grind and getting a hands on feel for the game, the party members, and the rollouts; I just dont care for feeling like im getting nowhere because missing attacks and getting quadruple hit by debuffs, maladies, damage, and sanity loss that all need to be resource fixed while redoing levels with lvl 1 characters in the mean time while trying to grind for little amounts of resources to upgrade heroes as you go... just too much to enjoy the game as a great game.  
Cheers to all who think this is great, but it only seems to be meant for masochists and people who dont enjoy their time outside of pretending that their gaming efforts mean something as if theyre a streamer or something lol. Thats so little of the gaming community. Watch someone cram all that effort into a video if you wanna know how this game goes, or be ready to just stop giving a shit unless you need to look up how to power through instead of finding a payoff for your time, money, or energy.  
Its great, but it expects soooo much for a hardcore indy game. But if youre here, you mostly know whats going on. Just dont expect to enjoy yourself by being challenged. The challenge is over saturated for relatively small amount of what is going on. Get ready to grind to level 6 over hundreds of hours on so many characters, as slow as possible, to imagine youre doing something worthwhile at this point.  
If you can play for free, its a good chunk of hours to see what its like... if you wanna see things to the end, then be prepared to do an empty grind and hoping for RNGs best efforts to keep you feeling rewarded. Otherwise, find the tenacity to care enough to finish an eventually empty endeavor. Or pretend its worth your time: its all up to you and what youre willing to give up for likely meager personal reward. Or resolve to believe it means something to you.  You can love it, but youre trusting the slim systems to be on your side more often than not, which is the antithesis to the games design. Good Luck to you if so.

I really wanted to finish the game once before reviewing it, but fuck the sunk cost, because this is a miserable game experience that quickly grows stale after, at best, the first 3-4 runs in each of the dungeon maps.
Fake difficulty, and meaningless upgrades that never actually make you feel any stronger. They could literally just remove the upgrades entirely and simply add new enemies as you progress and the game would be the exact same. The skill and equipment upgrades are only there so you can't make a steady progression, and instead have to spend hours grinding dungeons to get the gold and upgrade materials needed. And guess what? Guess fucking what? Nothing changes. The enemies scale right back up to counter your increased HP and DMG. The bonus ACC you got from your skill? Now the enemy has 30 dodge, so good fucking luck.
There is no bigger waste of time that I have had from playing Darkest Dungeon. I really was expecting a difficult but ultimately rewarding experience, instead I got a slow, meaningless grind that only left me wishing that I could hurry up and get the all upgrades I needed to challenge the final dungeons, but I'm not wasting my time anymore with this shit.
If you enjoy missing what is a supposed 80% hit chance five times in a row, meanwhile receiving 3 crits from the enemy back-to-back, then this is the game for you, you sad sack of shit.

The light is a lie. Hope flickers, fragile and false, barely shielding your heroes from the inevitable. They pray, they fight, they bleed... and still they die, because in this place, faith and effort are never enough. Ruin hwill come to your family, and it spreads like a curse, one that no blade or blessing can stop.

Plans offer little comfort here. Nothing in Darkest Dungeon unfolds the way it should. A single crit might lift you from the edge or cast you straight into it. Healers fail when you need them most, torches burn low, and death waits, quiet and polite, around every corner.
Even triumph feels like a mistake, an oversight the dungeon will soon correct. And when defeat comes, as it always does, it arrives not with shock, but with cruel familiarity. 

There can be no hope in this hell... no hope at all.

Good roguelike turn-based role-playing game!
7/10

+ Great visual style.
+ Great music and sound effects.
+ Great voice acting.
+ Great dark fantasy atmosphere.
+ Good storyline.
± Hardcore gameplay.
+ Good turn-based combat.
+ Lots of heroes, enemies and artifacts.

- Bad game balance (even on easy difficulty, some enemies will take multiple turns out of turn, and enemies will often focus on just one hero and kill him quickly).
- Hellish random (victory does not depend on your skill or hero characteristics, but on chance, who will be luckier, you or your enemy, who will be the first to do a critical hit, who will miss, etc.).

If you like pain and suffering, this game is for you!

The biggest selling point of this game is the art (the writing, the visual art, and the voice acting)... but the quality of the art crashes dramatically as you get later into the game.

I feel cheated, to be honest... because if the art had sucked in the first two hours of the campaign, then at least I could have gotten a refund!

One of the best RPGs I've ever played. The campaign is long but so rewarding. It forces you to plan ahead, and really take the overall well-being of your heroes into consideration. Losing a high level hero is a crushing blow, so every action counts. It's brutally hard, and I love it.

The game is good, challenging and charming... that is until the screen doesn't flicker constantly, like, REALLY bad flickering. My game is always flickering when left-clicking onto a hero. in a dungeon, just walking sometimes, more frequently in the dark, the screen starts flickering by itself.

Now, some images like the Mission Success, the hero preview and hit animations were plain white images. Then, a few minutes later, the game crashes but doesn't close by itself, ALT+F4 wasn't working nor was the Task Manager appearing. Like my screen just frooze, but no, just the game being funny with me... Needs an update for these bugs, which does make it sort of unplayeable (is that how it's spelled?) since, well, took me one mission before the crashed.

Can't say much about the game itself, couldn't have an honest experience yet, I'm just reviewing to report the game state.

i love strategy games and extremely HARD games. This one is easily the hardest most RNG luck of the Gods game I've ever played. It's so hard that it's frustrating to play most times since your whole team of 4 has a chance to miss or have their attacks dodged for multiple turns in a row. I usually can tolerate RNG bologna, but the entire game favors against you.

The biggest problem I have, is that even when you think you've got an advantage or enough supplies, you never actually do and instead of the game helping you get back on track, once you hit a downward spiral, it just gets worse each time you try to complete a quest. For example, I won my first 3-4 quests, then had terrible RNG on the next two. Those two runs depleted my resources so quickly, that now, even at the easiest difficulty, I have no resources and can only go into quests naked. Sure I can abandon the quest once I find items, but then my team gets no resolve and I have to spend a big portion of the resources I obtained abandoning quests on alleviating the stress of the team. 

Eventually I'll come back and hopefully have a better understanding of the mechanics, but after 5 hours of gameplay, it seems the core appreciation of this game is how blatantly BS the resource loop is.

Git gud or whatever but for now this shit is trash in my humble opinion

Shite.

Unbalanced Slop. RNG af.

Nothing beats losing hours of progress because the game just decides "Lol, you don't need to live anymore"

Nothing beats wasting valuable resources only to not use/need them so you don't bring them with you only to then need *twice as many as you bought* in the next dungeon run.

Nothing beats witnessing a character who was previously swamping enemies with no problem become a blubbering and worthless mess in 2 turns of combat because, once again, "Lol, RNG says no".

Nothing beats the, totally 100% Obvious and transparent "insanity" system that 100% Tells you everything you need to know about it and definitely *doesn't* rely on the player to look up guides to figure out how to reduce/negate it.

Nothing beats wasting money on Town upgrades only to find out that that's apparently one of the worst things to buy right away and apparently you should just spam the stagecoach until it's 100% (Very intuitive design there fellas).

Nothing beats having to waste time running low level characters and grinding them out just to wait for 2 main members of your core party to get out of Rehab or take a break from catching STD's (That are totally useful, trust me guys) just so you can spend all the money you just earned grinding out slop ass low level chars to *put the other 2 members from the core party into wherever the f*ck they want to go.

I get the devs wanted to make a challenging game.

But this isn't challenge.

It is a Pachinko machine with *some form* of team synergy that gets completely negated by RNG Dice Roll combat that *heavily* favors the enemy AI.

Don't buy it on sale. If a friend gifts you it, send it back.

Don't believe a single positive thing anyone says about this garbage because these people are sadists that enjoy *not having fun*.

Sure the art style and music are good, but this is a f*cking game. Not a concert.

It's just not fun.

If you enjoy this, call the Emergency Services of whatever country you are in and tell them you need to be sectioned. You *are* having a schizophrenic episode.

Inb4: "lol skill issue" What f*cking skill? The game is a basic aah turn based combat game with pretty basic characters and skill selection. If I need to exploit these chars and their skills to beat it then then that'#s just inheritly bad design. why the F*ck would I waste my time? Might as well just whip out the console commands and cheat to the fucking end credits.

Darkest Dungeon isn’t a game about being a hero; it’s about managing a group of flawed, stressed-out people trying not to collapse in a hole. The art style is striking, the turn-based combat is punishing but fair, and the narrator’s voice is iconic.

The highlights:
The Stress System: Watching your favorite Crusader develop a gambling addiction or go paranoid adds a layer of strategy you won't find in other RPGs.

The Vibe: It perfectly nails the "Lovecraftian horror" atmosphere.

Risk vs. Reward: You have to know when to push forward for loot and when to retreat to save your team.

It’s brutal and you will lose people you like, but every victory feels earned.
Lots of replay value and great writing. If you like the macabre and the gothic and you're not afraid of losing your adventurers to streaky bad luck, then this is worth a playthrough.

RNG is absolutely unfair. It's like as if I'm missing something in this game. How could my 80% trap disarm chanced hero gets squeezed 3 times in a row? How can a single mob always crits me and I'm only hitting doges or misses. Why do you hate us this much?

Absolutes Meisterwerk meiner Meinung nach. Ein herausforderndes Spiel, das sowohl durch seinen einzigartigen Artstyle als auch durch das Kampfsystem stark heraussticht. Man muss ständig damit rechnen, dass man mit einem eigentlich gut zusammengestellten Team einen Run startet und trotzdem von einer Sekunde auf die andere auseinandergenommen wird xD Man muss nämlich nicht nur auf die HP sondern auch auf das Stresslevel der Charaktere achten, ansonsten hat man ein Problem - oder auch nicht, denn Stress kann sich möglicherweise auch positiv auf den Character auswirken. Nach jedem abgeschlossenen Dungeon haben Charaktere die Chance, Quirks zu bekommen die entweder vorteilhaft oder schlecht für Kämpfe oder das Erkunden der Dungeons sein können. Wenn man rundenbasierte Kämpfe und Herausforderungen liebt, dann sollte man unbedingt dieses Spiel gespielt haben. :)

Often negative reviews are poorly written whinge-fests, from miniscule gripes with the placement of a single icon on a toolbar; to the other extreme of decrying the installation of 3rd party launch-ware. Neither of which actually get as far as reviewing the game. 

However .... many of the negative reviews for Darkest Dungeon are actually right on the money. 
Tone, setting, art design, notional game mechanics and especially the narration / VO work. All good. 

But then the flip side is that the game is so unbelieveably grindy AND ... when you think you've built up some momentum, you try your first level 5 mini boss you wipe so comprehensively, losing stuff and people in the process, and watch a good many hours vanish like Keyser-Bloomin-Soze. 
And that's not even feeling like you're on the home straight. 
Or you even know where the home straight is. 

No-one expects to win every battle. But there shouldn't be a need to grind another 8 hours just to get to that battle again and wonder what you did wrong the last time. Because more often than not you didn't do anything wrong, it's just 'luck'. 
That's not good game design that's just lame.   

Because this is marathon after marathon after marathon. And it never changes into a Snickers. 
Only onion. 
Remember that bit in the film The Dictator when Nadal says to Aladeen, he is like an onion... 
... Darkest Dungeon is the onion. 

And to top it all off, this is on easy setting. 
It's not that the game is difficult, it's just that shizzle happens that you cannot mitigate for. 
So what's the point?
That's not difficult, that's just being a [[insert expletive]]. Game designers we're looking at you. 

On one very short run through my starting two heroes got killed before I even reached the Hamlet. 
I kid you not. What is the point in that?
Is there anything I could have done differently? 
No. 
Sooooooo.... what's the point?
If that happens without any poor choices made on the part of the player then there is something fundamentally wrong with the game design. 

Having completed Slay the Spire on lvl 20 ascension, FTL on hard and X-com on hardest, I still go back to those games to play. Because they are fun. 

Darkest Dungeon is not fun. Time invested does not equal reward. 
The disclaimer at the start of the game that heroes will die ... blah blah blah ... doesn't negate the fact that the game is time sink hole. 
And it doesn't feel like a fun sinkhole. 
It's an onion.

Darkest Dungeon could have been a reasonably good turn based strategy but it isn't. 
It's incredibly flawed by the repetitive (and dare I say it) conceited time-wasting design.
Top 50 games of all time? 
You're havin' a laugh!
Only for those people who have only played a maximum of 49 other games.

A masochistic game charading as difficulty. Spend all your money on supplies, go for an easy quest - heroes miss half their attacks as enemies dodge and hit you back with all kinds of status effects. Lose your best party members, abandon quest. Start from the ground up with new heroes. Rinse repeat.

I got this on a big sale a while ago (it's -85% off right now too), and I just had it sitting in my library for a while before finally giving it a try.  I'm only a couple hours in, but I have to say I'm enjoying this one immensely.  I'm genuinely surprised, because while I love the idea and the gameplay loop of these types of games, and have enjoyed a bit of Slay the Spire and Monster Train, for example, those others never quite hit right for me.  Slay the Spire just really bores me, personally, and Monster Train is kinda similar in that I just feel like I'm doing the same thing over and over.  In Darkest Dungeon, having to wok on your soldiers' stress levels, upgrade skills, upgrade equipment, hire new soldiers, etc., just adds so much for me that the other similar games are missing (once again, for me personally).  Sometimes your best troop is super stressed so you have to take your #2 tank or something, and sometimes you lose a team member, and they're perma-dead (I didn't realize you could retreat until after my first death haha).  The team management and town upgrading just adds so much compared to the other similar games I've played.  Also, the different dungeon types having different monsters so different strategies/team compositions will work better in different dungeons, is a huge plus.

I haven't tried any of the DLCs, but they're all on sale for -75% off now too, and I'm sure will be again since I got the base game on sale a few months ago and it is already on sale again now.  Anyway, as I write this the game is on sale for $3.74 so it's less than a XL cup of coffee.  You basically can't go wrong at that point ($3.74 for a game with 126.6k reviews "Very Positive"), and even at the full price of $25 I'd think this one is probably worth it for anyone who enjoys these types of games.

Playing this game is like walking on lego pieces and shattered glass with no shoes on. The heroes look and act tough but in reality they die very easily to any enemy and are vulnerable to every status effect in the game; bleed, blight, stress you name it. Their skills usually deal chip damage to every enemy unless it is critical attack, which is extremely rare for your hero to do. What to expect from this game:
- Good sound effects
- Amazing narration
- Memorable soundtrack
- Sudden deaths of heroes
- Traps with no way to stop them
- Retreating from battle to randomly fail
- Your heroes sometimes working against you
- Plenty of frustration, low fun factor
- Hours of grinding so your heroes stand the slightest chance
- Mindless trial and error as to which hero works best in which dungeon
- Dead bodies of enemies getting in the way of your melee heroes
- Enemies getting an extra turn
- Fanbase deflecting criticisms with "heheheheheheh" because they're stupid and pathetic
- Refunding this game is unlikely because it requires a lot of playtime at the start

The game was on sale for 2 bucks, I watched my friend play it all the time, but never realized just how criminally unfun and misleading the opening two hours of the game are. My review is probably biased but... that's what a review is. I probably am being mislead by not getting too far, but if the opening was that annoying, I didn't want to waste the 2 hours I have while I still could refund.

I really like games that "Don't hold back" and are "Meant to be hard", but this is just not a good spin on either of those in my eyes. I feel like if I knew what to do I wouldn't have such a hard time but, it doesn't teach you what to do not like other major "Meant to be hard" games that is. Dark Souls is a prime example: its hard but every failure is your own. In DD, it seems that you have to rely on constant RNG to build up a team's gear and pray they don't get a bad . As my friend puts it "you have to prepare for everything to go wrong", to which I claim that you CANT prepare for half of it. 

DS, Touhou Project, DMC (in DMD modes), Terraria Calamity Mod, Geometry Dash - and so many more difficult series or games I find myself enjoying - are MUCH better at being "unforgiving and still fun".

Overall, Darkest Dungeon is messy, I could spend the 2 whole dollars - plus 5 for the DLC - on something that actually brings joy and entertainment instead of a Reddit Indieslop game dependent on almost entirely RNG.

It's been five years since I last played Darkest Dungeon, and every time I glance at my Steam library, I'm confused seeing 295 hours logged while I remember almost nothing of the story or its impact. All that sticks with me is the endless hassle of resource management, the overwhelming fear of losing a hero, and the laborious process of rebuilding a team which is the true horror of this game.

It was a wack cycle of loss. Each time a high level hero fell, it wasn't just another defeat; it was a jarring reminder of the tedious grind ahead. The dread of having to rebuild my team from scratch overshadowed any fleeting moments of atmosphere or storytelling that might have been there.

In the end, Darkest Dungeon became less about its eerie lore & Atmosphere and more about the relentless grind that drained every bit of enjoyment out of my playthroughs. Nearly 300 hours and 5 years later, the only memories that remain are the burdensome RNG and the unyielding stress of its broken resource management.

Reviewing (mostly) every game (or DLC) in my library, part 139:

⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️☆☆ (8/10)

[i] Darkest Dungeon[/i] is a brutal, unrelenting, and psychologically punishing dungeon crawler that somehow makes suffering feel rewarding. You lead a rotating roster of flawed heroes into plague-ridden ruins, cursed forests, and ancient crypts—all in service of cleansing your family estate of its Lovecraftian rot. But here’s the catch: the real enemy isn’t the monsters. It’s despair.

What makes [i]Darkest Dungeon [/i]special is how well it integrates mental strain into its mechanics. You’re managing health bars, yes, but you’re also managing fear, stress, madness, and trauma. Every torch that flickers out, every trap you fail to disarm, every ally that breaks ... chips away at your team’s sanity.

It’s cruel. It’s beautiful. It’s genius. [i]Darkest Dungeon[/i] is the rare game that fully commits to its thesis: adventuring is hell, and it breaks people. But if you embrace the darkness—if you can handle losing your best healer to a heart attack mid-boss fight—you’ll find a deeply rewarding experience. Every little victory feels earned, and every torch-lit step into the abyss unforgettable.

🤯[b] Pros:[/b]
[list]
[*] Innovative stress system. Not only do characters take damage, but they also suffer from stress, develop phobias, lash out at allies, or spiral into hopelessness. 

[*] Tense, turn-based combat. Positioning matters. The combat system is deep and tactical, with turn order, team synergy, and formation all playing critical roles. You’ll agonize over each decision—attack now or heal? Shuffle positions or protect the squishy hero? It’s slow-burn, edge-of-your-seat stuff.

[*] Grim, unforgettable art style. Heavily inked lines, bold reds and blacks, and gothic animation make every moment look like a page from a cursed comic book. Each hero class is visually distinct, and the enemy designs—from swine abominations to cosmic horrors—are deliciously grotesque.

[*] Narration to die for. Wayne June’s voice acting is iconic. His deep, apocalyptic narration is your constant companion, reacting to crits, deaths, discoveries, and defeats with poetic dread. Lines like “Remind yourself that overconfidence is a slow and insidious killer” become mantras.

[*] Meaningful town management. Between expeditions, you manage the Hamlet: sending heroes to the sanitarium, tavern, or abbey to recover. Choosing who gets treated, who gets upgraded, and who gets benched adds another layer of strategic weight. Everything costs gold, and your best soldiers may be out of commission just when you need them.

[*] Replayable and customizable. No two runs are the same. With different hero classes, quirks, trinkets, and dungeon layouts, each campaign plays out differently. You can also modify the difficulty, use mods, and take on challenge modes like Stygian or the endless Darkest level.

[*] Embraces loss as part of the story. Heroes will die. That’s the point. It’s about learning to live with failure, to rebuild after loss, and to keep going even when the game is actively kicking you down. The emotional highs only work because of the crushing lows.
[/list]

🔦[b] Cons:[/b]
[list]
[*] Grinding can be slow. Especially later in the game, progression can stall without a fair bit of grinding. Repeating missions for money or heirlooms might feel tedious after a while, especially if RNG punishes you repeatedly.

[*] RNG can feel cruel, not fair. Missing a 90% stun, getting crit three times in a row, or watching your tank suffer a heart attack out of nowhere can feel unfair. 

[*] Combat is slow-paced. Every fight is deliberate and lengthy. That’s by design, but if you’re someone who prefers snappy turn-based combat, this might test your patience.

[*] Story is atmospheric, not character-driven. Don’t expect party banter or branching arcs. The story is told through setting, item descriptions, and narration, not dialogue or cutscenes. The mood is rich, but the plot is minimal.
[/list]
[hr]
If you enjoyed this review, please check out my curator page to find more: [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/45814768-Verdict-Play-or-Pass/]Verdict: Play or Pass. [/url] Also, please leave a like and visit [url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/Indie_Gems]IndieGems[/url] and our YouTube channel for more reviews like this one. 
[/hr]

I am going to continue playing this game but I feel like it requires too many out of game guides, tutorials and wiki pages to explain the actual mechanics of things.  The game could use a lot more small reminders like when going to do a quest it can list the flaws of the party that affect combat or exploration so you don't have to deal with tedious bookkeeping.  I would also recommend Flaws have bonuses to them so the choice to remove them isn't just money related.   As an example fear of humans can cause higher stress when fighting humans but confer a bonus like dodge, accuracy, or damage.  It might also have the added benefit of making me feel a bit more attached to a character.

The combat can be slow and tedious especially when someone crys about something causing allies to take sanity damage; meanwhile I am wondering why this has take at least 5-10 seconds every time it happens slowing down the gameplay.

I am not really a fan of not being able to purchase out of combat healing as it feels silly leaving someone alive so your party can make out in order to not head into a fight with a bunch of missing health. I understand it's risk versus reward but it's an absolute immersion breaker.

Repetitive, uninteresting, and pretentious. Darkest Dungeon tries hard to be intellectual and concept-driven with its mumbo jumbo about the imperfections of its heroes and the psychological stresses of adventuring, but all of this is just a façade that never gets conceptually deep—an excuse for a harsh and unforgiving game aimed at those who believe games ought to be hard.

I seem to understand that a large portion of the community mods the game to make it easier, which is quite telling. I'm not sure there's much point in that, as there isn't much to see beyond the difficulty itself. I completed the game on 'Radiant', the so-called easy difficulty, without mods. It was an awful, uninteresting, and honestly braindead grind that I wouldn't recommend to anyone.

Special mention goes to the silly procedurally generated component, with the narrator's voice droning on about the 'fortune' awaiting to be spent every time I loot something as trivial as a torch. I'm glad I don't have to hear this anymore.

The game is easily summed up as a data-heavy, arbitrary-difficulty slog with an extra helping of melodrama and frustratingly bad UI that was somehow never updated for QOL. The worst part of the game BY FAR is the arbitrary difficulty. I could overlook the painful slowness of character movement, the inconsistent stat readability, the boring unlocks, the almost uselessly-small inventory (and inventory selection), the annoying involuntary mini-map manipulation, and the rest of the meta pain points, were it not for the glaring issues with manufactured difficulty.

Everything in the game is trying to portray some sense of bleak hopelessness and cthulhu-esque mythos, which the devs apparently thought should mean the player does not get to enjoy themselves. However, the player should not feel uninspired by the character's experience. It's not the feeling of overcoming insurmountable odds and achieving the impossible in the face of certain doom; it's the feeling of yawning to death and uninstalling in the face of certain recycling through a bad gameloop for a hundred hours.

The loop goes like this:

Recruit some fodder, then go into a dungeon. But your fodder has to WANT to go; if they're too high or too low a level, then they refuse. But before you go, fiddle around with the entire roster for twenty minutes by shuffling them through hoops in town to cure the maladies they acquired, which makes them unavaliable until next time you leave town. Also, don't forget to unequip everything and re-equip it on the other fodder you slotted in to replace the recuperating fodder. Or, who cares, leave the stuff equipped on the invalids because it's no good anyway- most everything has negative effects to go along with their not-that-helpful positive effects. Later on, you'll get better equipment that won't matter either, because:

Once you go in the dungeon, you have to satisfy a clear condition while slowly plodding down hallways with no distinctive layouts, sometimes doubling back (slowly) to walk on more invisible traps that you never get a chance to disarm, and encountering groups of enemies that invariably
A. Hit harder than you
B. Hit more often than you
C. Do more AOE than you
D. Can re-up their entire roster if you try to heal yourself for even a single round
E. Have way too many HP for their dungeon level
F. In. Chat.

But while you do that, you're also going crazy just from existing, because oooh, spooky. These battle-hardened veterans of the hellwars who have waded through entire herds of lance-wielding pig centaurs and undead will most certainly lose their minds from simply standing around in the dark for thirty seconds. You're also being tempted with items that are all trapped and give you negative attributes for opening them, which might lead you to ignore them, except nope, since your characters went crazy earlier, they now auto-open random items and get worse traits to go with their already completely-scuffed portfolio.

Also, you run out of money to fix the traits pretty quickly, so now you're just staring at an entire rack of fodder in town that is fully stressed and completely bugnuts before you've even stepped foot in a dungeon. But don't worry, you can retreat and abandon your quests (which causes more stress, which causes more craziness), so if you're facing bankruptcy, just go into a dungeon (after spending twenty minutes fiddle-farking around in town with lists, every time, isn't this fun gameplay?) and fight A SINGLE ENCOUNTER, get one of your fodder outright killed because the enemies, in addition to the above stuff, also team-target a single character and dogpile them twice before your party gets to act AT ALL, slog through the fight, and then run back to town, which should give you exactly enough to heal one guy on your rack of six to ten crazies. And then go back and do it again until you have a party of four manageably-sane fodder (you've spent two or three hours at this point screwing with lists, let's not forget), after which you take them into a dungeon that is listed as level 3, which is exactly what all your party member's levels are at, and they are immediately dunked on because:

Miss. Miss. Miss. MISS. MISS. MISS. Miss. Miss. Miss. MISS. Huh, what's my accuracy? 90? Oh, but they have 10 dodge. So... 80? That's still better than average chance to hit, right? MISS. MISS. MISS. Oh snap, I hit once! ...for 1/3 damage because they have permanent protection. Well, keep on slogging I guess, they have to die eventua...MISS. MISS. Weird, the monsters hit me at a rate of 75-90% and frequently get all four party members at once. Maybe I can put some accuracy charms on my guys? Where even ARE some accuracy charms? Ok, I finally found some and wasted a charm slot on accuracy that could have been something partially useful if my career soldier already knew how to aim a sword at a stunned target (stunned means they miss a turn, not that they're, y'know, stunned...). Oh, and once I use my one ration of firewood I can put some buffs on my party, and this one guy can put this one buff that gets one other guy some accuracy, so now I'm sure to be able to connect with som...MISS. MISS. Miss. Miss. MISS. God, isn't this great gameplay? *yawn* Time to fidget some more lists!

And the entire time, there is a disembodied narrator giving the same tired, goading speeches every ten or so seconds...for hours. You could turn off the narration, of course- but then you'd miss actual lore when it happens. Unless, of course, you fidget the list every time you want to hear actual narration instead of "You stepped on a trap (that you couldn't see), pray it doesn't become a habit." and "Keep killing the enemies (that you can't do anything but kill, you want to tell me to continue breathing or anything else while you're at it there bud?), press the advantage (that you never had)." Or you could put on subtitles, which is just as tedious.

Where is fast travel? Where is auto-purchase? Why am I grinding for resources IMMEDIATELY going into level 1? Why am I not allowed to grind without imminent risk of party kill? Why is the game bad when it could have been good? Why do you want me not to enjoy the game?

There is the outline of a good game hiding underneath the mountain of crap here; more resources, more USEFUL resources, more meaningful player actions, less juggernaut-tank enemies, less lists, less microfidgeting with lists, less meaninglessness, better UI, larger inventory...there's a lot of things that could have flipped this into great fun. Instead, it went from two hours of interest to four hours of deepening dismay and realization to two final hours of complete loss of interest, much in the same way as Jump King did for me. I like platformers, but Jump King isn't a platformer; it's a micromanagement precision game masquerading as a platformer. Similarly, I enjoy roguelite/likes and dungeon crawlers, but DD isn't that- it's a kick-you-in-the-nuts simulator with hours of forced and incredibly boring interaction that, god help me, would have been better as an idle game.

On its Tenth Anniversary. A review: A deep and well made RPG, with some base building elements. A heavy theme of horror and lovecraftian menace flow throughout the story. Strategize for your fores into the dungeons, as you dive deep into the broken and corrupted estate of your ancestor. Plan your expedition well; for preparation (and supplies) is paid for in Gold (you earn) now and later in blood if you choose to go light on supplies. Inventory management is important, as your treasure earned will take up slots that you may need for your party to heal, eat, or get through obstacles. Upgrade your estate to prepare for even greater horrors to come. Your heroes will become stronger as they beat threats and complete missions. They will need your help (and investment) in better gear: Armor, Weapons and other tools. Seek out Trinkets and Baubles: they will offer your heroes advantages that a sharpened sword or stronger shield can not. Beware, they will suffer horror and stress (one of the core mechanics of the game) in these dungeons that will take effort of their employer (You) to fix. As they see the horrors and violence, or see others fail or fall in combat, they will become overwhelmed, even developing specific types of mental conditions as the stress causes a test of their resolution. Sometimes, they will overcome their fear and find a bravery that few men or women (both who will be hired by you, as the scion and their leader) normally possess. But all too often, they will become paranoid, or fearful, or irrational. And they may ignore your order, harm themselves, or attack or act on their own (the game is dark in some ways that are realistic, or at least may lead some folks to feel uncomfortable. Just a note). But you will need to, as the player (and their leader/employer), find and learn about the various systems that this RPG will present for your. There will be trial and error. You *will* lose allies and those you hire. And those heroes will not return, if they are gone, they will stay as such. You may chose to retreat from a mission to save a hero(s), and you can retreat from battles and come back or approach things a different way. But remember, they will suffer stress of defeat, and this is a game of challenge and difficulty. Much like any game of lovecraftian horror should be. A last word: sometimes you will find curious objects, curios if you will. Some will be helpful, some will be harmful, and some can do both. *Do* pay close attention to the wording and how they are described. And do keep in mind, your supplies may have more than one use, and may have a curios interaction. Good luck, and welcome home.

[h3]Have you ever imagined what would you get if you combine gambling addiction and RPG masochism?[/h3]

Well.. you get a rougelike dungeon crawling game where the core experience is to make you and every character you manage suffer.

[h3]How Masochistic Are We Talking About?[/h3]

I've played my share of masochistic games... be it Souls-like, SMT series, even tediously collecting golden bricks in Lego Marvel Super Heroes. But Darkest Dungeon's masochism is different. 

The game is all about management. 
Each character has a stress bar. Hit 100 and you get a really bad random affliction (penalty). Hit 200 and your HP instantly goes to 0 because... they had a "heart attack" (shrugs) but here's the interesting part. This game doesn't kill your character instantly, instead it puts that character in a "death's door" state where if they get another hit they'll go over that state's threshold and permanently die. You can negate this state with a healing skill on that character. And you can negate and get "Death's Door" repeatedly, it's not a the next time you die... no, the game wants you butt clenched as you pray to whoever is up there so your character doesn't die from a bleed you didn't wanna use bandages on.

Literally keeping things one mistake away from their death.

That and every room, every loot chance that gives your character a bad trait or compromise your dungeon run, every mob that could stun, make you stressed, and crit your party to death's door. 
That's the gambling aspect. Risking a bad run would deny all your investment on the character you've been using. But quitting is also costly because there's risk you get bad traits. 

There is no room to breath except when you're camping, even then you could still get ambushed. It's like playing poker/mahjong, except you play with your party member's lives at every hand. One bad encounter, or accumulating bad luck will run your pot dry and someone gets killed.

[h3]The Pacing...[/h3]

Honestly this is the most interesting part... 
The pacing of the game isn't bad per se. Since every dungeon run is basically a drug for gambling addicts (though couch traders would deny it...), the game's pace is decided by how fast you can understand the game's mechanic, and how lucky you are to get good items early on. 

However, starting off... the game will not give you any good equipment/trinkets, and while you don't need it... the difficulty jump to veteran level dungeons basically requires you to have a concrete party and build already. Personally, I think it's too fast of a learning curve considering how many class of characters there are, and how frequently you need to rotate and mish and mash them. 

For beginners, I highly recommend getting a mod that lets you bring a lvl 3 character to enter apprentice dungeons... Because the game locks lvl 3 characters to only take veteran and above level dungeons despite you not having a full party yet, or the necessary upgrades. Meanwhile your resources are wasted cycling members to replace resting ones.

Overall, the pacing doesn't demand anything from you... there's no time limit. But you're also gonna inevitably get harder and harder missions. While apprentice dungeons still comes up, there's only 3 slots / dungeon area for every in-game week. You could get a mission that's inconvenient for you. 

It's both brilliant and slightly annoying because progression relies heavily on luck.

[h3]The Modding Community[/h3]

Let's be honest here... the modding community of this game is one of the biggest incentive of this game. There's a lot of things you can mod from gameplay to character skins. If you really wanted to... you could also make the game easy from it or harder. And there's a lot of premium quality mods the community has made... so if that's what you're interested in, you won't be disappointed.

Overall, the game is fun if you're into RPGs. There's a lot of depth on party building/synergy, and enemy gimmicks. The stakes keeps things engaging, and no two dungeon diving have the same result as you would a normal RPG.

Darkest Dungeon is a roguelike, side-scrolling dungeon crawler which tries and successfully makes suffering fun. 

Picture this, a turnbased RPG in which your party of four has a random encounter with some spiders, pretty typical right? Well imagine that the spiders go first, they instantly posion your healer and kill them, they then shoot web at your melee guy pushing him to the back of your line meaning you have to waste turns putting him back to the front so he can attack, during all this your other two party members get so stressed that one starts attacking randomly and the other just dies of a heart attack basically ruining the run. That's darkest dungeon and it happens often. 

The fun is overcoming the odds with a rag tag bunch of killers who manage to get out of the dungeon on the overside. The game priorities placements and positioning as the way you set up your team can be life or death. In the down time between dungeon crawls you can build up your little town, go to the pub and upgrade your team (only for them to die next round losing all your upgrades) the fun isn't about getting to the end, it's the balance of trying to build a team that can get there only for them to all freakout because you didn't buy enough torches. 

Simply put if you enjoy going at a snails pace, taking it slow and really looking over the minute details and feeling that immensely satisfying feeling of over coming a difficult dungeon then this game is for you, often regarded as a classic and for good reason, this is a suffering simulator and call me a masochist but I love it.

A strong, dark, lovecraftian world with a compelling atmosphere only enhanced by its narrator. Adventuring the moody world through turn based combat with a high difficulty, requiring strategic team composition and stress management. The game is challenging and not for the faint of heart, but very rewarding when you get it right.

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
[*][b]Deep Atmosphere:[/b] An incredibly rich and immersive atmosphere that really brings you into the world.
[*][b]Character Management:[/b] Not only do you have the usual management of where do I place these characters, what trinkets should they equip, and which of their moves should I be using each turn. You also need to manage their mental and physical health, falling short on either count will end your run.
[*][b]Narration:[/b] The narrator plays a central role in the experience, providing a gloomy tone and reacting to events you trigger along the way.
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
[*][b]Difficulty:[/b] The game can feel unfairly difficult and unforgiving, with random encounters and frustrating boss mechanics. However, you may read this as a skill check more than a con.
[*][b]Not suited for the time poor:[/b] The difficulty can feel punishing for players who have less time to dedicate to the game, potentially turning it into a chore with repetitive grinding.
[*][b]Stress Management:[/b] The stress mechanic, while important, is too expensive to manage. All your money will be drained on stress relief and healing negative ailments rather than actually growing and improving your team/characters.
[/list]
