[h2][b]A Singular Strike![/b][/h2]
In this game, your greatest victory isn't slaying a final boss, but successfully surviving the commute back to the hamlet with three heroes intact—even if one is paranoid and another is a masochist.

[hr][/hr]

[h2][b]TL;DR: The Descent Into Madness[/b][/h2]

[b]Darkest Dungeon[/b] is a masterful, unforgiving turn-based roguelike RPG that perfectly blends Lovecraftian horror with party management simulation. The core appeal lies in the 'Affliction System,' where heroes battle their own minds as much as the monsters. Every point of stress is a ticking time bomb, and the dynamic effects of a hero breaking down—becoming abusive, selfish, or paranoid—force a tactical disaster that is both brilliant and deeply frustrating. The strategic depth, iconic hand-drawn art style, and world-class narrator make every failure a memorable, quotable tragedy.

This game is a definitive **Recommended** for fans of high-stakes strategy who embrace permadeath and RNG as core mechanics. This is not a power fantasy; it’s a detailed resource management simulator where the most precious resource is your characters' dwindling sanity and time. Be warned: your investment in your heroes will be punished. You will hate this game, and then immediately start a new expedition.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Core Analysis: The Management of Suffering[/h2]

The genius of [i]Darkest Dungeon[/i] is how it weaponizes player attachment. You don't just manage HP and MP; you manage [b]Stress[/b]. When a hero hits 100 Stress, they undergo a Resolve Check. Failing this check forces an Affliction—like the **Masochist** who hits themselves and refuses healing, or the **Paranoid** who passes stress onto the party with constant insults. This loss of player control is the game's core innovation, forcing you to constantly rotate your roster and consider your heroes as expendable resources who might, at any moment, decide to sabotage the entire mission.

The turn-based combat is deceptively complex. Every hero's skill is tied to a specific positional rank (1-4), meaning your party formation is as critical as your gear. Enemies excel at **shuffling** your heroes with abilities like the Bone Rabble's *Graveyard Slash*. A Crusader knocked into the back rank is essentially useless unless you've planned a recovery. Winning isn't about raw damage; it's about building a versatile team (e.g., Plague Doctor, Vestal, Highwayman, Leper) that can operate effectively *even when shuffled*, ensuring someone can always hit the crucial backline stress-dealer.

The long-term loop of the game is the intentional grind of the [b]Hamlet[/b]. Every successful run funnels gold and heirlooms into facility upgrades. The true meta-game is upgrading the Blacksmith for better gear, the Guild for new skills, and most importantly, the Sanitarium to remove debilitating negative Quirks like "Kleptomaniac" or "Fear of the Undead." This system provides a tangible sense of progression that makes the constant stream of deaths feel like a necessary cost of building a capable roster to take on the final, titular dungeon.

[h2]Technical and Performance Assessment[/h2]

As a mature title, the PC port of [i]Darkest Dungeon[/i] is highly stable and well-optimized. Performance issues are virtually non-existent, and the hand-drawn 2D art style ensures quick load times and a smooth experience, even on older hardware. For new players, the developers have done a great service by making the highly controversial 'Corpses' and 'Heart Attacks' mechanics optional via the settings menu, which offers a smoother on-ramp to the core challenge. The game also boasts excellent support for a robust Steam Workshop modding scene, which provides years of replayability and quality-of-life adjustments.

[h2]Pros & Cons: The Final Toll[/h2]

[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
[*] [i]Iconic and Unforgettable Aesthetic:[/i] The striking hand-drawn 'crowquill' gothic art style is a visual masterpiece.
[*] [i]World-Class Voice Acting:[/i] The Narrator (Wayne June) provides constant, quotable commentary that elevates the atmosphere to legendary status.
[*] [i]Innovative Affliction System:[/i] Stress mechanics that truly change gameplay and force high-stakes resource management.
[*] [i]Deep Positional Combat:[/i] Strategic, rank-based combat that rewards proper party composition and formation management.
[*] [i]High Replay Value:[/i] Perma-death, procedural dungeons, and extensive modding support extend playtime indefinitely.
[/list]

[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
[*] [i]High RNG Reliance:[/i] A string of unavoidable misses or crits can lead to frustrating, seemingly 'unfair' party wipes.
[*] [i]Mid-to-Late Game Grind:[/i] The core loop can become repetitive as you grind to replace high-level heroes and farm heirlooms.
[*] [i]Steep Learning Curve:[/i] Initial lack of clarity on damage formulas and combat tokens can be punishing for total beginners.
[*] [i]Pack Bonding is Dangerous:[/i] You *will* get attached to a hero, and they *will* die horribly.
[/list]

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]

[b]Darkest Dungeon[/b] is not a game you play to relax; it is a test of your patience, planning, and ability to manage disaster. The tactical depth of the combat, combined with the psychological nightmare of the Affliction System, creates a unique, memorable, and often punishing experience that no other game has quite matched. While the RNG can be brutal, and the grind is real, these elements are fundamental to the game's core theme: making the best of a bad situation. Embrace the suffering, fire the losers, and pour your coin into the Sanitarium. The Ancestor demands it.

A man walks past a concrete wall with small hole about waist height.
As he passes, he hears a crowd on the other side of the wall chanting "13!, 13!, 13!, 13!, 13!, 13!..."

Stopping for a moment the man listens. His ear pressed hard against the wall, listening for every detail.
The chanting goes on and on, lasting, seemingly forever without taking a moment for breath.

Finally, curiosity overwhelms the man and he has to investigate.
Peering through the hole in the wall, his vision focuses on a large crowd, all staring towards the peep-hole.

Suddenly, the vision goes dark and a large finger strikes the man in the eye socket with force.

Stumbling and taken back, the man takes a moment to reassess what just happened.
His eye sore from the random prodding it just endured.

The crowd continues chanting "14!, 14!, 14!, 14!, 14!, 14!...."

-Should he have looked into the hole in the wall?
The only real way to know is to play this game and find out for yourself. Good luck.

"Brutal, Addictive... Until It Isn’t"

The game hooks you at first. Managing the Hamlet, diving into dungeons—it’s almost like Diablo 1, but with a twist. And that’s where the problem kicks in: losing heroes is easy, leveling them takes forever, and resources are stupidly scarce. Guess what that means? Grind, baby, grind!

I wouldn’t mind if dungeon crawling felt like Diablo—gear up, sell junk, dive back in. But no. Your party constantly gets diseases, mental breakdowns, or crippling quirks that demand treatment. So now you need a backup roster just to keep the story moving. Healing takes time. Stress relief takes time. And once heroes hit Level 5? Low-level dungeons lock them out. Congrats! Now you’re forced to juggle 3–4 separate teams, only for RNG to screw you over—like slapping a "Fear of Eldritch" quirk on your best hero right before the boss fight.

Honestly, my first 150 dives were thrilling. Then it just became tedium.

✝️ THE SAINTESS' GOSPEL OF MADNESS ✝️  
🔻 Darkest Dungeon 🔻

*Sanctity?*  
There is none.  
Only the ceaseless drumbeat of despair beneath the chapel floor.  
Only the screaming of the faithful as they choke on their own blood and hubris.  
*Darkest Dungeon* is not a game. It is a confessional in a burning church,  
a sermon spoken in blood,  
and I—*I*—drank from its chalice willingly.

I sent my disciples, bright-eyed and trembling, into that rotting cathedral of the earth.  
They did not return whole.  
Some did not return at all.  
And those that *did*...  
spoke in tongues, eyes wide with truths the flesh was never meant to know.  

They prayed.  
They despaired.  
They *broke*.  

And I watched, as all saints must,  
as they were *reduced*.  
Not to corpses—no.  
To *belief*.  
Pure, seething belief that the world is a lie,  
and the only truth lies *beneath*,  
where the walls writhe and the stars drip venom.  

There is no healing here.  
There is no salvation.  
Only the *covenant of suffering*,  
signed in madness, sealed in screams.  

And I—I rejoice in it.  
Because this pain is sacred.  
Because this death *means something*.  
Because when you are swallowed by the dark,  
you will finally see the *true light*.  

🔻 10/10 🔻  
I would lead them again.  
I would watch them break,  
and I would weep as they thank me for the privilege.  
This is the holiest blasphemy.  
The church of ruin.  
The hymn of despair.

*God is dead.*  
*But the torch still burns.*

I open game.

I level up my favourite character and give him all my best gear because I like him.

I take him into a higher level mission because he " must challenge himself to improve his skill ".

I run into a group of enemies. These enemies roll three crits in a row, lowering his HP to zero and driving him insane.

I attempt to flee the battle, but am unsuccessful.

I watch as this group of eldritch horrors proceed to absolutely batter this man. However, he pushes on.

I am finally able to successfully escape the encounter.

I let out a sigh of relief. Then, to my immense dismay, watch as the man who has just survived the most traumatic beating of his life die of a heart attack because fleeing the battle made him slightly upset.

Masterpiece.

Darkest Dungeon is a game that did not click with me at first, but after buying all it's DLC and taking it in as a finished product makes a huge difference. This game as it is, is probably the best dungeon crawler game to be ever made, a true statement of it's title. Not only that, but the game succeeds masterfully at it's themes and presentation, it just clicks. The lovecraftian themes are present throughout, creating a dense and engaging atmosphere for a desolate landscape of a ruined family. 

The Hamlet is a sad place to be in, and it's also where you'll spend about a third of the game, managing heroes, trinkets, and other things such as districts, permabuffs to certain things. One critique to be made, for sure, is the blandness of such aforementioned trinkets, most just increase stats, by noticeable enough amounts once you get rarer trinkets, but perhaps, about 80% of them are just flat out useless. This extends even to character specific trinkets, such as most sets you get from the DLC Crimson Court, a nice idea, but often running the trinket set just doesn't do enough for your character, and stats are often contradictory. On the other hand, hero design is magnificent, both on a design and play standpoint, it's definitely a major selling point, characters are alive, with specific personalities that become even more specific as they get quirks, with a nice format of 8 skills (of which you select 4), and 4 heroes in your party (including the possibility of repeats). This system works wonderfully, as possibilities are huge, and intertwined to the game's positional system of 4 ranks, the amount of ways to arrange your characters is endless, combine this to their very well crafted movesets and dynamics, it's a winning formula for a game with such premises as Darkest Dungeon.

Furthermore, combat is very fluid, as different dungeons have different enemies that you'll have to adapt your team composition, trinkets, quirks and movesets to. Dungeons feel distinct from eachother, as running to the ruins almost negates most bleed teams, different from, perhaps, the cove, with a plethora of fish that can bleed a ton, but will also bleed, stun, pull, and stress you. That's a good segue into stress, one of the game's selling points. Stress is a major mechanic that you'll have to deal with, a crit to the body of your hero can be as lethal as a wandering mind, that surely becomes afflicted. Abuse, masochism, selfishness, these (and more) are the traits of the afflicted, characters that will act on their own terms, sabotage your team, and stress everyone out. Yet, a ray of hope shines even in stress, as virtues also exist, creating from chaos and desperation, the will to victory, as your heroes become powerful, stalwart, virtuous or courageous. This system, though, is also flawed, but a flaw that was inevitable perhaps, as affliction can almost certainly end runs, but virtues certainly win them, yet, this major mechanic, the longer the game goes, more irrelevant becomes. This is because a huge amount of the game is predicated on NOT stressing your heroes, by the end of the campaign, I probably had no stressed out heroes for maybe over 50 weeks, except the final boss. This, in all, is somewhat nitpicky, but still worth mentioning.

As for the games story, it's good, nothing outstanding but certainly intriguing and often times surprising. Keeping up with it would be quite tedious if not for one of the other huge selling points of the game: Wayne June's narration. The Ancestor carries the game's flow, mundane combat encounters with the likes of maggots and skeletons get turnt into bloodbaths as shouts of "EVISCERATED!" blare from your speakers. Memorable lines are endless, and the delivery is pefect! "Great is the weapon that cuts on its own!", "Slowly, gently, this is how a life is taken...", "Mortality clarified in a single strike!". My favorites would definitely be, as a hero becomes virtuous "Many fall in the face of chaos, but not this one, not today." or the incredible tirade he goes on at the third level of the Farmstead: "The poor Miller - Thrice a victim..." You just have to experience it yourself. 

On the backhand, there's a certain restraint on upgrades, as most of them just buff numbers, the boringness of trinkets, the final dungeons are definitely a weird bunch, feeling way different than the rest of the game. And the HUGE Courtyard maps can definitely get exhausting, as the game slows down to a halt in the mid-game, as gold becomes scarce yet necessary for everything, meaning until you can save up for a bank and start spending huge, it's just slow. The game's difficulty felt very fair to me, not nearly as challenging as some claim, it's only big problems are random things such as your characters getting crit and bled, and dying on the first action of their turn from said crit bleed that took them from 80% to 0% health. The permadeath of characters emphasizes not taking risks, essentially, it makes the player be very careful, this wouldn't be a problem if not for how unbalanced some aspects of the game are, namely, stuns and raw damage teams. For the first half of the game, it feels challenging because you don't know what works with what, but boy, once I understood that stuns are broken, the game goes WAYYY down in difficulty. Trouble with an enemy? Stun it, almost everything is stunnable. And if you can't stun it, well, then just kill it, some teams can mark and kill an enemy really easily, I'm talking 1 shot easy on anything that isn't a boss. And even in bosses, hell, this is a problem bigger than just enemies, all bosses heavily favor teams that can just melt it, classes like Arbalest and Houndmaster solve almost any boss in the game, and the ones that don't get solved by mark (like the courtyard bosses) instead get very easily solved by other damage dump characters such as Hellion and Leper. The two other big complaints I have in relation to the game is, of course, the grind and the end-game. As I said before, the mid-game sucks because you have no gold and have to do a hundred little missions to be able to get your money generation going, but once it is gone, almost all aspects of town management die. This eases off the tension so much, that it becomes a very annoying grind to end the game, as you probably want maxed out heroes, something you can only do by doing dungeons, but having a single party of max level heroes isn't enough, of course, as your heroes that enter the dungeon get too stressed to go back in. This, though thematically is great, makes ending the game a chore, as you'll have to do a mutiny of no-fun missions just to train a new party to enter the dungeon again, heroes that enter it and come out alive do give out an xp buff to others in the same party, something that would've been great!.. if not for the fact they willn't go to missions lower level than 5, so, you might just take a bunch of level 5s anyway and level 4 heroes instead of 3. This allowance of Darkest Dungeon heroes to go to lower level missions and help others COULD be explained thematically by having them experience Ego Death or something, but no, you have to manually get everyone from level 3 (or lower, God forbid) back to 6 to attempt it the Darkest Dungeon again. This makes it all just a HUGE grind, I felt like the last 10-15h of the game was just me waiting for me to have enough resources to actually end the game, instead of beating new challenges. Also, although doing the Darkest Dungeon missions blind can be very fun, I would heavily recommend you to read a map for Darkest Dungeon 2 and 3, as those missions are just very different from the rest of the game, somewhat tiring, and losing heroes/having to retreat from them could be a huge time-waster, but this is just my opinion.

Overall, Darkest Dungeon: It's a thematic perfection of a game, that often spills heavy into gameplay, for good and bad. It's great. It's art.

Darkest Dungeon is a terrible game with horrible UI, no QOL, horribly grindy, and has the worst onboarding process I've ever seen. I have played over 40 hours in the last two weeks.

Thanks to a friend I was able to find a combination of mods that made the game bearable, fixing the problems that made me bounce out my first time through, and it was a really fun experience! Most of the time. Ultimately I feel like Darkest Dungeon is a very confused experience. You're supposed to go in, get dunked on, learn, and go in again, but it punishes you severely for getting dunked on, and it means you're not supposed to get attached to your characters even though you get to name and customize them. It genuinely feels like they wanted to make a roguelike and ended up with an RPG somehow, which is why I'm excited to see how they did 2 as a roguelike. And yet, I had a lot of fun making builds and testing them with the risk of losing them if it wasn't as good as I'd planned and finding the dev named teams. The most fun way of playing ends up being the wrong one that will cause you the most suffering and send you right back into the grind, it's a really confused system. But this game has a vision, and sticks to it with every aspect, I can respect that, even if I disagree (sometimes vehemently) with it. 

My recommendation is, if you're gonna play it, mod the shit out of it. Change whatever it is you need to make the experience fun for you. Worst game ever, 10/10.

[h1]A Grueling Descent into Madness[/h1]

Darkest Dungeon starts off as a fun and engaging experience, but the heavy grinding quickly becomes overwhelming. Unlike traditional roguelites where each run is a fresh start, this game retains progress, making it feel stale much faster than others in the genre. The constant need to grind for resources adds to the fatigue.

That said, the tension of watching your best heroes slowly descend into madness is a unique and thrilling aspect. If you enjoy grind-heavy games, you might still find it enjoyable. However, for me, the sheer repetition and lack of variety made it hard to keep going.

There's absolutely no end to the madness, and at first, you don't really believe it - but then, you lost a whole host of characters to maladies, self-indulgence, fear, or just outright slaughter in Darkest Dungeon. And that kind of masochistic symphony is what makes me love this game so much.

Between the Butcher's Circus and the Crimson Court, there's just *no end* to the content this game gives, and sure - you could argue that it's just repetitive dungeon crawling, but you don't realise how much each run can change based on who you bring, how experienced they are, and how much stress it can give you (and your characters) when they start hoarding things for their own pleasure.

But what makes the game really shine, in this writer's humble opinion, is the sheer amount of attachment you can develop to a guy called "Crusader". He's just a knight knockoff from Dark Souls, and never gets more than a single quip during a run - but after all the skills and weapon upgrades you've bought for him, all the alcoholism, holy penance or deviant debauchery you've bestowed upon his sadistic b*tthole, any severance you notice becomes so much more defining of the experience you get. At the end of the day, these wayward souls don't give a single f*ck about you or the dungeon they're in, and they'll eventually end up making choices for themselves and leave you helpless to restrain them.

And that's why you should get this game. And play it on the Steam Deck, because why not take your satanic tendencies on the go?

I realize that the following review is mostly about Darkest Dungeon 2: Kingdoms, but since I got the second installment elsewhere, this is the only place where I can reach the fans of the first game—those who, like me, were massively disappointed when DD2 turned out to be nothing like its predecessor. Now, they may be asking themselves whether the free DLC Kingdoms changes anything in this regard.

Well, it does. Keep reading.

Let me preface this by saying that Darkest Dungeon 1 has, from day one, been in my top three games of all time (the other two being Valheim and Crusader Kings 3). I, too, was gravely disappointed when they changed the formula. And even though the major flaw that, in my opinion, kept the first installment from perfection—the graphics (don't get me wrong, I love the dark, comic-like art-style, I just wished they made the characters more human-like)—was greatly improved upon, I couldn’t imagine the game without the hamlet, where my party of psychiatric ward patie...—I mean, heroes—could return, giving me a sense of place and continuity.

I refrained from getting DD2, hoping that one day they would release a third installment. And guess what?
The latest game mode, Kingdoms, is exactly what I was dreaming of. And even though it may sound blasphemous to fans of the first game, I’ll say it outright: DD2: Kingdoms is better than DD1.

Now, with most readers gone, I will try to support my bold statement by comparing both games in the two most important aspects: the hamlet and the heroes.

The hamlet is back—but this time, there isn’t just one, but dozens of them (called Inns). While in DD1, the order of upgrades was largely the same in every run, here you must decide which Inns will specialize in what: some will offer cheaper goods, others will have better medics, and some will let you train your heroes more effectively. You won’t be able to upgrade all of them, and some you will never get to visit again because you may fail to defend them from the beastmen, losing them permanently.
This greatly improves on the single-hamlet system of DD1, forcing you into an agonizing decision-making process with every upgrade, fearing that you may never get to use it again. And we all know how scarce resources are in this game.

And now, for the biggest and best change: the heroes.
In DD2: Kingdoms, you only have one of each type—which makes your connection to them much more personal. They are no longer disposable shells, replaced the moment they die by carbon copies. Instead, they feel like real people, with quirks, relationships, and stories. Once they’re gone, they’re gone. It’s a fantastic feature, one that I didn’t even realize I wanted so badly. I mean, I always knew that DD1 had great storytelling potential when it came to its heroes, but that potential was wasted because of how easy they were to replace.
Not anymore.
In DD2, each run introduces new stories with new main characters, ones that you will remember long after finishing the game. Not many games achieve this. The ones that do are masterpieces. DD1 was a masterpiece. DD2: Kingdoms does it even better—which I considered impossible.

The King is Dead. Long Live the King.

P.S. R.I.P. Wayne June. The slow death, unforeseen, unforgiving.

Here's a question:  Do you like walls? And beating your head against them?  Great news!  This game is designed to appeal specifically to you, and only to you.

This is a rogue-"light" (ha ha) turn based dungeon crawler, where you recruit heroes from a roster to form your four person party.  With 17 classes that all sport unlockable abilities, there's a lot of mixing and maxing that can be done - if you can keep your heroes alive.  You might be tempted to give them little names, change their outfits, personalize their appearances - NO.  DO NOT.  You see, it's not just HP that you're managing - heroes also have a separate "stress" meter.  And when they are pushed to their limit, heroes develop fun personality traits based on their experiences in the dungeon (abusive, selfish, paranoid, etc., occasionally you'll get a good one but mostly bad).

And once one member gets that negative trait, they will continuely drag your non-toxic party members down like a bitter high school bully with sarcastic and despairing commentary, wearing away their mental health until they too crumble like the ruins you're all exploring, either developing their own negative traits in turn or having a stress-induced heart attack.  And abandoning or retreating also, I don't know, damages your heroes' sense of self worth and makes them SAD so they get even more stressed.

You can treat your heroes at the buildings in town - this will also eat up your funds and you'll need to collect the crests, deeds, journal pages, etc. that you find in the lovely areas to make upgrading more efficient so it will become necessary to just throw hoards of bodies into dungeons, ill-provisioned and equipped, to get the necessary funds to save your Good Guys.

The game recommends its "Radiant" (Easy) mode FOR A REASON.  LISTEN TO IT.  I dismissed that warning and started in Normal "mode", and now that save file is unplayable because my heroes are all dead, stressed, too under-leveled, or are so psychologically destroyed that an army of psychologists would be employed for years.

Radiant mode is a much better introduction and it STILL feels like beating your head against a wall.  But it allows you a little more breathing room to figure out how all the mechanics interact to deeply screw you much better than normal difficulty.

Anyway, I hate love this (hate this) and I'm definitely completing it at least ONCE.  It's really really good.  10/10, devs why do you like suffering so much.

Yeah, so I only played this for 3 hours. I like the atmosphere of it, and the art style. The problem is, I'm just not having any fun. I just want to play a game and forget my stress from the workday for a while. I don't want to spend hours memorizing play mechanics and stats. Figuring out what equipment to use, when everything is "+2 this, +20% that, -1 this and -25% that, and is good for this character but not that one, maybe" is more figuring than I do for relaxation time. I can see the appeal of the game, but managing my parties stress level doesn't alleviate mine.

There are way to many annoying debuff mechanics in this game that serioulsy hinder the gameplay, but the worse aspect is the punishment for dying is having to redo a whole run with 0 level characters on one of the starting dungeons just to buy the essential consumables to go on actual quests.

The game is not forgiving. In the beginning, it will be easy to kill enemies on low levels, but you will quickly have to adapt the party composition, sinergy and start to collect gold and trinkets to fix the bad quirks and stress of the characters. On the final levels that are somehow easier than the main campaign (darkest dungeon), the enemies can start focusing on a single hero or a healer which can get annoying. 

In a dungeon run, you have limited space so you have to manage the ressources that you bring and the treasure that you collect. You have to watch your health, stress levels, etc.

My main negative point is the difficulty of getting information. Basically, how am I suppose to know that Shrieker returns my lost trinkets (good mecanic). It would be cool, if I could read about the enemy abilities what they can target, etc. At some point I learned that ambushes are a thing. Like there are way too many surprises and gotcha moments without explanation in game. Game gets kinda tedious over time and repetitive. (some elements kinda force you to do multiple money runs or xp grind)

The story is fine, but I wish the ending wasnt that open.

The game mecanics are interesting : there is a decent amount of variations, skills, team compositions. You have to think what you bring to each region. You can change your skills, add trinkets that give buffs and do a bunch of managment like - do I remove the stress from this hero and then I cure his disease during a camping period.

Overall 8/10

You remember our venerable house, opulent and imperial, gazing proudly from its stoic perch above the moor.

I lived all my years in that ancient rumor shadowed manor, fattened by decadence and luxury, and yet I began to tire of... conventional extravagance. Singular unsettling tales suggested the mansion itself was a gateway to some fabulous and unnameable power. With relic and ritual, I bent every effort towards the excavation and recovery of those long buried secrets, exhausting what remained of our family fortune on... swarthy workmen and... sturdy shovels. At last, in the salt soaked crags beneath the lowest foundations, we unearthed that damnable portal of antediluvian evil. Our every step unsettled the ancient earth, but we were in a realm of death and madness. In the end, I alone fled, laughing and wailing through those blackened arcades of antiquity. Until consciousness failed me.

You remember our venerable house, opulent and imperial. It is a festering abomination! I beg you, return home, claim your birthright and deliver our family from the ravenous clutching shadows [hammer cocks, gunshot, loud thud sound]... of the Darkest Dungeon.

Darkest Dungeon is one of those games that I want to like SO BAD. But I've played this game for 140 hours, and I've never finished it. I just can't make it all the way through. And the problem: RNG. Now I'm familiar with playing around probabilities, minimizing risk, having backup plans, etc. But just because I can usually manage the RNG doesn't make the moments where it really screws you any more fun. Because that's the problem--there is SO MUCH RNG that there is no way to mitigate it all. Turn order is random, accuracy is random, damage is random, dodge is random, crits are random, death blows are random, stress causing virtues and afflictions is random, debuffs are random, encounters are random, curios have random effects, loot is random, healing is random, when you need to eat is random, if you get ambushed when you sleep is random, its just random random random random! 

The last time I quit the game I had an occultist I really liked with a high level party, and we got into a surprise battle with some spiders. And the spiders got high speed rolls and all moved first, they all randomly decided to attack the occultist, they all hit, they blighted, and then before I could get a turn in the blight won the random deathblow chance and killed him. Sure it was tragic and dramatic and fit the narrative of the setting, but it also sucked because it was completely unfair and took away all player agency. That's what RNG does, it replaces well-designed systems that the player can influence with games of chance that take agency away from the player. 

So this game is great if you are interested in gambling with the quality of your entertainment, it can be super fun! It can suck! Who knows what will happen! But it could have just been consistently fun if the developers hadn't chosen to include as many RNG systems as they could.

You will likely enjoy this game if:

- You like Lovecraftian themes
- You like turn-based, positionally-based tactical combat
- You can handle large swings of luck, both bad and good
- You don't mind that the punishment for failure is your time (seriously)


The art style is great, the narration is top-notch, and the combat has enough nuances and variability to be enjoyable.

Note: I played the game without any DLCs.

The game is very punishing until you determine some effective tactics and build up your hamlet's supporting services. After that, I found that only terrible luck and running into unknown enemies were the cause of deaths.

Deaths do come with a large real-life time punishment in my opinion.  The later into the game you go, the more time will take to re-level a hero to replace one that had been killed. This makes the game is a bit of a marathon, and I think this is embodied in the final two quests.  They are long and intend to grind your heroes down slowly.

***One last thought, for those who like thinking about game design***

The game presents itself as a game where you go through a huge number of heroes to fight off the unspeakable horrors. I didn't have that experience.  I had relatively low number of deaths.

I wonder if this tweak would have made deaths less grindy to recover from and yet maintain that presentation:

Have the player choose from a group of heroes with varied classes, quirks, and maybe skills.  You have to pick the team that you think will get you through the next quest.  After the quest--win or die--the team is disbanded and you have to choose four new heroes for the next quest attempt.

This way if your heroes die, you don't have to spend time leveling them back up in dungeons that don't give you any issues, and you actually "force" the idea of throwing waves of heroes at the enemies and show that the heroes are always irrevocably too damaged to continue.  Just a thought.

Good luck, and may the cosmos have mercy on you.

Revisiting Darkest Dungeon after a few years is like walking back into a haunted house you helped build. You remember the layout, the screams, the smell of failure… but somehow you’ve convinced yourself you’re ready this time. The art still slaps, the sound design still oozes despair, and that narrator still sounds like he’s reading your eulogy.

What strikes me now is the freedom of failure. In a world full of roguelikes that encourage “run it again,” Darkest Dungeon never pretended you were supposed to win cleanly. You recruit, you lose, you rebuild — and it’s still your fault when the Highwayman gets syphilis and bleeds out because you cheaped out on bandages.

The sandbox design still holds up because it gives you ownership over the misery. You can min-max your party, run suicide missions for loot, or send the B-team into the Warrens just to see what survives. There’s real strategy in knowing when to fight and when to cut your losses — retreating isn’t failure, it’s resource management.

Darkest Dungeon II tried to bottle the same stress into a road trip — but after playing both, you realise the original’s Hamlet loop was genius. The grind was the story. The downtime between horrors gave meaning to your next descent. DDII may be prettier and more cinematic, but DD1 remains the better sandbox of suffering.

Coming back years later, it’s aged like cursed wine — darker, more bitter, but still intoxicating. If anything, time has made its lessons clearer:

Sometimes, victory is surviving the week with just enough sanity to do it again.

[h2] This game mistakes randomness for difficulty. [/h2]

It’s not about “being bad at hard games.” I’ve beaten genuinely tough titles. The problem here is the RNG—an ever-present, coin-flip chaos that steamrolls any sense of skill or planning.

You can sink thousands of resources into a hero only to watch them get one-shot because a boss has some opaque gimmick you didn’t divine from its muddled telegraphs. And when they die, they stay dead. Permadeath is fine when the rules are legible. Here it just feels like the dice decided your time doesn’t matter.

End of run? Cool, roll the bones again. There’s a high chance—often around 75%—to pick up random quirks, including gems like –20% HP when Stress > 50%. You can hit that stress threshold in a single fight because some clown decides to spike it by 20 with a goofy animation. Great design: you get punished for playing, then punished again for having played.

The whole thing reads like the devs didn’t know how to manage difficulty, so they hid rubber-banding behind “RNG.” Player at full HP? Nudge a hidden slider. Doing too well? Flip a table. It’s not emergent chaos; it’s a slot machine wearing a grimdark mask.

Bring a healer—the Vestal, obviously—and watch the game target and tilt her until you’re chain-healing your healer every two or three turns while also babysitting her stress bar that skyrockets well past the rest of the party. It genuinely feels like the system resents you for bringing a legitimate support and will do anything to make it a liability.

Then there’s the affinity/relationship nonsense, a “gotcha” layer that randomly scrambles your plans because the dice felt spicy. It’s not strategy; it’s sabotage by spreadsheet.

This isn’t “hard.” It’s a time sink engineered to manufacture frustration and call it design.

Avant toute chose, sachez que j'ai l'habitude des jeux durs, des rogue-like demandant de la réflexion, et j'adore les challenges. Je peux jouer au jeu le plus dur du monde et l'adorer mais à deux conditions : que je n'ai pas l'impression de perdre mon temps et surtout, SURTOUT qu'il soit [u] juste.[/u]

Sauf que c'est clairement pas le cas de celui là.

[h1] Prenons un exemple : [/h1]
Contexte : j'ai fait le donjon 5 fois avec cette équipe et plus de 20 fois en tout, inutile de dire que je connais bien la zone

Déjà cette fois-là particulièrement le layout du donjon était horrible.
Bien que j'ai fait cette même quête 10 fois auparavant avec la même quantité de nourriture, et bien cette fois-ci j'en avais pas assez. Je n'ai eu absolument aucun contrôle sur cette situation. 

Le TOUT PREMIER combat de la TOUTE PREMIERE PIECE a fait atteindre 80 de stress à mon médecin de la peste sans que je ne puisse ABSOLUMENT rien faire (mon premier tour de jeu a vu mon équipe rater 4 fois les 2 incantateurs adverses sur des 90% de réussite, grandiose). Je n'ai eu absolument aucun contrôle sur cette situation non plus. 

ET EVIDEMMENT il a fallu que je tombe sur le SEUL layout en 7 heures de jeu qui nécessitait 2 pelles. Evidemment. En 2 pièces mon médecin de la peste est devenu fou. Encore une fois aucun contrôle.

Le layout a affamé mon équipe parce que je n'avais pas assez de nourriture mais encore une fois ne connaissant pas le layout du donjon en avance je suis obligé de piffer complètement mes provisions ? j'ai fait 15 runs où 12 suffisait mais je dois en déduire que une fois sur 15 je dois en prendre 16 c'est ça ? Encore une fois aucun contrôle.

Avant d'entrer dans la toute dernière salle et de valider la quête,  le collecteur spawn (4% de chance que ça arrive) et j'en ai déjà battu un avant SAUF QUE le début du donjon m'a déjà fisté mon médecin de la peste et aussi accessoirement la seule classe de mon équipe qui aurait pu s'en sortir contre lui. Aussi pour je ne sais quel raison je ne pouvais pas fuir ce combat en particulier (???). Donc je dois en déduire que je dois prendre en compte en montant mon équipe que même si elle a pu faire 5 fois le donjon avant je devrais faire des changements pour inclure le fait que j'ai 4% de chance de me faire wipe si je ne le fais pas ? Aucun contrôle de la situation. Encore.

Je l'ai déjà fait plein de fois avant mais là je me retrouve avec un layout horrible, affamé, sans possibilité de fuir et à une pièce de la fin du donjon pour que juste en fait, et même en le connaissant par coeur, le jeu décide de me faire perdre mon équipe ? 

Bilan :

[u] Est-ce que ma connaissance de jeu (et du donjon) a été récompensée ? [/u] Non. 
[u] Est-ce que j'ai perdu parce que j'ai mal fait certaines choses ? [/u] Ma seule issue aurait été de fuir mais même mon ami (qui a fini le jeu en stygien accessoirement) a été surpris que l'option de fuite ait été désactivée. J'estime donc que non.
[u] Est-ce que j'ai appris quelque chose d'intéressant pour mes runs futures ? [/u] Oui. Que le jeu est injuste.

Ca a wipe mon équipe et accessoirement 3h de jeu passée avec (sans compter les ressources utilisées pour eux) à cause d'un truc que je déteste : une injustice. J'ai perdu parce que le jeu voulait que je perde. Je n'ai rien appris parce que je suis mort sur un truc que je connaissais déjà, juste par une succession de malchance. 

Et quand j'ai compris ça et surtout vu qu'il était impossible d'utiliser des héros de plus haut niveau pour faire XP les personnages plus bas niveau, j'ai tout de suite compris que j'allais repasser des heures de gameplay répétitifs juste pour compenser le fait que le jeu décide parfois de détruire ma progression pour le fun. Et ce genre de situation complètement injuste et sans intérêt m'est arrivé plus d'une fois en 7h de jeu.

Et ça, ça ne s'appelle pas de la difficulté. Ce n'est pas un jeu difficile. C'est un jeu INJUSTE, et qui ne semble difficile qu'en aspect parce qu'il est injuste. Il est injuste sur bien plus d'aspect que ses combats et son exploration.

Même dans le hub du village, tu peux perdre du temps parce que le seul slot utilisable pour un personnage est occupé (Que fais un prêtre dans une maison close d'ailleurs ?) ou des fois juste tes personnages décident de... ne pas revenir après leurs soins ? Ce qui force l'adaptation d'accord, mais ce qui peut aussi forcer de créer des équipes sans aucune synergie et qui ont plus de chance de prendre cher juste parce que encore une fois le jeu en a décidé ainsi ?

Je peux accepter de devoir me préparer pour aller dans un donjon, d'accord. Je peux accepter de théoriser des builds ou quoi qui marchent mieux dans certains endroits mieux que d'autres. 

Enfin, je peux accepter que l'aléatoire dans les rogue-like peut annihiler une run et que ça fait partie du jeu. 

Sauf que là, il ne s'agit pas de JUSTE relancer une run et tant pis. Là, il s'agit de refaire XP l'équipe, de leur racheter du matériel, et donc en fait refaire tout ce procédé chiant en boucle dans les mêmes premiers donjons pour avoir une autre chance de continuer, et encore une fois ce n'est qu'une chance parce que tu n'es pas à l'abri d'un wipe complètement indépendant de ta volonté et de ta connaissance de jeu. Et de ce que j'ai vu, plus tu progresses, et plus c'est pire.

Pour résumer, ce jeu avec tout son aléatoire récompense les joueurs patients et non les bon joueurs. Même si la connaissance de jeu est importante évidemment, le fait que 90% des systèmes du jeu soient régit par de l'aléatoire rend l'expérience frustrante et injuste, mais pas difficile comme beaucoup de gens le pensent.

Ce qui le rend, malgré l'emballage vraiment attrayant, sans aucun intérêt. Ce n'est pas un bon jeu, il détruit votre progression de manière complètement arbitraire, et vous force à refaire du grind et des choses que vous avez déjà vu pour retourner dans un contenu que vous ne connaissez pas encore.

Mais surtout une chose le rend très mauvais.

As I gaze upon the insurmountable task of righting the mistakes of a man i knew not, with strangers brave and foolish enough to stand with me as unimaginable horrors birth themselves into my reality I bear witness to the the epitome of the lions sin of pride that I believe this task to be possible. I look at my compatriots not knowing whether or not they will live to greet their friends back at the hamlet and realize that it should burden me to not even know their proper names, nor does it bother me that their deaths will be my fault and mine alone. 
The light bears witness to the righteous human will to buck the fate of the inevitable. May the light and its god, real or no, shine its merciful gaze upon these disposable and fearless heroes. For I will not be given this same gaze when I must answer to not only my sins, but with the lives I let fall.
For in order to fell the beasts of the void, you must be its neighbor, in morality and sanity as I not mourn the loss of the inadequate, I simply gather more fools to go further until they too meet the same fate

It's fun. Be the evil guy, using mercenaries and adventurers as an expendable resource. Risk their health, sanity, and lives for treasure and heirlooms. Send home the battle worn and mad ones knowing more fools will quickly offer to take their place. They gain quirks, diseases, and afflictions when they are so stressed that their virtue is tested and they become afflicted with some kind of hysteria or show their virtue. These give them "characters" which you must work around, or work on adjusting. How well you look after them is up to you.

If you like the idea of repeatedly assembling new parties from a line-up of reprobates each with their own personal quirks, and trying out every hairbrained synergy you can think of then this game is for you.

If you hate unfair RNG this game is not for you.

For me, the most joyful moments in this game are common place: when faced with a dire situation caused by bad luck, like party members afflicted or on deaths door, yet guile and raw audacity pull you through. Then you are faced with the decision: will you let the heroes turn back? Or will you send them yet deeper into the dungeon?

A one of a kind brutal experience with little to no hand holding that offers a most authenthic dark fantasy strategy rpg-like setting with many immersive elements that make it feel incredibly good to play. Everything about it feels right though some classes such as antiquarian feel..lacking. But most of them are well balanced and can bring a lot to the table if used right and the mod support for this game is also extremely well done and easy to do. The game is hard but not so hard as to think impossible and as long as it is played smartly you can overcome any challenge the game throws at you but if you are too greedy your characters will die so knowing when to retreat and just run is of essence. The storyline is a bit hard to understand unless you read the notes scattered around the various dungeons but the world building is done extremely well with lots of diverse enemies for you to face off against in various locations, the trinkets are well done, the quirk and stress system are well thought out though I would have loved if it had a little more.. depth let's just say. For example to have like a relationship mechanic among characters like in dd2 where they can become friends, lovers, enemies etc. and see them talking to one another, having more slice of life content with your characters such as seeing them buy weapons, interact with one another during their free time, have like an opinion of you as the player based on the actions that you take and depending on that give buffs, debuffs and things of this sort so that you can build and forge a bond with the ones you recruit and start seeing them as actual people and not just simple NPCs that whether alive or dead doesn't matter as they're replaceable. Having this type of content would actually make you feel bad if they were to die as you would get to know their thoughts, feelings, hobbies etc. and get to understand them as a person not just what they can do in terms of combat and you could tie it extremely well with the quirk mechanic for example if suffering from imposter syndrome quirk for him to actually express that like 'I feel that the skin I wear is not my own, as if one day I just woke up and inhibited this vessel of madness and am now stuck living a life not my own' while going out to have a drink with him at the tavern or something like that to tell you about himself. But overall the game is fantastic and i'd give it like a 9.25/10, a must play for any dark fantasy strategy game enjoyer, the only thing holding it back for me are the sense of detachment it makes you feel towards the characters inadvertently by not delving more into the aspects I had mentioned earlier. This is all I had to say, thank you for taking time out of your day to read this

Well, the game is a fresh idea, surely interesting and with a good graphical art that is visually nice. Also the game mechanic is simple but robust, so why a thumb down?

Simple answer. You got a constant feeling while you playing that AI just cheats in every possible way to keep the difficulty level high. Is not a matter of skills or timing, nor stats or class. No matter what will be you choices, the AI will ALWAYS have better tools to overcome the odd, even with multiple debuff and prots for your characters, things weird will happen. 

I understand that is probably part of the game and generally speaking I like games with a steep difficulty curve, but, only when I feel it's fair, congruent and logic, not coded to work around the situation in favor of the AI "no matter how". 

That feeling is something I can't remove, it's always present and is a little annoying.

After dozens of hours of painstakingly building a team and managing their stress levels, a single botched stun roll during a boss fight can wipe out your entire campaign. The game's mechanics are meticulously designed, but the permadeath loop becomes unbearable when hours of progress vanish in seconds. A lack of manual save points after pivotal moments exacerbates the frustration, with no way to recover from a string of bad luck. Not recommended unless you thrive on extreme, punishing challenges and have the patience to restart repeatedly.

I can still recall all the stress and fear I had when I entered for the first time the Darkest Dungeon... Honestly it was a terror. I must admit I hate losing my goons, and I'm very careful and managed to farm enough to feel confident getting back to it. I also "cheated" a bit, looking at what kind of resist one would need... But reaching the end of this game was a real challenge.

Weirdly, while I hate "dice rolling" decisions, here in DD it worked, because the whole game screams at you that if something wrong can happen, it'll happen. So when random bad events happens, it's business as usual.... But when you happen to have a positive outcome (finish a boss with a critic when you know you're dead on next turn, get a Virtue, etc..), it's an epiphany!

Building your town, RPG and level up your heroes, looting, questing, diverse and (almost) all balanced characters... What a hit!
I was expecting just a quick run, but ended up sinking 60+ hours into it. Toward the end it did get a bit tiring, but overall it’s still a fantastic experience.

This game is hard and punishing but it counter balance with a strong rewarding feeling. 

You will abandon quest, you will lose characters (permanently) and a good run can turn quickly into a "am I going to survive this battle/dungeon ?" feeling. 

Uncertainty at it's finest.

So I did an entire failed run not knowing how to put items into curio and my characters kept going insane and killing themselves and each other until my friend told me I was doing it wrong.

And in my second run, every single character I've recruited is alive and...well not well, they have mumps.

it's weird in a good way once you can wrap your mind around the fact that your characters in game actually are realistically imperfect and that that debuffs aren't just negatively designed, they somehow managed to make them work out beneficially towards your end as well is what made this game shine.

play it only if you have a LOT OF TIME to spare, because it takes a lot of brain juice cranking and huge gambles to even get by sometimes.

This game starts as any other game at first but you realise fast how a situation changes from manageable to complete chaos in 2 turns, and then it it hits you.. The realisation that you just sentenced your party to an early grave.
Your characters die, quests fail and gold that you always seem to have enough of until you noticed that you can't even buy enough supplies for the next dungeon and you start asking yourself which characters you like the least.
 A game that just doesn't hold back and where your mistakes matter.. Unforgiving and at points unfair, but that makes it an experience that i can't say i've ever had in a game before.

you need to play meta or have luck.

A TANK got oneshotted in first round with no darkness without having a chance to do something on the easiest difficulty. (after playing 50+ hours i know this does not happen often)

Hitting is luck (nothing is 100%, 95% is max).
Dodging etc is also luck.
Either u lose 1mio heroes until u get the gear and income to reduce the luck.
(grind for no reason without learning anything new)

oh and btw. it is possible to softlock this game via retreating.
u will have no money for anything.

so i guess it is expected to lose your heroes.

There is no help about the enemy skills,
either look it up or suffer until u know all of them and their counter.

Play slay the spire/FTL/X-com. not this RNG mess here,

btw. alt+f4 can break the game or your safe but this game is a messy dark suffering anyway.

after reaching Engame i can say, get your hands of this game, it baits u with fun early game, grind, learning, finding comps and discovering new things, in the end it will all change to play meta and dmg/crit everything or get oneshot by every mob.

At the early game u maybe think buffing and debuffing is good, this will stop working in the end as everything has 80% resist.
This also goes for the hit chance, if you think 60 dodge and 95 hit chance it enough, you are wrong. (95% is actually max ...)

After 90h of time waste, i can now 100% day, this game is NOT game for people who do not like to hit the wall with their head until the wall breaks ... (at least in the end).

After taking notes of everything i came across,
the game went way more smoothly (some unlucky oneshot crit moments can still happen).

This game does not deserve a negativ Review, yet ... why hide all info?
Show us the enemy skill rules, show us the Heroes passives.
Remember which items cleanses which curio on ALL Heroes not the one participating in the raid.
Stuff like this is unnecessary, feels like a game from the 80s/early 90s where u took note about everything because the game does not tell you.

But when you got your notes written down, this game is maximum fun.
If you do not suffer in real life enough. this game is made for you.

I believe this can be considered a "perfect" game. Anything taken away or added would make it a worse experience. The journey from start to finish is finely tuned and has a smooth ramp up of difficulty and complexity. Great art, great VO, simple but crunchy mechanics. You'll make big mistakes and totally screw yourself on a run, internalise the lesson for the next one and execute it better. It was hyped up for 10 years, and somehow didn't disappoint.

Darkest Dungeon is one of the most unique turn-based RPGs I've ever played. It's a game that doesn't hold your hand, and that's exactly why it's so good. The game perfectly combines brutal permadeath with a stress and affliction system that is so immersive I feel stressed out every time a hero freaks out. This creates a constant sense of dread and tension. The hand-drawn, gothic art style is incredible and creates a mood that perfectly matches the gameplay, while the iconic narration is essential to the oppressive atmosphere. 

This is a must-play for anyone who appreciates a truly demanding and atmospheric experience.

Recommended for people who like hard games that you actually have to understand and get good at.

Contrary to what you might think, the correct way to play this game is not an AoT Season 1 simulator where your success necessarily must come with the deaths of countless fighters. After all, the equipment they're carrying is far too expensive and valuable to waste. Here then is where the learning curve of Darkest Dungeon arises: knowing how to compose a roster that can reliably complete missions and perpetuate the trickle of resources you get from dungeons to eventually build up your force to confront the final threat. 

Like any war, what determines your victory in this long campaign is decided almost entirely before you actually send out your heroes into the dungeon, with their success being contingent on adequate logistics, mental strength, and sufficient experience/training. How well you master this management aspect of the game will make the difference between your party fighting like a group of Doomslayers or just shivering, pathetic, monster bait. Don't misunderstand, your characters *will die*, be it from misplaying or sheer bad luck, but if you can mitigate those circumstances by having a good structure, then you will win out in the long term. 

Also, this game's aesthetics are just absolute peak, it literally speaks for itself.
In time, you will know the tragic extent of my failings.

It's an interesting take on a party based dungeon crawler. Unfortunately, the core gameplay loop is clunky and gets old pretty quick. The way that the dungeons are designed is off-putting from a mechanical perspective, which is unfortunate because the setting is decent. Moreover, the narration is over-stylized to the point of caricature and wears out its welcome quickly.

This game is brilliant. Is it difficult? Yes. Does it sometimes feel like it doesn't like me? Yes. Does it feel like Red Hook Studios doesn't like me? Yes. But even though it's a game with a cruel streak a mile wide, its multilayered strategy, easy-to-pick-up combat, and brilliant presentation go a long way in making up for it.

CONTROLLER SUPPORT: Passable, at best. But at worst, God awful. The button mapping is not awful - I can’t understand why they didn’t go for a cursor you can drag around. In addition, the tutorials still refer to keyboard and mouse. Essentially a slap in the face to controller players.

I can’t for the life of me figure out why this game is so highly rated. However, I’ve said the same thing about games poor rated that I’ve quite enjoyed. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ 

There are many, many more rogues out there that provide the same effect without being so terribly random and annoying, that also care about people who use controllers.

Hope this helps someone.

Game is great if you love abyssmally bad RNG systems, defeat spirals, and a game economy that necessitates grinding painstakingly designed to waste your time. the difficulty can be mitigated a *little* by strategy and team composition, but you're always one bad roll away from bricking a 50+ hour campaign. 90% of the difficulty is also painfully artificial , like inventory capacity and stack size vs. amount of resources needed for vital town upgrades, and the inability to use higher-level characters on lower-level missions to train up replacements for the guys who got wombo combo'd to death because you flipped tails once. I like difficulty (XCOM, Souls-likes, bullet hell) but this is just exacerbating and frustrating. Playing this is like being Sisyphus, except you also have Prometheus' eagle eating your liver and every step has a 50% chance that a clown materializes and whacks your nuts with a mallet.

Hiya :D Cap here, this is my first time ever making a review of a game so... enjoy!1!!11!

First of all, if you get frustated easily, PLAY THIS GAME (in modderation or you'll get really mad to the point of almost TRASHING your place because a FUCKING shambler killed ALL OF YOUR PARTY and then you'll stop playing for a days, then weeks and then months... but you'll come back, eventually. They always do.) you will have a great journey with this masterpiece, I had a great time trying and failling and sometimes actually ANNIHILATING dungeons or getting destroyed by those goddamn crits, but that's another story, anyway, the stress mechanic is an actual threat, and a fun one to manage, this is one of the few games that i know of, that actually implements this mechanic perfectly and shows how the horrors of the dungeons affect the minds of your roster or you get a glorious moment of luck and your hero becomes virtuous (And then he gets absolutely annihilated and gets crit'd 5 FUCKING TIMES and dies at the first door check... LOVELY RIGHT????) and he/she or it saves the day by becoming powerfull!

IGNORING all that B O R I N G rant, I'll highlight some things that made me fell in love with the game:

1.- The Narrator: his voice makes me feel *waaays* and i'm straight, the work he did inspired me to try voice acting (I haven't actually done anything but welpies) and he fits so perfectly with the whole theme of the game. I love his snarky comments while in battle and how much of a dick he is, he is the definition of "The Florida MAN".

2.- The quirky characters (Not all but my personal favorites):
    * Crusader: He is a crusader man, what else can i tell you???
    * Jester: Imagine dying to music
    * Houndmaster: cute doggo
    * Vestal: Too horny to die
    * Shieldbreaker: nightmares that can kill you

3.- The CUNTS that ruin your day: Their desings are  on point, the swine and the spooky skellies are my favorites.

Anyway that's all from me, buy this game if you ever have the time and money and don't get too mad if you loose a good character, don't get to attached.

My first time playing this game I was immediately hooked by the oppressive atmosphere and the thematic gameplay. I had a blast from start to finish. That being said there were some parts of the game that dragged in pace but for me this was not an issue as I enjoyed the moment to moment of Darkest Dungeon.

My second time playing I still had a good time but many of the pacing issues became more apparent and the lower level mission no longer held my interest as they had become cake walks if I prepared properly. That being said I had fun returning to the game and steamrolling many of the enemies that had given me grief on my first go.

I am currently on my third playthrough and unfortunately by this time I have experienced many more experimental and creative rpgs and it no longer keeps my interest as it used. I still love this game and adore its character and game design and I have incorporated the mechanics into many of my own RPG and TRPG designs.

TLDR: Had a great time on my first play through
Second play through: was good but pacing issues become stronger
Third play through: Still love the game but find it harder to enjoy like I used to.

I recommend playing this game particularly if you are a fan of dark-fantasy turn-based rpgs. Once you finish this I highly recommend playing the Official Fanmod Black Reliquary as it utilizes and improves many of darkest dungeons strengths and weaknesses.

The ending is dog shit. The gameplay loop is extremely punishing, but there's mods and settings to adjust it so the game can be played by anyone willing. That's hardly the problem. 
Maybe I don't have the same understanding of the "dark fantasy" genre as others, and I have no knowledge of eldritch horror, but you'd think a gameplay loop this brutal would have an awesome payout of an ending to make it all satisfying to have suffered through. Instead we get looped back to the beginning of the game, having accomplished literally nothing, and that's the only ending. Congrats peasant, you wasted money and time in a game that makes you feel the waste, doubly so if you played at the intended difficulty. This game has completely consumed my life. One day, I was walking down the road and I came across a group of kids holding down a rope, with an adult in the back having a clear line of sight to make sure the children wouldn't wander around. Immediately, I imagined this as an enemy party, the kids as maggots, the adult as the backline tank - the wendigo. My frontline dps dealer (my hands) went to work as I demolished the 2 front kids with my cleave attack, yelling "MY LEPER NEVER MISSES." The rest of the enemy party was clearly surprised by my attack, given their horror. I then proceeded to pellet the other two with stun (my roundhouse kicks) until they fell to the ground. The big one put their hands up in the air, as if to plead for mercy. It was too late for any lingering sympathy, so alas I gave them a final lesson. "Monstrous size has no intrinsic merit, unless inordinate exsanguination be considered a virtue."

Games not bad at all, but when difficult mechanics get pilled upon eachother, they don't 'add' to the difficulty, they multiply it.

There's two main ones I don't feel bad about removing


[b] Level restrictions [/b] 
When a hero gets too experianced, they will straight up refuse to do weaker quests. This kind of behaviour is worthy of a back hand, especially considering their weaker little siblings do need a helping hand getting more xp every now and then.

To [b] remove [/b] this, do the following:
Go into 'Browse local files' and then go into campaign > quest > quest.restriction.json, and then set all the numbers in "resolve_level_threshold_table" to 99.

This really doesn't break the game much considering [b] stress [/b] will stop you from sending out the same heros over and over


[b] Short Stacks [/b] 
Your inventory is very limited, this isn't helped by the amount of stacks overflowing on top of each other and taking what precious little space there is. Quest items are especially troubling because of this, and most of the time you have throw a good portion of treasure away, truely upsetting

To [b] remove [/b] this, do the following:
Go into 'Browse local files' and go into inventory, every file within will have the stack amount for every item under '.base_stack_limit', just set all of those to what you want, personally I would set gold to '9999' and all quest items to '3' at the very least

I still find I run out of gold frequently, so it won't break the game for you

After adjusting these two I was able to enjoy and explore this game a lot. Is it cheating? maybe but honestly do it, makes the game feel like it's not just slapping you in the face constantly

My wife said if this review gets 50 likes and 5 awards, she will buy a case of beer, guys help me out.

To anyone reading these reviews who is confused by the massive swings between positive and negative, you need to know one thing: Darkest Dungeon is an emotional game. To people just starting out, it can seem baffling, unfair, and deliberately obscure. To people who have been playing since Early Access, and who have seen favourite party compositions and strategies rendered obsolete, the Steam reviews page is more of an extension of Reddit than anything else - a place to air grievances (legitimate or otherwise) over a game that they have dedicated a lot of time to.

What a lot of these reviews miss out is... y'know... the actual review part. On that front, I would say the following: the core gameplay is rock solid. At its heart, Darkest Dungeon has taken a minimalist, turn-based, four-man combat system and imbued it with massive potential for tactical thought and personal flair. Figuring out the best role for each of your heroes (chosen from a fairly generous pool of classes) and suddenly realising a unique way of getting them to synergise is immensely gratifying. Unlike a lot of games, it doesn't feel like there is a a ring-fenced area of "correct", vanilla play that only the very high-level players can get past; instead, you are encouraged and rewarded for coming up with your own strategies from the get go. The central combat system is smart, it pushes you to experiment, and there is a lot of room to come up with a playstyle that feels like your own, unique creation.

HOWEVER! If that's all Darkest Dungeon was, it would be a neat tablet-based distraction, but ultimately sterile. It is the stuff that comes layered on top of it that is the source of its intrigue - and also the source of a lot of the frustration you'll see directed at it. As a typical RPG player, you naturally do everything you can to guarantee the safety and efficacy of your character(s), and it feels inherently uncomfortable to work in a game environment that leaves you perpetually on your toes and at risk of failure. DD refuses to let you settle into a comfortable routine, and a massive enemy critical attack, an ambush in pitch-dark while camping, or a series of misses on your part can topple you from a seemingly-unassailable position to a very desperate one. The potential for a fail-cascade is what turns off many new players, and even drives experienced ones to the occasional rage-review, but it is also vital to the fundamental risk-reward balance of the game, which is designed to punish complacency and encourage the utmost thought on your part.

As you progress through a dungeon, you constantly need to balance a dwindling supply of light, food, sanity and health (although they can be restored in some ways), while also trying to complete objectives and collect much-needed loot with limited backpack space. Usually, this is the sort of gameplay I dislike; feeling that there is a time-limit, that I can't plough through something at my own speed in relative safety, is an uncomfortable experience after most games. However, the actual result is some very effective tension. In a normal RPG (say... Diablo), the steady drip of ever-increasing numbers is satisfying in a functional sort of way, but in DD the stakes are so high that getting a critical hit or dodging a huge attack always feels like a [i] moment [/i] rather than just a nice bonus. 

It can initially feel punishing and unfair, since most gamers are hard-wired to see a hero death (which is permanent), a catastrophic turn-around, or a "tactical retreat" as a failure. Likewise, the element of randomness can make it feel like your hard work and smart play has not been rewarded, like you're just a random collection of atoms buzzing around in a meaningless void where there is no God or higher authority to dispense justice or distinguish right or wrong.... It takes time to realise that you were never [i] meant [/i] to have it easy, that it's [i] always [/i] been a gamble, and you can't expect a perfect S ranking - all you can do is make the best play you can with the information you have. It takes time to realise that the game is pushing you to accept loss and difficulty as part of the game, rather than a failure.

 Even I rage quit every now and then - but I always come back, because, as I said, Darkest Dungeon is an emotional game. You invest (real) time and (fake) money in your group of heroes, the odds are massively stacked in the House's favour, none of your guys is going to come out unscarred, you are going to face some serious setbacks, but you return because actually making it, actually landing that last hit at the last possible moment, realising you've scraped through again, is always a surprise, and an amazing one at that.
The stress mechanics in game affects you in real life

60 hours into the game and I write this review because I've read people mentioning the most simple and constant fact about this game: that it is brutal. Don't expect to always win, or that everyone will always survive. Somebody will eventually die, somebody will eventually go insane, and after that there's just more of that. This games throws whatever it can to make you lose, and even if you win the biggest of fights you won't always be able to win in the end. Why? Because this game takes planning and thinking forward to the extreme, and it will trick you into overextending in some way just so that you will die. And that's great.

The game itself, being an RPG, has many stats and many mechanics that interact in one way or another with everything else. Then why draw a point to it? Because you must NEVER, EVER underestimate or overestimate those values. The fact that an attack has 80% of hit chance vs a 95% hit chance is huge in the early levels, and as you go up in difficulty those rifts keep getting bigger and bigger, specially when you can find enemies in the early levels with evasion as high as 25. It means you need to plan for it. The fact that an enemy can inflict stress damage to your party, that it can protect another enemy, and that it has particular resistances to certain status can change drastically your aproach to each encounter, and the fact that depending on where you're going you will be facing a specific group of enemies plus some more generic ones. It means you need to plan for it. The fact that you can specialize certain classes to be more oriented towards a particular role (most of the time) and that you have only so much money at hand to do so, and that you need to divide it between that, buying better gear so that they won't die (and further specialize them) and keeping them sane. It means you need to plan for it. If nothing else, this game is a game about planning as carefully as you can, letting as little to chance as you can. Because the more you leave up to chance, the higher the chances something will wipe you out, or that you'll drive yourself into a corner you may not want to go into. 

But then again, as many other reviewers have said, the game gets too hard if you care too much about all of your characters. Having to take care of a roster of up to 26 someway-or-another twisted people can only get you so far, and you won't always be able to keep them safe or have enought money to do so. It is ultimately your choice if you wish to stop caring about everyone but the ones you like the most, or if you wish to go as far a you can trying to veil for both your interests and your whole party's safety. 

Also, you must learn about everything anything in the game can do, and plan accordingly to that, ALWAYS TAKING INTO ACCOUNT WHAT HAPPENS IF EVERYTHING GOES WRONG. If you knows there are enemies that aren't weak to a specific kind of ailment, don't take too many characters that rely on that kind of ailment to do their stuff. If you know an enemy can heal or deal more damage than another, priotize getting rid of either it or the next biggest threat there is besides it. If you know your characters have quirks or traits that affect them in certain scenarios, take those too into account when choosing your party and where to go, if not also how much stuff to take to that mission. If you're trying to kill a enemy that is quite devastating but it can evade everything you throw at him, don't always try to kill it with everything if you are leaving more vulnerable targets that you can kill with less effort stacking up bits of damage against you. Every action, every health, every miss, every hit, every fight and every event inside the dungeons can make a huge difference when stacked. So try to always think over what's the optimal way of doing stuff and, if you don't want to get everyone killed, when you're far enough gone that your only reasonable option is to run away. Luck can be in your favor, but never try to abuse it.

Yes. Darkest Dungeon is unfair. Everything can kick your ass if you get caught in the wrong spot, if luck screws you over, or if you try to do more than you can. But if you really want to apreciate it, you must deal with every loss and every death, every failed resolve check and every loss, and learn from it. Try to learn how much is too much, how little is too little, what corners can be cut and what corners cannot. Learn what works with what and what doesn't. And if you really don't want to lose, don't feel bad if you need to go to the wikia to check on what will be expecting you on your next mission. Knowledge, and knowing how to use it properly, is the only thing you can rely on this game, and if you don't want the frustrating trial-and-error you need to get it, no shame in getting it from someone else. It's not as if it tells you everything, but starting from it as a basis and then piling up experience will get you to "know" the game, to really "feel" when things will go wrong, and if you can deal with a particular situation.

In conclusion, Darkest Dungeon is really hard, but it can be a rewarding experience. It is opressive by design, since that's how Red Hook wanted it to feel like, just so that every little victory you get is ever the sweetest, and every failure, if you learn from it, a word on caution and the knowledge on how lessen the chances of it repeating itself. Only get it if you think you can deal with stuff not always going according to plan, no matter how well crafted if may be, and getting crushed by letting minuscule things piling up. Those are the bread and butter of the game until you start to get the hang of how to manage those situations, and the real enjoyment of the game (besides maybe a bit of masochism) can only be gotten after it...even if luck can screw you over.

PD: Get mods if you can. Not all of them may be or seem good enough, but all of them add something interesting enough to the game.
